gold_sents: The plaintiffs filed a lawsuit on March 8, 2014, alleging that the City of Montgomery, Alabama, improperly imprisoned them for failing to pay traffic fines.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they did not have an ability to pay the fines due to their financial circumstances and that the city did not consider their ability to pay.[SENTMARKER]On May 1, 2014, the District Court granted the plaintiffs motion for a preliminary injunction, preventing the city from collecting more money from traffic tickets of plaintiffs'.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2014 the parties filed to dismiss the case pursuant to a settlement agreement, which included numerous changes to Municipal Court proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: This is a class-wide civil rights action brought in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the City of Montgomery and Judicial Correction Services, Inc. (JCS), a private for-profit corporation, for violating the Fourteenth Amendment due process and equal protection provisions of the United States Constitution by charging appeal bonds to those who could not afford to pay their traffic ticket fees, costs, and surcharges immediately.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their due process rights by imprisoning them when they could not pay their debt and by automatically converting monetary fines into days in jail at a rate of $50 per day.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on November 17, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to change their policies and practices and to refund the plaintiffs their outstanding fines.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that no one will be jailed again in the future for the inability to pay a $50 fine.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

Georgia, 461 U.S. 660 (1983), and Turner v. Rogers, 131 S. Ct. 2507 (2011) applied to municipal court proceedings, and awarded plaintiff's attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in November 2014.

gold_sents: On August 23, 2018, three Maricopa County, Arizona residents who have been referred to Maricopa County's Marijuana Diversion program filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona, Phoenix Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and monetary relief, claiming that the Maricopa County Attorney's Office and Treatment Assessment Screening Center jointly operated a marijuana possession diversion program that discriminated against the poor in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment, and led to unreasonable search and seizure in violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs amended their complaint twice to include new named plaintiffs for the class.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the defendant's motions to dismiss the complaint, and discovery is ongoing both for class certification and the underlying claims.

gold_sents: On March 8, 2006, the Pacific News Service filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the California Department of Corrections in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the defendants had violated the constitutional rights of the press and the public to attend, meaningfully observe, and gather and report on important information at executions being carried out by the defendants at the California State Prison at San Quentin.[SENTMARKER]On May 30, 2013, the issue in this case became moot due to a state court decision.[SENTMARKER]In Sims v. California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR), the California Court of Appeals held that CDCR’s lethal injection regulations were invalid for failure to comply with the APA.[SENTMARKER]The court permanently enjoined CDCR from carrying out the execution of any condemned inmate by lethal injection until their new regulations complied with the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]This case closed after a voluntary dismissal filed by the plaintiff organization.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 13, 2006, Pacific News Service (PNS) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) alleging that the inclusion of pancuronium bromide in San Quentin's lethal injection protocol violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]PNS alleged that the use of the 23 second drug in the lethal injection cocktail paralyzes all movement of the inmate's voluntary muscle fibers.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed, however, that one intended purpose and effect of the drug is to induce paralysis.[SENTMARKER]The case is not a challenge to the death penalty or to all lethal-injection executions, but rather the drug's use to conceal from the public possible manifestations of pain or other important information.[SENTMARKER]On February 10, 2006, the 2 Court consolidated the two cases, and the parties agreed that the case should be dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On August 29, 2010, the court ordered the CDCR to turn over its supply of sodium thiopental to the FDA.[SENTMARKER]The CDCR filed a motion to dismiss the case, claiming that it had complied with California’s 12 Administrative Procedures Act and that the Lethal Injection Regulations became final on 13 August 29, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion, but the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On May 22, 2012, several national and local news agencies filed a § 1983 lawsuit against the state of Idaho, alleging that the policy of the Idaho Department of Correction to prohibit public viewing of the preparatory phase of the execution process, during which the inmate is restrained and the IV is inserted, violates the First Amendment right to free speech and the Fourteenth Amendment right to due process.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on June 5, 2012, but the Ninth Circuit reversed the denial, on June 8, in time for the injunction to apply to the scheduled execution of Richard Leavitt.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, the District Court entered a permanent injunction ordering the Idaho Department of Corrections to modify their execution procedures to allow witnesses to the execution throughout the entire execution process.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 22, 2012, a coalition of media corporations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Idaho against the State of Idaho, the Idaho Department of Corrections (IDOC), and the Governor of the State, seeking a preliminary injunction, a permanent injunction, and declaratory relief in response to alleged First Amendment violations by the IDOC for the execution of a death row inmate.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that IDOC's execution procedures prevent uninhibited viewing of the entire execution of the condemned inmate.[SENTMARKER]On June 5, 2012, the parties entered into a Stipulation which requested that the parties submit a joint litigation plan for the Court's consideration to allow for discovery and a full evidentiary hearing on the request for permanent injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which IDOC agreed to implement a single lethal dose of pentobarbital through the IV instead of the three-drug series that was used for the November 18, 2011 execution of Paul Rhoades.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' request for expedited briefing and ordered the parties to participate in mediation with Chief United States Magistrate Judge Candy W. gold_sents: In 2016, prisoners that had completed their sentences but remained incarcerated by the Illinois Department of Corrections filed this class action against the state in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Illinois statutory scheme governing mandatory supervised release (MSR) for sex offenders and the requirement for offenders to have an approved “host site” in order to be released from custody violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court awarded the plaintiffs summary judgment on the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction on January 15, 2020,  requiring IDOC to present a plan for releasing class members from custody, and quarterly reports outlining steps that were being taken to ensure that all class members would be properly released by January 2, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of July 2020, the court's supervision of IDOC's progress is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 18, 2017, a class of homeless sex offenders filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Illinois Attorney General and the Director of the Illinois Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by denying them the right to live in compliance with the terms of mandatory supervised release (MSR) by imposing unmeetable restrictions on where they can live that must be satisfied in order for such individuals to be released on MSR.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on three grounds, including that the plaintiffs were indigent and homeless.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on the fourth ground.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit upheld the district court's decision to grant the defendants summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: This is a civil rights action brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Kansas against the City of Dodge City, Kansas and Ford County, Kansas.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the Defendant had a policy which unlawfully kept him in the custody of the Defendant in the Ford County Jail because he could not afford to post a cash bond pursuant to an established schedule for the alleged offense; .<n>The Plaintiff sought declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief.[SENTMARKER]The Court entered an injunction requiring the Defendant to release all individuals arrested (for non-warrant arrests) in the City for violation of municipal ordinances of the City on Own Recognizance Bonds ("OR Bonds") without further conditions of release as soon as practical after booking and will not require individuals to post any type of monetary bond.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant also agreed to pay the Plaintiff's costs and attorney's fees incurred by the Plaintiff and the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed with prejudice the Plaintiff’s claims for damages, costs, and attorney fees.

gold_sents: In 2015, indigent former criminal defendants filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that that the defendants had a practice of imprisoning individuals who had failed to pay court debts without meaningfully determining whether the individuals had the ability to pay the debt.[SENTMARKER]In August 2018, granted plaintiffs’ motion for class certification, and held that the Judges’ policy/practice of not inquiring into the ability of the persons falling within the certified class to pay before they are imprisoned for non-payment of court debts was unconstitutional, and that the Judges’ failure to provide a neutral forum for determination of such persons’ ability to pay was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit affirmed the lower court on August 23, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendants petitioned the Fifth Circuit to rehear the case en banc on September 6, 2019, but the court denied to rehear on September 30.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a petition for writ of certiorari in the U.S. Supreme Court on December 20, 2019.[SENTMARKER]Cert was denied on March 3, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: This class action lawsuit was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the City of New Orleans, the Orleans Parish Criminal District Court, and the Sheriff's Office.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by placing and keeping them in jail prior to any debt-collection proceedings when they cannot afford to pay the preset amount of money required for release after a Collections Department nonpayment arrest if the person seeks to contest the issue of nonpayment or the validity of the debt.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that the plaintiffs had no standing to pursue their claims for equitable relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In response to the economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic of 2020, Congress passed the CARES Act, which created, among other things, the “Paycheck Protection Program.”[SENTMARKER]Under this program, small business owners could apply for a loan from the Small Business Administration; if they later certified that all of the loan funds had been used for qualifying expenses, the loan would be forgiven.[SENTMARKER]The SBA’s rules disqualified many small business owners with criminal records.[SENTMARKER]Several small business owners brought this lawsuit against the SBA in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, challenging this criminal record exclusion.[SENTMARKER]On June 29, the court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the SBA to extend the application deadline for the named plaintiffs from June 30 to July 21, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The following week, Congress passed follow-up legislation extending the deadline for all applicants to August 8, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of July 29, 2020, further developments in the litigation are pending.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 8, 2015, a group of individuals brought a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the City of Ferguson, Missouri, alleging that the City was violating the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments by holding people in jail for longer than 48 hours without a neutral determination of probable cause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were unable to pay fines owed from traffic tickets or other minor offenses, were not afforded counsel or any inquiry into their ability to pay, and were held in jail indefinitely, in overcrowded and unsanitary conditions, and denied access to basic hygiene products and medical care.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the City's motion to dismiss the case for lack of jurisdiction, and the case was dismissed on February 13, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 27, 2015, a person jailed by the City of St. Ann, Missouri (the City), for failing to pay the fee required under the City's secured bail system, sued the City in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, arguing that the City had violated the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, and asking for declaratory relief, injunctive relief, damages, attorneys' fees, and costs.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the Judge assigned to the case, Judge Rodney W. Sippel, granted a stay in the proceedings to allow the parties to test the effects of a provisional settlement agreement, under which plaintiff agreed to drop his non-equitable claims, and under which the City agreed to end its secured bail policy and pay the plaintiff a $10,000 fee for acting as a class representative.[SENTMARKER]On May 4, 2018, a Consent Agreement was signed by Judge Sippel, whereby most of the original relief sought was agreed to by the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]The Court retains jurisdiction for two years, which may be extended for one more year upon agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 4, 2015, a homeless man filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the City of St. Ann, alleging that the City's policy and practice of refusing to release ordinance violation arrestees from jail unless they pay a generically set "bond" amount violated his constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff's counsel was previously the lead counsel in a similar case against the District of Columbia in which the Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on May 5, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: .<n>The City will notify all arrestees in writing upon release of the time, date, and place at which they are required to appear in court, if any.[SENTMARKER]The City will not hold an arrestee in its custody for another municipality on charges prosecuted in a municipal court for more than 10 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Parties agreed to seek, when and as needed, the continued stay of the lawsuit for up to a period of one year.

gold_sents: On August 9, 2016, a group of individuals who were placed in jail because of an inability to pay fines, penalties, and other charges filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued thirteen St. Louis County municipalities under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and § 2201.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by ArchCity Defenders and private counsel, asked the court for declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief, claiming violations of the Fourth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In their complaint, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendant municipalities engaged in a deliberate and coordinated conspiracy to fill their coffers by extorting money from thousands of poor, disproportionately African-American people in the St. Louis region.[SENTMARKER]On April 24, 2017, the case was dismissed as to all defendant municipalities except the City of St. Ann.[SENTMARKER]The case (including mediation efforts) is ongoing against the City.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 24, 2019, the City of St. Ann, Missouri, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against Velda Village Hills, the city of Beverly Hills, and the St. Louis County Sheriff's Office.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their civil rights by failing to provide adequate food, water, and medical care to inmates in their jails.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also failed to provide inmates access to a shower and limited inmates' use of cell phones.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on April 24, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the entry of a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In June 2017, a man awaiting criminal trial and Lexington National Insurance Corporation filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that that the Criminal Justice Reform Act violated the bail provision of the Eighth Amendment, due process under the Fourteenth Amendment, and freedom from unreasonable search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment because the act favored non-monetary pre-trial release conditions over bail.[SENTMARKER]After and appeal to the Third Circuit regarding denial of preliminary injunction and a subsequent denial of certiorari in the Supreme Court, the plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 14, 2017, a New Jersey criminal defendant filed a class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the Attorney General of the state and the Camden County Prosecutor alleging that New Jersey's Criminal Justice Reform Act (CJRA) violated his right to due process and his civil rights.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendants violated his Fourth Amendment rights by imposing severe restrictions on his pretrial liberty without offering him the opportunity to be released on monetary bail.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit affirmed the District Court's denial of the injunction, finding that the district court's decision to grant the preliminary injunction was not based on the merits of the case, but on the fact that the parties had agreed not to enforce the provisions of the CJRA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the complaint.

gold_sents: Persons in the custody of the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) brought this class action against DOCS and the New York State Division of Parole (DOP) for the extra-judicial imposition of sentences requiring post-release supervision.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was denied by the District Court, and the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion for summary judgment was granted with respect to several defendants, but denied on the issue of qualified immunity; and plaintiffs' cross motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of liability for three officers was granted.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the qualified immunity decision, but the Second Circuit affirmed.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendants moved for summary judgment again, but that motion was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is currently scheduled for trial in Summer 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] On June 9, 2006, the Legal Aid Society of New York filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of the New York against New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) and the N.Y.[SENTMARKER]Division of Parole (DOP).[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants' practice of adding a term of post-release supervision (PRS) to sentences in which PRS had not been No. 152836cv 1 in violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on the grounds that because plaintiffs’ constitutional rights were not "clearly established" at the time that those rights were allegedly violated, state officials were entitled to qualified immunity for their actions.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion for a preliminary injunction because the plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court to determine whether the plaintiffs' petition for a writ of habeas corpus was timely filed.[SENTMARKER]In the third instance, the court denied class certification, but the motion was denied as moot and the court never addressed the merits of class certification.[SENTMARKER]On September 8, 2015, the case was re-opened and the parties filed a motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion, and the defendants moved for a judgment of summary judgment on the ground that they were not entitled to qualify immunity because their actions were not clearly established.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2015, the court vacated the judgment, and remanded the case for further proceedings.

gold_sents: Civil Rights Corps sued Tulsa County and various judicial officers, alleging that the court system operated a wealth-based detention system by detaining arrestees without inquiring into their ability to pay bail.[SENTMARKER]While the plaintiffs motion for preliminary injunction was denied, the plaintiffs motion for class certification is still pending.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2018, a group of people arrested in Tulsa County, Oklahoma, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma on behalf of hundreds of people detained in the Tulsa County Jail solely because they could not afford to pay money bail.[SENTMARKER]The named plaintiffs alleged that the jail's wealth-based detention scheme, which jails people who are unable to meet secured financial conditions of release, violates their equal protection and due process rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, and the case was remanded for further consideration of the public's interest in light of the new rule in place at the time of their arrest.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's decision to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a consumer class action on behalf of consumers nationwide who had been the subject of misleading and inaccurate background reports sold by the defendant, RealPage, Inc. to landlords.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), alleging that the defendant, RealPage, Inc., adopted and maintained a policy and practice of failing to timely update the criminal record information it maintained so as to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged, thus not accurately reflecting the final disposition of these cases.[SENTMARKER]Moreover, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendant systematically violated FCRA by failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information the defendant maintains about consumers to these consumers upon request.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the defendant agreed to provide consumers additional information about federal agencies responsible for enforcing FCRA, refrain from including expunged criminal records in tenant screening reports, and disclose the names of vendors who retrieved criminal record information to consumers, plus damages.[SENTMARKER]The settlement term ended in 2020, and the case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 5, 2014, a consumer class action was brought in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia against RealPage, Inc. (RealPage) alleging violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C.  1681-1681x (FCRA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that RealPage violated the FCRA by failing to timely update the criminal record information that it maintains to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged and (ii) failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information it maintains about consumers to those consumers who made a request for their "file" copy.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on July 13, 2015, which established a $936,200 settlement fund for payments to class members and for attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: In 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that a local rule which required it to agree to garnishment of judgment fees from bail bonds before it could post bail for indigent arrestees violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution and threatened its ability to operate as a non-profit.[SENTMARKER]The District Judge granted a preliminary injunction in March 2020 enjoining the County Criminal Court Clerk from garnishing fees from bonds posted by the Bail Fund.[SENTMARKER]In December 2020, the District Judge approved a consent decree where the Bail Fund and the County Government agreed to make the injunction permanent.[SENTMARKER]The matter is ongoing as the parties are litigating over who should pay attorneys fees and how much.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||||| DATE [CONTRACTED] On February 5, 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund (NCBF) brought this action in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against the Nashville Office of the Clerk of the Criminal Court of the Twentieth Judicial District.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, and the right to due process, by denying bail to those who could not afford to post a bond.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss on March 17, 2020, and the parties entered a consent decree on May 22, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree enjoined the defendants from enforcing Rule 10(B) against any third-party attempting to post cash bail bonds in Davidson County.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the consent decree would inure to the benefit of the parties and their respective heirs, successors or assigns, and would be binding upon the parties.

gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2015, the Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the City of El Paso, the Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity, and other entities and officials alleging violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the E-Government Act (E.G.A.).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, EPIC alleged that the defendants violated the privacy rights of low-income debtors by intentionally refusing to inform them of their rights, refusing to properly inquire into debtors' financial inability to pay their fines and/or the debtors' reasons for failing to pay, and refusing to conduct a privacy impact assessment prior to collecting voter data.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied EPIC's request for a preliminary injunction, and the parties reached a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay $100,000 in damages to the plaintiff, and to pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendants to comply with the court's order that they not collect voter data prior to the completion of the data impact assessment.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on December 26, 2017.

gold_sents: In January 2016, two indigent women that served imprisonment terms at the Randall County Jail filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the City of Amarillo's municipal code created a modern-day debtors' prison and violated their Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]In August 2016, the Court granted the defendant's motion to dismiss and ordered the plaintiffs to pay $3,660.00 in litigation costs.
pegasus_output_sents: This is a civil rights action brought under 42 U.S.C.  1983 and the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution against the City of Amarillo, Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that the City's fine collection system is unconstitutional as applied to indigent individuals.[SENTMARKER]They also allege that municipal officers violated the Due Process Clause by failing to make an affirmative determination of indigency status and consider adequate alternatives to incarceration.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, arguing that the plaintiffs failed to state a plausible claim for municipal liability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: Foster children in Georgia's Fulton and DeKalb Counties brought suit against the state and counties Division of Family and Children Services.[SENTMARKER]The class of children alleged that they did not receive necessary treatment and services while spending months in emergency shelters, experienced abuse and neglect as a result of an insufficient number of caseworkers, and received inadequate health care and emotional services while in foster care.[SENTMARKER]In 2005 and 2006, the plaintiffs reached settlement agreements with the state, Fulton County, and DeKalb County.[SENTMARKER]As of November 2018, the State is still under the supervision of the independent monitor in order to meet the court-ordered benchmarks, having not yet completed sufficient improvements.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2002, nine foster children in the custody of the Georgia Department of Human Resources filed this action in the Superior Court of Fulton County on behalf of a class of Fulton and DeKalb County foster children and a subclass of African-American foster children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to correct alleged deficiencies in the foster care system.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motions to dismiss and for summary judgment, but the Tenth Circuit vacated and remanded with directions to consider separately each provision of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a consent decree in October 2005, which was approved by the district court on October 28, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties were unable to reach agreement as to the appropriate amount of fees and expenses to be awarded.[SENTMARKER]Finally, the District Court referred the case to mediation, where the parties agreed to pay the entire cost of mediation.[SENTMARKER]The District Court awarded fees of approximately $10.5 million, and the parties filed suit with the entry of a Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, claiming that the court's decision not to grant an attorney's fee enhancement was inconsistent with the Supreme Court's ruling in the case of Delaware Valley I.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with its decision.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, who are children in the custody of the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services (DYFS), brought suit against the state alleging abuse, neglect, and lack of services.[SENTMARKER]After the New York Times published several articles about the deaths of children in the care of DYFS due to lack of care, in 2003 the state entered into a settlement agreement providing for a systematic overhaul of the state child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]The latest modification of the agreement was made in 2015 and remains in force.
pegasus_output_sents: This is a class action lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services (DYFS), the Department of Human Services (DHS), and the state's Department of Social Services (DSS) on behalf of two homeless children who were in the custody of the Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the children's civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate in-for-dignified data in the form of a pre-placement preventive services program designed to help children remain with their families or be returned to their families when appropriate.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a modified settlement agreement in July 2006 that required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with an adequate amount of information about the DSS program.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, children in the custody of the New York City Child Welfare Administration ("CWA"), and children who, while not in the custody of CWA, are or will be at risk of abuse or neglect and whose status is known or should be known to CWA, sought declaratory and injunctive relief against both the city and state for systematic deficiencies that jeopardized their well-being.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed on December 13, 1995, and the parties reached to two separate settlement agreements, one with the city and one with the state, on December 2, 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs returned to court in January 2001, seeking an order directing the state to comply with specific terms of the state settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the state had acted with insufficient diligence in implementing the information management system, and therefore extended the terms of the agreement in this area and directed that the plaintiffs receive semi-annual reports.[SENTMARKER]The defendants provided a January 2017 report to show that they were continuing to develop, implement, and update their information systems for child welfare needs.[SENTMARKER]A year later, the court ended its supervision of the portions of the settlement that it had retained jurisdiction to enforce.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 1, 1995, a group of children who were the legal responsibility of the New York City child welfare system filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Mayor of the City, the Commissioner of the Department of Social Services, and the Governor of the State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City's Child Welfare Administration (CWA) was failing to provide the children with adequate counseling and support services to ensure that they were safe and being adequately cared for.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, but the parties moved jointly for conditional class certification and approval of a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]On March 31, 1999, the district court approved the settlement agreements.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed this appeal in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: This was a class action challenge to New York's unnecessary institutionalization of children in foster care in psychiatric facilities.[SENTMARKER]The initial settlement agreement, entered on February 28, 2011, provided for increased community-based placement opportunities for children in foster care with mental illness as well as individualized planning, staff training, and monitoring.[SENTMARKER]In addition to the initial settlement agreement, on July 7, 2011, the plaintiffs agreed to release defendants from all liability in exchange for payment from defendants.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2016, the parties agreed to extend the Court's jurisdiction until June 30, 2016, at which time its jurisdiction presumably expired.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2010, three children in the custody of the New York City Administration for Children's Services (ACS) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ACS violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by improperly placing and detaining children who are in foster care in acute-care psychiatric hospitals longer than necessary and failing to move these children to the least restrictive placements appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on October 12, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a new policy and procedure for the provision of emergency and inpatient mental health services for foster care and child protective system children.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is final and binding on all parties, as weB as their successors and assigns.

gold_sents: On May 30, 2013, an eleven-year-old child in the custody of the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS), filed a lawsuit in the Court of Common Pleas, Abbeville County, South Carolina, against SCDSS and the Boys Home of the South (BHOTS), alleging that, as a result of Defendants' failures, Plaintiff was sexually assaulted on multiple occasions, causing him severe and permanent mental injury.[SENTMARKER]Following removal to Federal Court, in early 2014, Plaintiff settled with both SCDSS and BHOTS for an undisclosed sum of money.[SENTMARKER]BHOTS also permanently closed as a result of the lawsuit.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 1, 2013, a South Carolina foster child filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina against the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) and Boys Home of the South, Inc. (BHOTS) alleging that he was sexually abused while in foster care by another foster child, A.R.[SENTMARKER]Dkt.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the sexual abuse was preventable because the SCDSS and BHOTS allegedly had notice and knowledge that the foster child alleged inadequate supervision at BHOTS.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that they failed to provide Plaintiff with urgently needed medical and mental health treatment after the alleged abuse.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment on January 21, 2014, and the parties agreed to a settlement on June 28, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the funds for John Doe will be placed in a discretionary trust and an educational trust for his benefit.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the court.

gold_sents: On January 12, 2015, a class action lawsuit was filed against the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, alleging numerous deficiencies in the operation of the state's child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2015, the parties reached an interim settlement agreement, providing for an end to certain SCDSS practices, as well as for studies of additional SCDSS practices.[SENTMARKER]Monitoring revealed incremental improvements in conditions, and the settlement remains in effect.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 4, 2016, the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) was sued in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina by a group of children who had been placed in the custody of the DSS at the direction and control of the agency.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the children were being placed in restrictive, institutional settings and were not receiving basic health care services.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a Final Settlement Agreement (FSA) in October 2016 requiring the DSS to develop a Health Care Improvement Plan (the "Plan") for all children in foster care in South Carolina and to provide medical and mental health services and access to services in the network.[SENTMARKER]The FSA also required the state to address long-standing problems experienced by children in the foster care custody and in the operation of the state's child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]The parties' joint report was filed on October 5, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The report was submitted to the court on October 13, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the final settlement agreement on October 20, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the court will have continuing jurisdiction to oversee compliance with the agreement until it is fully implemented.

gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] On February 23, 2007, a paraplegic customer of Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc. filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that Chipotle violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the California Disabled Persons Act (CDPA) by denying him full and equal access to two of its restaurants, one in Encinitas and the other in Pacific Beach.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiff's motion to dismiss, and the case was remanded to the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit remanded the case to the district court with instructions to enter judgment that Chipotle's 19 written policy violated the ADA and to issue appropriate injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On June 17, 2007, the District Court granted partial summary judgment to both parties.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing filed this ongoing lawsuit on behalf of several LSAT test takers against the Law School Admissions Council (LSAC).[SENTMARKER]The State claims that LSAC routinely denies reasonable accommodations to test takers with disabilities in violation of the California Unruh Civil Rights Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In 2014, the parties have agreed to a consent decree that the court approved.
pegasus_output_sents: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Law School Admission Council, Inc. (LSAC) on April 12, 2012 alleging that LSAC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the California Unruh Civil Rights Act (UNR) by failing to grant individual plaintiffs' requests for disability-related accommodations to test-takers of the Law 19 Admission Test (LSAT) in a manner accessible to individuals with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in May 2014 and the parties entered a consent decree in May 2014.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires LSAC to comply with the ADA and the UNR by providing accommodations to individuals who take the LSAT and to stop the practice of annotating test scores that are earned under non-standard time conditions.[SENTMARKER]The decree is effective for four years from the date it was entered.[SENTMARKER]In addition, LSAC is required to provide each individual plaintiff with a copy of their test score report.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion to dismiss the case with prejudice, and the case was dismissed on May 29, 2014.

gold_sents: Disabled plaintiffs sued a public transit agency for violation of the Americans With Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act, alleging their bus system presented numerous barriers to access, subjecting the plaintiffs to delay, embarrassment, and ridicule by passengers and drivers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree, in which the defendant agreed to remedy the problems with its bus system and pay $250,000 in damages, fees, and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 1999, the City of Steamboat Springs, Colorado was sued in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehabilitation Act) by failing to make its public transportation system readily accessible to and usable by persons who use wheelchairs.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of Title II of the ADA and of Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the City agreed to make certain improvements to its transit system.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was final and binding on the parties, including all principals, agents, and employees of the City.[SENTMARKER]In addition to making improvements to the transit system, the consent decree required the City to provide comprehensive training for all bus and van operators, dispatchers, and mechanics, as well as timely refresher training for any new operator or mechanic who demonstrates a lack of knowledge of proper wheelchair lift operation, maintenance, and repair.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the city to ramp or otherwise provide access to the restrooms at the Alpine Slide/stables area, a men's and a women's restroom on the east side of the rodeo grounds, and to develop and implement a public education program to promote the use of the city's transit system by individuals with mobility impairments.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 12, 2000.

gold_sents: Disabled patrons of a concert venue filed a class action against the owners and operators of the venue for failure to remove barriers to access.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, with Defendants agreeing not to obstruct wheelchair areas and to pay damages and attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 26, 1992, the Colorado Cross-Disability Coalition (CCDC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the owners, operators, lessors, and/or lessees of Fiddler's Green, a concert hall in Denver, Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The CCDC alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide adequate seating for persons with mobility limitations and their nondisabled companions in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were denied full and equal enjoyment of the services, facilities, privileges, advantages, and accommodations of Fiddler’s Green on the basis of disability.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs injunctive relief, liquidated damages, attorney's fees, and other costs.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2014, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (Amtrak) seeking to enforce Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and its implementing regulation, 49 C.F.R. Part 37.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Amtrak had violated the ADA by failing to make its stations readily accessible to and usable by individuals with disabilities, including individuals who use wheelchairs, and of necessary remedies to bring its services, programs, and activities into compliance with the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which Amtrak agreed to pay the United States a total of $1 million to resolve the complaint.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the parties agreed that the ADA would remain in effect for 10 years from the date of the effective date of this agreement, and that Amtrak would maintain records showing the dates and length of training, instructors, and attendees, including job titles.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required Amtrak to submit its ADASP Sunset Analysis to the DOJ and Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) and to submit a report to the Federal Railroad Commission (FRCC) within 60 days of the date it entered into the agreement.[SENTMARKER]In addition to the $1 million payment, Amtrak agreed that it would hire a full-time ADASP consultant to conduct a review of its facilities.[SENTMARKER]In a parallel action, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBOI) filed a civil action against Amtrak for violations of Title II and the implementing regulation.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in a settlement that was approved by the District Court in June 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a final judgment in favor of the federal government, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On July 22, 2013, attorneys from United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the State of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that nearly two hundred children with disabilities were unnecessarily segregated from their communities and the general population by the State, which had placed them in nursing homes.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ sought an injunction requiring the State to comply with Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C. § 12131-12134, which, as interpreted by the Supreme Court in Olmstead v. L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]In June 2014, the case was consolidated with another pending case, which is in the Clearinghouse as PB-FL-0007.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 20, 2011, the U.S. Department of Justice (the "DOJ") filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the Florida Agency for Persons with Disabilities ("APD"), alleging that the State of Florida violated the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA"), 42 U.C.[SENTMARKER]12131-12134, by placing hundreds of children with disabilities unnecessarily in nursing facilities.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ's complaint alleged that the state violated the ADA by failing to provide sufficient reimbursement rates for in-home nursing services for children with significant medical needs.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that Florida's policies and practices placed other children at serious risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on April 4, 2014, when the parties entered into a consent decree that required the State to implement a number of corrective measures to ensure that the children were placed in the most integrated setting appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]As part of the consent decree, the State also agreed to pay a total of $1 million to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2005, two organizations that advocates for people with disabilities filed this lawsuit n the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the City of Detroit, claiming that the city had failed to meet federal and Michigan accessibility standards in altering intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the parties negotiated a plant to correct the affected intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]As of 2018, a special master continues to monitor implementation of the agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: The Center for Community Access, Inc. and the Michigan Paralyzed Veterans of America (MPVA) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in June 2006 against the City of Detroit, Michigan, under the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City had violated the ADA by failing to install curb cuts to meet the required accessibility standards and codes.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary and attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On August 31, 2006, the District Court entered a final judgment in favor of the City.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the City to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees, costs, and a portion of the costs of the case.[SENTMARKER]The Court also ordered the city to comply with the ADA and Michigan law.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This was a case brought to make a 300 unit apartment complex in Canton Township, MI accessible to persons with mobility impairments.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in 2006 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan by two individuals and the Fair Housing Center of Southeastern Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The suit eventually resulted in about three quarters of a million dollars in retrofits, damages to the plaintiffs and attorney fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2006, a disabled resident of Canton, Michigan filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against Beztak Properties, Inc., a real estate development company, alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988 (FHRA) by failing to design, construct, and/or operate an accessible apartment complex in Canton.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants' failure to comply with the ADA and FHRA violated the plaintiffs' rights under Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 (C.R.A.[SENTMARKER]), and the FHRA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also violated the plaintiff's right to equal treatment under the Michigan With Disabilities Civil rights Act (PWDCRA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a partial settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by the court on October 2, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: A class action lawsuit was filed on July 10, 2012, against the Mississippi Department of Education, under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 (IDEA), alleging that the defendant had failed to execute its responsibilities under IDEA, by not ensuring that the Jackson Public School District provide disabled students with a free and appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment, even after conducting an investigation into the School District and identifying its systemic failure to meet its IDEA obligations.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on September 29, 2014 stipulating the implementation of a Program Sustainability Plan for the 2014-2015 school year.[SENTMARKER]On September 11, 2015 District Court Judge Daniel P. Jordan III granted a motion to dismiss with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi on behalf of children with disabilities in the Jackson Public School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 (IDEA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant, the Mississippi Department of Education (MDE), had failed to provide their children with the free appropriate public education they are entitled to receive under the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, finding that the defendants had violated the IDEA by failing to provide the children with appropriate services to address their deficits in reading and math.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide students with disabilities with a free appropriate education and to create a separate alternative school program to serve only those students who have been denied meaningful educational benefit from their IEPs.

gold_sents: On August 3, 2006, plaintiffs, a group of disabled persons receiving public benefits filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the South District of New York against the New York Human Resources Administration alleging that it discriminated against disabled persons by involuntarily segregating them by transferring their public benefits cases from local benefit centers to three hub centers that only serviced people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The Court approved a proposed settlement agreement in June of 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 19, 2006, the New York City Human Resources Administration (HRA) was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and New York State Human Rights Law (N.Y.[SENTMARKER]HRL).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the HRA discriminated against them on the basis of handicap in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction prohibiting further case transfers from local Job Centers to the hub centers.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to this court in November 2011 and the parties attempted to negotiate a settlement of monetary claims.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement on November 7, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendant would provide plaintiffs with draft training materials for their review and comment and would pay the plaintiffs reasonable counsel fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the court on November 15, 2014.

gold_sents: Students sued the New York City Department of Education, the City of New York, and the chancellor of the New York City Department of Education to seek injunctive relief under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and New York state law.[SENTMARKER]The student plaintiffs are either student in Staten Island District 75 schools or vulnerable to being sent to those schools, which are separated from New York City community schools.[SENTMARKER]District 75 students receive their education in a restrictive setting where they are largely isolated from interactions with students who do not have disabilities.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief in the form of a permanent injunction against future violations and an order for a remedial plan to reimagine policies, practices, and norms that will permit each student to learn in the most integrated setting possible.[SENTMARKER]The case remains open.
pegasus_output_sents: Disability Rights New York filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the New York City Department of Education (DOE) and the DOE's Chancellor, Richard A. Carranza, on behalf of students with disabilities who were being educated in segregated and unequal public schools and classrooms in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504), the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and the NYC Human Rights Law (NYCHRL).[SENTMARKER]The Named Plaintiffs and Class Members alleged that the DOE and Carranza violated the ADA, Section 504, and NYCHRL by placing children with disabilities in the least restrictive environment in which they can learn alongside their non-disabled peers, to the maximum extent appropriate to their needs, and by failing to provide appropriate academic interventions to engage these students in learning and permit them to demonstrate mastery of Standards-based curricula.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the DOE.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Four blind or visually impaired library patrons sued the Free Library of Philadelphia in in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, seeking relief under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and Title II of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the Library's new program to lend e-reading devices was discriminatory, because the Nook Simple Touch devices the library had procured were inaccessible to visually impaired users, and because accessible alternative devices were available.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The library agreed to transition to the exclusive use of accessible devices within four years, and to add ten accessible e-readers within 60 days of the settlement date.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2010, four blind library patrons sued the Free Library of Philadelphia in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, alleging that the Library's e-reader lending program violated Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 ("Rehabilitation Act") and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the library's lending program discriminated against the blind by denying them access to its NOOK e-book reading devices, which are completely inaccessible to the blind.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Final Settlement Agreement, which required the library to purchase e-reading devices that are fully accessible to both patrons who are blind and patrons who do not have such disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, granted their motion for a preliminary injunction, and granted their request for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The final settlement agreement, which is subject to court approval, requires the Library to comply with Section 504, Title II, and the ADA by refraining from lending any inaccessible e-books to its patrons.[SENTMARKER]The Library also agreed to pay the plaintiffs reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed a suit in federal court on January 20, 2011, against Millcreek Township, PA and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the sidewalks and intersections in Millcreek were not in compliance with the disability accessibility mandates of the Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and sought injunctive and declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]On November 23, 2016, the parties partially settled, with the Township and PennDOT committing to adhere to ADA requirements in the future and to retrofit sidewalks and intersections where necessary.[SENTMARKER]A series of consent decrees, over which the court retains jurisdiction, have been entered and the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 28, 2011, the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation ("PennDOT") and Millcreek Township, Pennsylvania ("Millcreek") entered into a Consent Decree and Partial Settlement in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania (Erie) to resolve allegations that the defendants violated Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA"), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 ("Section 504"), and other federal civil rights laws by failing to make certain facilities accessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the consent decree and partial settlement with respect to some of the claims set forth in the complaint filed by Voices for Independence, Inc. ("VFI"), a membership organization that advocates for access and inclusion of persons with disability into housing, employment, and recreation.[SENTMARKER]According to the parties' consent decree, the parties agreed that the parties would allow at least fifteen (15) days to agree upon any modification to the terms of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction to enforce all terms of the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]In the meantime, plaintiffs, Millcreek, and PennDOT have continued discussions and negotiations regarding several unresolved additional issues, leaving some unresolved and subject to further litigation in the above-captioned case alleging violations of Title II, Section 504, and Section 701.

gold_sents: In 1996, parents of a student with autism filed this lawsuit on his behalf against the Arkansas Department of Education and the Williford School District under the IDEA, the ADA, Section 504, and 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The parents claimed that their son was unfairly discriminated against due to his disability and was deprived of an appropriate education.[SENTMARKER]In 2004, the Eastern District of Arkansas Court held that neither defendant had violated the federal statutes and found for state and the school district.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| DATE ||| LAW ||||| DATE [CONTRACTED] This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas on behalf of the parents of an autistic boy in the Williford, Arkansas, school district.[SENTMARKER]The parents alleged that the school district violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA),  504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide their son with a "free appropriate public education" (FAPE) and by disclosing private information about his individual education program (IEP) in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed all of the plaintiffs' claims with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened and the district court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment on the basis of the state's Eleventh Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the court remanded the case for further proceedings, finding that the defendants had violated the ADA and the ADA, and that the plaintiffs had failed to show that they were harmed by the defendants.

gold_sents: This federal lawsuit was filed in 2000 in the Eastern District of California; in it, a former high school student and the Gay-Straight Alliance Network sued his school district for failure to take effective measures to remedy continuing harassment that he faced based on his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for a consent decree entered August 15, 2002, which required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program, revise its policies, select compliance coordinators, develop systems for reporting harassment and discrimination, allow students to form a gay-straight alliance, and create a community advisory group.[SENTMARKER]The decree implementation period was 6 months.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2000, a group of gay and lesbian students filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the Visalia Unified School District (VUSD) alleging that the VUSD violated the federal civil rights law by failing to prevent discrimination and harassment based on actual or perceived sexual orientation or gender.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that a number of teachers at Golden West High School had listened to students openly make derogatory comments about gays and lesbians without making any attempts to stop them.[SENTMARKER]On or about November 2000, the plaintiffs filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, but the district court denied the motion.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a consent order on June 30, 2005, requiring VUSD to implement a "Mandatory Student Training Program" for all certificated employees, administrators, and non-certificated staff who are responsible for monitoring student behavior.[SENTMARKER]The program will be mandatory for all students in one grade level in all VUSD high schools and 20 continuation schools on the subject of preventing harassment and discrimination on the basis of actual or perception of sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The consent order also requires the district to develop policies to alleviate the allegedly hostile and intolerant environment in public 23 schools within the district.[SENTMARKER]The order is effective immediately upon its entry by the court, or 60 calendar days after the last report under 6 Section X is received, whichever date is later.

gold_sents: The plaintiff, Students for Fair Admissions (SFFA) sued the U.S. Department of Education to compel compliance with its FOIA request related to its investigation of Princeton University.[SENTMARKER]The defendant notified Princeton of the request and the lawsuit, and Princeton then filed a lawsuit against SFFA to enjoin the disclosure of the materials requested under FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The present case was consolidated into that suit, and the parties jointly stipulated to this case's dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2016, Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. (SFFA) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Education, New York Office for Civil Rights, alleging that the Department violated the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) by failing to respond to SFFA's FOIA request for documents concerning the investigation of civil rights violations at Princeton University.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2016, Judge Tanya S. Chutkan granted the Department's motion for partial summary judgment and ordered the Department to produce, by a date certain, any and all non-exempt records responsive to the FOIA request and a index of any responsive records under the claim of exemption.[SENTMARKER]On December 2, 2017, the Court entered a final judgment in favor of the Department.

gold_sents: Princeton sued U.S. Department of Education and OCR in a "reverse FOIA" to stop them from releasing documents related to an OCR compliance review to Students for Fair Admissions, Inc., which had submitted a FOIA request and filed a lawsuit against the DOE to compel disclosure.[SENTMARKER]Parties voluntarily dismissed case.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 13, 2016, the Office for Civil Rights (OCR) of the U.S. Department of Education (D.C.) received a complaint alleging that Princeton University had discriminated against applicants on the basis of race and national origin in the admissions process.[SENTMARKER]OCR conducted a compliance review of the University's undergraduate admissions program.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the University had violated the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and the Trade Secrets Act (TS Act) by failing to disclose certain confidential and commercially sensitive documents and information relating to the admissions program to OCR.[SENTMARKER]On October 27, 2016, the plaintiff filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia seeking to compel disclosure of the materials identified in OCR's FOIA request to the University.[SENTMARKER]The University brought this action for permanent injunctive and declaratory relief under the Administrative Procedure Act to set aside the Department’s and OCR’s final decision to disclose the applicant documents as arbitrary and capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.[SENTMARKER]The case was docketed as Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. v. United States Department of education, No. 1:16-cv-02154-TSC.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case, and the case was dismissed on May 26, 2017.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2010, a group of students with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Louisiana Department of Education for failing to provide accessible free public education to students with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]After negotiations, the court approved a Consent Decree in March 2015.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Monitor continues to file periodical assessments as the State works toward full compliance under court supervision.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 31, 2015, ten students with disabilities filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Orleans Parish School Board, alleging that the school system violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act (IDEA) and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by denying them access to public school because of their disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented a class of approximately 4,500 students in the New Orleans area.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to implement a number of corrective measures to ensure equal access and equal opportunity for all students.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to provide annual technical assistance to each school under its jurisdiction regarding the prohibited practice of undocumented suspensions and to develop and disseminate information to parents of students at each school about prohibited practice.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that each school must develop a written complaint investigation protocol describing the school’s process for investigating allegations of discrimination on the basis of disability.
