gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2002, a group of Westfield High School students filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the City of Westfield, the Westfield Public Schools, and the Westfield High Bible Club.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First Amendment rights by prohibiting them from distributing candy canes with an attachment that contained the story of the candy cane and some Bible verses to fellow students.[SENTMARKER]The school denied the group access to show the film, because it was "church-related," and the school feared that allowing students to wear the armbands would result in a disturbance among the students.[SENTMARKER]In April 2003, the district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, finding that the school's policies were unconstitutional prior restraints on free speech.[SENTMARKER]The district court also granted the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed not to punish the plaintiffs for distributing literature during non-instructional time, to allow the Bible Club to meet at the flagpole on school grounds before the start of each school day to conduct a morning prayer, and to make reasonable adjustments to their distribution policies.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: The National Federation of the Blind, The Council of Parent Attorneys and Advocates, Inc., and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland on May 31, 2018 against the Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights, and Department of Justice.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by requiring, purchasing, or incorporating inaccessible electronic book readers in the curricula of colleges and universities that receive federal funding.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants' actions in adopting the changes in the March 5, 2018 case processing manual, which allegedly eliminated certain substantive rights of complainants, violated the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on November 29, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay $50,000 in attorneys' fees and costs in full and final settlement of any and all claims for attorney's fees and cost in connection with this case.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice one year from the date of the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: On May 14, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the Department of Education (ED) in the United States District Court in the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that regulations issued by ED "sharply limit educational institutions' obligations to respond to reports of sexual harassment and assault" and therefore contravened Title IX of the Education Amendmentsof 1972.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing with responses to the complaint due on July 31, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 12, 2017, the Council of Parent Attorneys and Advocates, Inc. (COPAA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education (D.E.)[SENTMARKER]alleging that the D.C. violated Title IX by failing to adequately enforce its anti-harassment and sexual assault policies.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that a female student was sexually assaulted by a male student while walking home from school.[SENTMARKER]According to COPAA's complaint, the District failed to adequately investigate the alleged sexual assault and failed to provide appropriate support services to the student as she struggled to continue her education.[SENTMARKER]On May 6, 2020, the District Court granted summary judgment in favor of COPAA.[SENTMARKER]The District Court also granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case for a total of $1 million.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2006, two black high school seniors, Beautie Mitchell and Christopher Sutton, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the University of Michigan and the Michigan Attorney General challenging the implementation of a state constitutional amendment that was to go into effect on December 23, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties to the case either took no position or consented to the relief, and the Court granted the motion to intervene on December 14, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The district court in Northland Family Planning denied the State of Michigan's motion to dismiss and ruled that the state statute was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 18, 2008, the District Court issued a final order granting summary judgment to the Attorney General and dismissing all claims.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed the district court's grant of summary judgment, concluding that the portions of Proposal 2 that affect Michigan’s public institutions of higher education impermissibly alter the political process in violation of the Equal Protection Clause.

gold_sents: In late 2003, several students with disabilities filed a lawsuit against the New York City Department of Education and the New York City School Board for failing to follow the orders of impartial hearings requiring them to compensate or fund tuition and services for the special education needs of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2008 a settlement agreement was approved which included injunctive and compensatory relief.
pegasus_output_sents: This class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of individual parents of children with disabilities against the New York City Department of Education.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their rights under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) by failing to comply with decisions, determinations, orders, and statements of agreement and orders of Impartial Hearing Officers (IHOs) entered pursuant to the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for class certification, and the parties agreed to a settlement on December 11, 2007 that provided for the payment of $1,590,625.25 in attorney's fees and $132,705.93 in expenses.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved on April 10, 2008 by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to the release of the defendants from any further litigation.

gold_sents: In 2012, a parent, individually and on behalf of their student-child with an educational disability in the Buffalo City School District, filed this class action complaint in the the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Buffalo City School District Board of Education and its superintendent denied free appropriate public education to children with educational disabilities, failed to promptly provide children with disabilities related services, and failed to provide parents with meaningful participation in their children's educational decision-making process.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties reached a settlement that required more timely speech and language therapy for members of the class and awarded attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in March 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 1973 ("IDEA"), 20 U.S.C.  1400, et.[SENTMARKER]seq., requires school districts to provide free, appropriate public education, including special education and related services, to educationally disabled children under the age of 21 residing in the Buffalo City School District, present and future, who are classified as disabled per the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the IDEA by failing to provide services to such disabled students when services for non-disabled students were no so delayed.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification in October 2012, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement on June 17, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the district court's final judgment would be final, and that the defendant would provide the individual plaintiff with individual and individual learning hours of speech and language therapy services as required by the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs.

gold_sents: On February 15, 1996, students filed a class action lawsuit against Owasso Independent School District ("OPS"), claiming that it had violated  Title IX of the Education Amendment of 1972, the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C. § 1983 by intentionally denying  female students an equal opportunity to participate in interscholastic and other school-sponsored athletics.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 1996, the Court entered a consent decree, which settled each of the claims stated in the Complaint and resolved all claims asserted against individuals who were named in their official and individual capacities, dismissing claims for damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 6, 2016, three female students at Owasso Public Schools, Oklahoma, filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma against the OwasSo School District, alleging that the school district violated Title IX by failing to fund and sponsor girls' sports in a manner that does not discriminate against female athletes.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, declaratory and monetary relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the district agreed to fund its interscholastic and other school-sponsored sports programs and to provide equal access to weight training and conditioning facilities and equipment to female athletes and male athletes.[SENTMARKER]As part of the consent decree, the district also agreed to construct an on-campus softball field which is comparable in quality to the district's existing baseball field.[SENTMARKER]The district agreed not to construct a softball/baseball work-out facility until such time as it has completed the softball field provided for within this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the district to urge coaches to play the maximum number of games permitted in order to avoid coaches of female teams failing to schedule or playa reasonable number of matches.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the District agreed to pay the plaintiffs $75,000 from its building fund toward the construction of a softball field.

gold_sents: Parents, on behalf of female students of Chouteau Public Schools, brought suit against the school district alleging that the school had violated female students' rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and Title IX of the Education Amendment through disparate treatment with respect to interscholastic athletics and programs.[SENTMARKER]In a settlement agreement, the school district agreed to take steps to remedy the discriminatory actions by, among many things, providing coaching, facilities and equipment to both male and female athletic teams on a gender-neutral basis.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 28, 2000, a group of female students at Chouteau Public Schools in Chouteau, Oklahoma filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma on behalf of all current and future female students in the Chouteau School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the district violated Title IX by denying female students meaningful participation opportunities in interscholastic and other school-sponsored athletics.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including the provision of locker rooms and facilities for both practice and competition; and (7) publicity.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement in which the district agreed to fund and sponsor a sufficient number of additional athletic teams for female students and to provide female students with off-season training opportunities to female athletes that are equivalent to those available to male athletes.[SENTMARKER]The district also agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: A lawsuit was filed on behalf of all school-age students with disabilities in Pennsylvania seeking to increase the number of children with disabilities educated with their non-disabled peers, and to make sure schools provided real supports to make sure inclusion would work as required by the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]After eleven years, the parties reached a settlement; however, the final report demonstrates many of the terms of the agreement was not met.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 1994, a group of parents of children with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Education and the Pennsylvania State Board of Education.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act (IDEA), 20 U.S.C.  1400-1485, by failing to identify disabled students, develop individual educational programs or plans, and provide a free appropriate public education to the maximum extent reasonably possible in the least restrictive environment in Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to develop a program of comprehensive personnel development to train regular and special education personnel in promising educational practices for the provision of supplementary aids and services to students with disabilities in regular classrooms.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendants to create materials to promote that all children, including those who have disabilities, are welcome in school and to disseminate information to parents about training opportunities and materials.

gold_sents: In 2015, a transgender boy filed a lawsuit against his school district because they would not allow him to use the boys' bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the school district's motion to dismiss, but the appeals court reversed and remanded, and the district court has since granted a preliminary injunction allowing plaintiff access to the boy's bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed to hear the school district's appeal in 2016, but later remanded the case after the Department of Education and Department of Justice withdrew their prior guidance on the issue.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court to determine whether the plaintiff's graduation from high school rendered the case moot.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2018, the district court denied the defendant’s motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a second amended complaint on February 15, 2019, and a motion for summary judgment on March 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2019, the court granted the summary judgment; the defendant appealed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 9, 2014, the Gloucester County Public School Board (the "School Board") adopted a policy stating that the use of boys' and girls' restroom and locker rooms "shall be limited to the corresponding biological genders" in violation of Title IX of the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the School Board's policy discriminated against a student by denying him the treatment and benefits afforded to other male students and that he was subjected to discrimination on the basis of his sex.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed G.G.[SENTMARKER]'s Title IX claim and denied his request for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Fourth Circuit vacated the district court's June 23, 2016 preliminary injunction, and the Supreme Court granted a stay of the District Court's mandate.[SENTMARKER]The School Board then implemented the policy and created three single-stall unisex restrooms for use by all students, regardless of their biological sex or gender identity.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals granted a rehearing en banc regarding mootness.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the case and denied a motion for a declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a lawsuit in the Northern District of Alabama against Tyson Foods, Inc. Fourteen current and former African American employees at Tyson's Ashland, Alabama plant filed a lawsuit over the same issues, and the cases were consolidated.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that Tyson had maintained racially segregated facilities and had subjected African American employees to a racially hostile work environment and retaliation and threats.[SENTMARKER]On November 7, 2006, the parties settled and Plaintiffs received $871,000, while Tyson was required to institute anti-discrimination policies and programs at its Ashland plant.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 11, 2005, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, alleging that Tyson Foods, Inc. violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by creating and maintaining a racially hostile work environment at its Ashland, Alabama, facility.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Tyson discriminated against a class of African-American employees by creating a racially segregated bathroom facility and by retaliating against certain employees who complained about the existence of this segregated facility.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, Tyson agreed to pay a total of $871,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties also entered into a consent decree in which Tyson agreed not to discriminate on the basis of race or to permit a racial hostile environment to exist at the Ashland facility.

gold_sents: In 2006, the EEOC filed this case against Eagle Produce in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged sex and wage discrimination.[SENTMARKER]In 2008 the parties reached a settlement agreement which included monetary compensation, as well as requirements for training and reporting.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2005, the Arizona District Office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against Eagle Produce, L.L.C., an Arizona Limited Liability Company.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant paid its female Quality Control Inspector, Anita Guerreo, at wage rates which were less than the rates paid to its male employees performing substantially equal work, and otherwise discriminated against that female employee because of her sex.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $3,002.50 in liquidated damages, interest, injunctive relief, attorney's fees, and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendant to institute and carry out policies and practices that help assure a work environment free from wage discrimination based on sex.[SENTMARKER]According to the terms of the settlement agreement, the defendant also agreed not to retaliate against any employee who complained of wage discrimination.

gold_sents: On August 9, 2006, the San Francisco office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a lawsuit under Title VII against Robert G. Aptekar, MD, Inc. and the Arthritis and Orthopedic Medical Clinic in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendants had violated the rights of the complainant by subjecting her to racial harassment, subjecting her to a hostile work environment, and by retaliating against her when she filed a complaint with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]On July 16, 2007, the parties entered a consent decree set to last 18 months, which the District Court (Judge Ronald M. Whyte) approved on August 20, 2007.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, the defendants agreed to pay the complainant $44,000 in unspecified damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 17, 2006, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (San Jose division) alleging that the defendant, Robert G. Aptekar, M.D., Inc., d/b/a/Arthritis and Orthopedic Medical Clinic, had discriminated against an African American employee by subjecting her to a racially hostile work environment based on her race, Afi-ican American.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that defendant discharged the employee in retaliation for complaining about racial harassment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree to further the objectives of equal employment opportunity as set forth in Title VII.[SENTMARKER]As part of the consent decree, defendant agreed to pay a total of $44.00 (Forty-four thousand dollars) to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the defendant to develop or revise its complaint policies and procedures to the extent necessary, such as to encourage employees to come forward with complaints about violations of its harassment policy.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to provide its employees with convenient, confidential and reliable mechanisms for reporting incidents of harassment and retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The decree terminated eighteen (18) months from the date of entry by the court, unless the court finds Defendant to be in substantial violation of the terms of the Decree because of noncompliance by the defendant.

gold_sents: On September 27, 2006, The EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Easter District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued Foam Works, LLC under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 alleging sexual harassment and a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]On October 12, 2007, District Judge Morrison C. England approved and ordered a proposed consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the Defendant to pay the complainant $21,500 in compensatory damages.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant was also required to conduct annual training on harassment, institute a confidential complaint procedure, retain pertinent records, and allow the EEOC to inspect documents with twenty days notice.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California on October 12, 2007 against Foam Works, LLC.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by subjecting a female employee to sexual harassment and retaliation because of her race, color, and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $21,500 to the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the defendant to provide training to its employees to prevent and correct discrimination, and to establish a record-keeping procedure that provides for the centralized tracking of discrimination complaints and the monitoring of such complaints.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed not to make any employer contributions to the settlement.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2006, the Los Angeles District Office of the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Hometown Buffet Inc. under for violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged sexual harassment and a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]On July 22, 2009, Judge Michael M. Anello approved the proposed consent decree put forth by the parties.[SENTMARKER]Its effective period was two years, and there is nothing more on the docket - so presumably the matter ended in 2011.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against Hometown Buffet, Inc. (HTB) alleging that HTB engaged in unlawful employment practices in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, since October 2002, HTB subjected several female employees to sexual harassment on the basis of sex, including unwanted physical touching and/or sexually charged and suggestive speech and conduct.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleged that the sexual harassment included, but not limited to, "unwanted physical touching" and "sexually charged" or suggestive conduct.[SENTMARKER]After the parties entered into a consent decree in October 2006, the parties agreed to a settlement that required HTB to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay each of the alleged female employees a total of $2,100.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of whether the EEOC satisfied its duty to conciliate prior to commencing this action.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2005 the San Francisco District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued Paragary's Management Group, Paramoor, Inc., and PDK Partnership under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC represented claimants who alleged the defendants had subjected them to a hostile work environment and disparate treatment.[SENTMARKER]On April 29, 2009 Judge Morrison C. England approved and ordered a consent decree to be in effect for three years.[SENTMARKER]The decree granted permanent injunctive relief and $60,000 in monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]There is nothing more in the docket, so presumably the matter ended in 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: The San Francisco District Office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the 9 Eastern District of California against the defendants, Paramoor Management Group, Inc., PDK Partnership, and PK Partnership, alleging that the defendants violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by creating an offensive, abusive, and hostile work environment based on the sex and national origin of the claimants.[SENTMARKER]The claimants alleged that they were subjected to both verbal and physical acts of harassment and discrimination based on their sex.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay the claimants $60,000 in damages and in complete satisfaction of their claims.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to implement an anti-harassment policy that will encourage employees to come forward with complaints about violations of the policy.

gold_sents: In December 2005, the EEOC district office in San Francisco, California brought this action against Pizzeria Uno Lombard, Inc., a regional restaurant chain, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California The EEOC alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 when it subjected female employees to a sexually hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The defendant never answered the complaint, and an entry of default was entered against it on September 8th, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC voluntarily dismissed the action in April 2007 before the magistrate judge's report and recommendation for judgement was entered.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Pizzeria Uno Lombard, Inc. and its officers, successors, assigns, and all persons in active concert or participation with it, alleging discrimination on the basis of sex in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, since at least November of 2002, the defendant had engaged in unlawful practices in the city and county of San Francisco which created an 11 offensive, abusive, and hostile work environment based on sex.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by failing to provide equal employment opportunities for its employees.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed without prejudice on September 12, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC filed a motion for partial summary judgment on September 14, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case is still ongoing.

gold_sents: In September 2005, the EEOC filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California under Title I and Title VII against Taylor Made Digital Systems.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief and damages, alleging that the defendant discriminated against one of its employees on the basis of her sex (female/pregnant) and race (African American).[SENTMARKER]In October 2006, the court  (Judge Maxine M. Chesney) signed a proposed consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to pay $30,600 to the employee who brought the initial charge.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to comply with Title VII, not to engage in retaliation against any employee because of the lawsuit, and to continue to post an anti-discrimination policy on its company intranet.[SENTMARKER]Finally, the consent decree required all inquiries about the employee who filed the initial charge to be directed to a specific member of human resources, who was prohibited from referring to the present lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree terminated after one year.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Taylor Made Digital Systems, Inc. (Taylor Made) alleging discrimination under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Title VII) and Title I of the civil rights act of 1991 (Civil Rights Act).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Taylor Made subjected Chene Gasper to unlawful race and sex discrimination because of her pregnancy when it refused to allow her to return to her position and demoted her.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by failing to implement or permit any action, policy or practice 23 with the purpose of retaliating against any current or former employee of Taylor Made because he or she opposed any practice of race discrimination or sex (pregnancy) discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $30,600.00 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Maxine M. Chesney on December 23, 2005 and became effective upon its entry by the court on December 24, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The settlement amount is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2008, six Best Buy employees filed a class action lawsuit against Best Buy alleging discrimination on the bases of race and sex.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the parties settled.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the implementation of policies to protect employees against discrimination and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]On December 8, 2015, the monitor reported that Best Buy had complied with the terms of the consent decree and it thus expired.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Best Buy Co., Inc. (Best Buy) alleging that Best Buy discriminated against African-American and female employees in violation of the California Fair Employment Housing Act (Fair Housing Act) and the California Civil Rights Act (C.R.A.).[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Best Buy refused to hire African-Americans who passed the company's pre-hiring tests into entry-level positions.[SENTMARKER]Best Buy also refused to employ African- Americans who complained about their treatment.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the company retaliated against black employees who filed complaints with the EOC.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which Best Buy agreed to implement a number of anti-discrimination and anti-harassment policies and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required Best Buy to pay compensation to African Americans and women who complained of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement are confidential.

gold_sents: This case was brought by employees of El Paso Corporation against their employer alleging violations of ERISA and the ADEA as a result of the conversion of their pension plans to a cash balance formula.[SENTMARKER]However, the Tenth Circuit ruled that the defendant’s conversion to a cash balance plan was legal, as were the means the company utilized to transition to the new pension plan.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 28, 2004, three former employees of El Paso Corporation filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against El Paso and El Paso Pension Plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that El Paso's conversion of its defined benefit pension plan to a cash balance plan, in particular one based on a final average pay formula, discriminated against older employees in violation of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the charge and the EEOC was unable to resolve the controversy.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed in part and denied in part without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2011, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") brought this lawsuit against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC ("BDC") on behalf of a visually impaired company employee in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The EEOC claimed that BDC discriminated against the employee in violation of the ADA when it conditioned his employment on the results of a medical exam and subsequently refused to hire him as a night warehouse loader upon learning that he had a disability.[SENTMARKER]The jury initially awarded the employee $132,347 in back pay, but it found that his damages should be reduced by $102,803 because he could have mitigated those damages by finding a comparable position.[SENTMARKER]On December 9, 2013, the District Court vacated these findings and awarded injunctive relief, only to be reversed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit because of erroneous jury instructions.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit denied the EEOC's petition for rehearing in May 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in December 2015, and the matter appears to be closed.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC (BDC), a wholesale liquor distribution company, alleging that BDC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) when it withdrew its conditional offer of employment as a Night Warehouse Loader upon being informed that Mr. Mike Sungaila was legally blind.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC also sought injunctive relief prohibiting further discrimination by the employer and mandating corrective action, including hiring Sungalia into a night warehouse loader position.[SENTMARKER]On January 9, 2012, the court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment, finding that the defendant was liable for discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered BDC to hire an outside consultant to provide employee training and assistance in revisions to BDC's policies, job postings, notice posting, and reporting and compliance review.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, BDC seeks to postpone the order until the Tenth Circuit rules on the issue of whether BDC must hire a consultant.

gold_sents: Female financial advisers employed by Morgan Stanley sued under Title VII and the Federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act, alleging that Morgan Stanley had a systemic pattern and practice of discriminating against female employees in compensation, promotions, and other areas.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, with Morgan Stanley paying $46m in damages, fees, and costs of administration, and agreeing to injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]This case was later consolidated with Amochaev v. Citigroup Global Markets Inc.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2006, three female financial advisors filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. and its predecessor company, Morgan Stanley DW Inc., alleging that Morgan Stanley discriminated against them and a class of similarly situated persons on the basis of their sex in several aspects of their employment.[SENTMARKER]The Named Plaintiffs alleged that they were denied equal employment opportunities to their female financial advisers and female registered financial advisor trainees in violation of federal and applicable state civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The parties engaged the services of Hunter Hughes, Esq., a highly experienced professional mediator, skilled in mediation of complex class actions, including employment discrimination litigation.[SENTMARKER]In April 2007, the Named Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint naming Morgan Stanley as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2007, the District Court granted the parties' Joint Motion for Approval of the Class Action Settlement Agreement, and on October 26, 2007, the Court granted final approval of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, the parties agreed to revise the "Power Rankings" used to allocate accounts and other business opportunities to ensure equitable and fair account distribution without regard to gender.[SENTMARKER]The term for the programmatic provisions of the Settlement is five years.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: This case was brought by several African-American current or former U.S. Capitol Police Officers against the United States Capitol Police Board.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought compensatory damages and injunctive relief, alleging that Defendant engaged in a pattern and practice of race discrimination in employment.[SENTMARKER]On October 13, 2016, the court granted defendant's motion to dismiss most of plaintiffs' claims.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a motion to reconsider which the court denied, and the court reaffirmed its reasoning on July 30, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the United States Capitol Police Board under the Congressional Accountability Act of 2001 (CAA) and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Police Board and others had violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and Title I of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they were subjected to a hostile work environment based on their known associations with African American officers.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the amended complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1).[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals granted the defendants' motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust administrative remedies on July 31, 2009, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.

gold_sents: The EEOC filed this Age Discrimination in Employment Act case against I.G.[SENTMARKER]Burton of Seaford alleging that the defendant had fired an employee due to his age.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a three-year consent decree.[SENTMARKER]Under the decree, the defendant agreed to pay $70,000 in damages to three former employees and provide training and take other steps to prevent further violations.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 2, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware against I.G.[SENTMARKER]Burton Company, Inc., a subsidiary of LG., alleging that LG.[SENTMARKER]had violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA) by terminating employees and applicants based on their age.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the terminations were based on age, and that the defendants violated the ADEA by failing to provide the EEOC with adequate training on the requirements of the law.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree (D.C. No. 06-524- SLR) in which the parties agreed to the following terms: (a) the defendant would not deduct its share of Social Security and Medicare contributions from the payment to the plaintiffs; .[SENTMARKER](b) the defendants would pay the plaintiffs a total of $222,,000.00 in monetary relief; .[SENTMARKER](c) the parties would cooperate in the enforcement of the terms of the consent decree; and (d) each party would bear its own expenses, costs, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is final and binding and is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the complainant, who intervened to become a plaintiff, brought this suit against Autozone, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged sex discrimination in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The case ended in a consent decree.
pegasus_output_sents: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against Discount Auto Parts, Inc., a Florida corporation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by subjecting a class of similarly situated women to sexual harassment in violation of Title VII and by terminating one of the women in retaliation for asserting her rights under Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay $150,000 to each of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendant to provide the EEOC with a copy of its policies, procedures, and training manuals regarding sexual harassment and/or retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the EEOC's motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the defendant.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: Financial advisors who sued their employer, Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., for race and gender discrimination in compensation did not state a plausible claim, so their complaint was dismissed pursuant to Title VII Section 703(h), which allows employers to compensate employees differently on the basis of seniority, merit, or quality or quantity of production.[SENTMARKER]The differences in compensation are only unlawful when they result from an intention to discriminate because of race, color, religion, sex or national origin.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2005, a group of black brokers at Merrill Lynch sued the firm under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and 42 U.S.C.  1981 alleging racial discrimination in hiring, compensation, account distribution, and “teaming” (the grouping of brokers that handle particular accounts) and seeking to litigate the claims as a class.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs’ initial motion for class certification in August 2010 and dismissed the entire case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the United States Supreme Court, which ruled in favor of the plaintiffs in June 2012.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On October 17, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Louisiana against Tasa, Inc. d/b/a Orr Minden Country Chevrolet.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging an African American employee in retaliation for having filed a charge of discrimination against the defendant with the Commission.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to settle the case by entering into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to institute and follow an anti-retaliation training program, post all vacant positions before promoting any employee to the position, and pay the employee's attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Donald E Walter on October 2, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the consent decree for the duration of three years after the date of entlative entry of this Decree.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the decree were as follows: (i) the defendant was required to post the vacant position before promotion; .[SENTMARKER](ii) it was not required to promote any employee; .[SENTMARKER](iii) it had to pay the plaintiff's attorneys' fees; and (iv) the plaintiff was allowed to file a complaint in the federal district court for the district in which the case was filed.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on December 31, 2005.

gold_sents: On April 13, 2015, a transgender man who was fired when he refused to sign an agreement to present and be treated as a woman at work as a condition of his employment filed a Title VII sex discrimination claim in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC later intervened in the case.[SENTMARKER]District Judge Carl Barbier directed the parties to arbitrate the case pursuant to an arbitration agreement between the plaintiff and his employer.[SENTMARKER]After the conclusion of the arbitration, which yielded monetary relief for the individual plaintiff, the EEOC continued to litigate the case to obtain injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]Judge Barbier entered an 18-month consent decree which required the defendant retrain its employees and post notice of what constitutes a violation of equal employment opportunity policies.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 5, 2015, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against First Tower Loan, LLC, doing business as Tower Loan of Lake Charles, alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Louisiana Employment Discrimination Law by terminating a transgender employee because of his sex.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the termination constituted unlawful discrimination on the basis of gender identity, sex stereotypes, and gender identity because the employee would not sign Tower Loan's written agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case was moved to the Southern District of Mississippi, where the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, 2016, the court granted the EEOC's motion to dismiss, and the parties entered into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to: (a) train each employee annually at a minimum with the first training to be held within six months after the entry of the decree; .[SENTMARKER](b) report any complaints about harassment or discrimination to the defendant’s Human Resources office; .[SENTMARKER](c) ensure that all persons in active concert or participation with it/them will not engage in any employment practice which discriminates on the based of gender status, transgender status, or sex stereotyping; and (d) pay the EEOC’s costs and attorney’s fees incurred in the case.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered by Judge Carl Barbier.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the terms of the consent decree, which included: (i) a requirement that each employee be trained annually, (ii) the types of sex-based employment decisions, (iii) the employer’s policy and procedures for reporting alleged discrimination, (iv) a description of the consequences, up to and including termination, that will be imposed upon violators of Defendant’s anti-discrimination policies, and (v) a provision that the EEOC may take reasonable measures to ensure compliance with the terms.[SENTMARKER]During the term of this Decree, the parties will bear their own costs and attorneys’ fees incurred.

pegasus_output_sents: On July 8, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against Avado Brands, Inc. d/b/a Don Pablo's Restaurant.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by engaging in racial discrimination and harassment against a female employee.[SENTMARKER]The defendant entered into a settlement agreement with the EEOC in which it agreed to pay the plaintiff in the amount of $50,000.00 for her economic losses, compensatory damages and punitive damages, and to provide her with two (2) hours of anti-harassment training to all management employees at its Maryland facilities.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the bankruptcy court in 2005 and became effective on December 1, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The court reopened this case on July 9, 2006, and the parties entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the defendant to provide the EEOC with a list of all employees who have attended and compieted training within two (2) days of the entry of the consent decree, to provide each employee with an orientation to its race and national origin harassment and equal employment opportunity policies, to post in all or places where notices to employees are customarily posted in the state, to maintain tor two years from the date of posting, and provide the defendant with a copy of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the court would retain jurisdiction of this case to resolve any dispute arising under this consent decree in the United States District Court of Maryland.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 6, 2003, African American employees of Friedman's, Inc. filed a class action lawsuit against St. Paul Mercury Insurance Company in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois under the Civil Rights Act of 1866, alleging racial discrimination in employment practices.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants created and maintained a systemwide policy and/or pattern or practice of race-based disparate treatment that limits the employment opportunities of African American workers.[SENTMARKER]The parties engaged in mediation in November 2005, but the parties failed to reach a settlement.[SENTMARKER]On January 14, 2005, the parties filed a bankruptcy petition for the Southern District of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on December 9, 2005, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement were as follows: Explicitly limiting the number of African Americans hired and paying African Americans less than similarly-situated white employees.[SENTMARKER]African American applicants who applied for employment at the company in who were not hired on such application would be eligible for the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the payment of a total of $1 million to African Americans and African Americans who applied in approximately 20 states.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 28, 2017, six transgender individuals currently serving in the United States military filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland Maryland contesting the President's ban on transgender service in the U.S. military.[SENTMARKER]Judge Garbis initially granted a motion for a preliminary injunction in September, but this was later stayed in 2019 when the Supreme Court issued a stay of this nationwide injunction in two factually similar cases contesting the ban.[SENTMARKER]This case changed dramatically in 2018 when the government altered its policy on transgender service in the military, eliminating an outright ban and instead putting new guidance on transgender men and women entering the service.[SENTMARKER]Judge Russell, reassigned to the case in 2018, dissolved the preliminary injunction, saying that it was only meant to stay a complete ban on transgender service in the military.[SENTMARKER]This also dismissed all claims against the 2017 outright ban as moot, and removed all plaintiffs that were already in the service and not seeking to join.[SENTMARKER]Discovery is ongoing in the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 9, 2017, a group of transgender service members filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald Trump and the Department of Defense, alleging that the President's decision to end the military's transgender policy violated their equal protection rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction, enjoining enforcement of the Accession and Retention Directives and reverting the policy to the status quo that had existed before the Presidential Memorandum Id.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted in part and denied in part the plaintiffs' cross-motions for summary judgment and remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]In light of the Supreme Court's Order, the defendants moved for the Court to stay the nationwide effect of the District Court’s preliminary injunction and the Ninth Circuit vacated without prejudice the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit agreed with the plaintiffs, and the case was dismissed on March 1, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: In 2016, three Pocomoke City, Maryland police officers filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they suffered racial discrimination and retaliation by their employer in violation of their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights and the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, two of the officers reached a partial settlement with Pocomoke City requiring adoption of anti-discrimination policies and procedures by the police department and awarding monetary damages to the officers.[SENTMARKER]As of September 30, 2020, the case is still ongoing pending a final settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 26, 2015, the EEOC filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Pocomoke City Police Department, the Worcester County Sheriff's Office, and the State of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that African American officers working for the City were subject to racial discrimination and a racially hostile work environment, and that the City violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by unlawfully terminating one of these officers and retaliating against another.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the EEOC's motion for partial summary judgment in March 2016, and the parties entered into a consent decree in January 2016.[SENTMARKER]The decree, which was entered into with the consent of the parties, requires the City to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and other costs.[SENTMARKER]The decree also requires the defendants to provide a neutral reference to any potential employer that contacts the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the District Court will determine the amount of the settlement at a later date.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII racial-harassment and retaliation suit against A & R Truss Company for violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.).[SENTMARKER]Alleging that Defendant had repeatedly subjected a black employee at the New Buffalo facility to racially offensive epithets and had met the employee's complaints with threats and intimidation, the EEOC sought monetary and injunctive relief, including compensation for emotional harm and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a one-year consent decree that provided monetary and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The employee received $20,000.[SENTMARKER]A & R Truss was subject to an array of anti-harassment, anti-retaliation, training, policy, and notice provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed an age discrimination action against Seagate US, LLC.
