pegasus_output_sents: On December 14, 2011, a group of African-American detectives in the New York City Police Department's Intelligence Division filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the City, the NYPD, and the NYPD's Deputy Commissioner David Cohen, alleging that the defendants violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by denying or delaying promotions based solely on race and color.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, for more than a decade, the Intelligence Division has implemented a secretive and unstructured promotions policy, administered by white supervisors, that denied or delayed promotions solely based on race.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC investigated the case for five years, concluding that it was a systemic pattern and practice of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]On March 4, 2016, the EEOC issued a final determination in favor of the charging parties, concluding there is reasonable cause to believe that the City violated Title VI individually and collectively.[SENTMARKER]On June 26, 2017, the EEOC referred the case to the United States Department of Justice, which reviewed the matter and determined that it did not file suit.[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2018, the parties filed a motion for summary judgment, which was granted by Judge Gregory H. Summons of the District Court.[SENTMARKER]On November 26, 2019, the parties submitted a stipulation of settlement and dismissal application.[SENTMARKER]The deadline for the plaintiff to apply for restoration of the case was extended to May 1, 2019, and the parties agreed to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]On May 17, 2019, the court granted the parties' motion to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: Current and former Black FDNY employees sued the City of New York alleging racial discrimination in their hiring, promotion, and compensation practices.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought to represent a class of individuals similarly situated who suffered from FDNY's policies that afforded too much discretion to higher-level individuals and fostered a culture of favoritism that harmed Black candidates for hiring and advancement.[SENTMARKER]The City filed a motion to dismiss and the Court partially granted the motion, but sustained the plaintiffs' claims related to the hiring and promotion practices with the FDNY.[SENTMARKER]The City moved for partial summary judgment in May 2020, arguing that the retired class representatives could not seek relief.[SENTMARKER]At the same time, the plaintiffs moved to certify the class.[SENTMARKER]Both motions were pending as of February 11, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2017, a group of African American employees of the Fire Department of New York (the "FDNY") filed a lawsuit against the City, raising claims under 42 U.S.C.  1983 and the New York City Human Rights Law ("NYHRL," N.Y.C Admin.[SENTMARKER]Code  8-101 et seq.) alleging that the FDNY discriminated against African American and Hispanic employees in its hiring, promotion, and compensation practices.[SENTMARKER]The FDNY settled the case in 2015, and the parties entered into a settlement concerning both monetary relief and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the plaintiff-intervenor, the complainant, filed this class action lawsuit against Pitt-Ohio  Express, Inc., a transport company, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Pitt-Ohio discriminated against women by refusing to hire women as truck drivers or dockworkers, in violation of Title VII 42 U.S.C. § 2000e.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2008, the court approved a settlement agreement between the plaintiff-intervenor and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $265,000 in monetary relief and  $305,000 in attorney fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]That same month, the court approved a consent decree between EEOC and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]This decree required the defendant to pay $$2,430,000 to EEOC (to be distributed to women that were affected by the defendant’s discrimination), to adopt anti-discrimination policies, to offer driver and/or dockworker positions to the women that were discriminated against, and regularly report to the EEOC to ensure compliance.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of five years.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against Pitt Ohio Express, LLC (Pitt Ohio) alleging that Pitt Ohio violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by failing to hire a qualified female applicant who applied for the position of Truck Driver at Pitt Ohio's Cleveland, Ohio terminal.[SENTMARKER]Pitt Ohio allegedly refused to hire the applicant because of her sex, and instead hired male applicants who did not meet the applicant's minimum qualifications and/or who were less qualified than the applicant and class member applicants.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on October 8, 2008 pursuant to a consent decree between Pitt Ohio and the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]Under the consent decree, Pitt Ohio was required to: (i) provide a training proposal to EEOC for approval within 30 days of the date of this Decree; .[SENTMARKER](ii) hire a class of female applicants as Truck Drivers and Dockworkers based on their sex, female; .[SENTMARKER](iii) provide written notice to any potential purchaser of its business, or of some or all of its assets, and any potential successor of this action; .[SENTMARKER](iv) conduct an equal opportunity component to its personnel policies and procedures; and (v) provide training to its executives, managers.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In August 2001, the Cleveland District Office filed this lawsuit against Sundance Rehabilitation Corporation in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio alleging violation of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, the Equal Pay Act of 1963, and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint specifically alleged that the defendant required terminated employees to sign a waiver of claims against the defendant, including EEO violations, in order to receive severance pay.[SENTMARKER]Following discovery and motions for summary judgment for both parties, the District Court granted summary judgment to the EEOC in July 2004.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed the decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in September 2004.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals reversed the District Court's judgment in October 2006.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court granted an extension of time to file a petition for a writ of certiorari in June 2007.[SENTMARKER]However, the docket does not indicate that this option was exercised.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, alleging that defendant SunDance Rehabilitation Corporation violated the antiretaliation provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Equal Pay Act (EPA), and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by requiring employees to waive their rights to file charges with the EEOC or participate in EEOC proceedings as a condition of receiving severance pay.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment in favor of the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, SunDance appealed, claiming that the district court's decision to grant summary judgment to the EEOC violated its right to a fair and just trial.[SENTMARKER]The court denied SunDance's appeal, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 25, 2007 the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a lawsuit against the Village of Woodmere, Ohio in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio to enforce Title VII, 42 U.S.C. §2000e, et seq.[SENTMARKER]The D.O.J.[SENTMARKER]asked the court for injunctive and compensatory relief, alleging the defendant had violated Title VII by discriminating against two employees in the defendant's police department on the basis of their race (white) in termination of their employment.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement and the Court entered a three year consent decree on May 23, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to implement new policies to deal with racial discrimination complaints and provide mandatory nondiscrimination training.[SENTMARKER]The individuals were to receive monetary awards, and one of them receive reinstatement.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against the Village of Woodmere, Ohio, alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging two former police officers on the basis of their race.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in 2007 to resolve the case.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to: (a) report to the EEOC any complaint of discrimination or retaliation made by any individual pursuant to its written policies and procedures; .[SENTMARKER](b) provide the EEOC with a copy of the defendant's policy and procedures that prohibit employment discrimination based on race or retaliation; .[SENTMARKER](c) pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees; and (d) implement a program to ensure compliance with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On July 24, 2008, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: On December 9, 2011, an openly gay former employee of Ohio Bell Telephone Company filed suit in U.S District Court for the Northern District of Ohio alleging that he had been dismissed in violation of the ADA, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, and multiple sections of Ohio's Civil Rights Act. Plaintiff took his husband's last name after the couple was married in Massachusetts and had AIDS and alleged he was fired for those reasons.[SENTMARKER]The court denied Defendant's motion to dismiss and the case settled in September 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 3, 2012, Plaintiff Jason W. Koren filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against The Ohio Bell Telephone Company, alleging discrimination in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (OCRA), Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and gender discrimination.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff and his same-sex partner had been married in another state which recognized same sex marriages.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff claimed that he was discriminated against because he was HIV positive and because he had entered into a same sex marriage.[SENTMARKER]The defendant moved for summary judgment, arguing that there was no evidence that Koren's termination was based on his gender, and that his termination was unrelated to his disability.[SENTMARKER]Judge James S. Gwin granted the defendant's summary judgment motion, finding that the plaintiff's disability was not a factor in his termination.[SENTMARKER]Judge Gwin also granted Ohio Bell's motion for a judgment in favor of the defendant.

gold_sents: On January 18, 2001, the U.S. Department of Justice ("D.O.J.")[SENTMARKER]filed a lawsuit under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the City of Sulphur in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Oklahoma alleging that the City discriminated against a Mexican-American employee on the basis of his national origin, when it failed or refused to promote him and took no action to remedy the effects of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The D.O.J.[SENTMARKER]sought injunctive and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]On February 23, 2001, the Court entered a consent decree, containing injunctions on discrimination and retaliation, with orders to the defendant to implement a nondiscriminatory policy and antidiscrimination training.[SENTMARKER]The individual received $45,000.[SENTMARKER]The decree expired after five years.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 26, 2001, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Oklahoma against the City of Sulphur, Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by failing or refusing to hire or promote an employee on the basis of his national origin, Mexican-American, when the employee was denied a promotion to the position of Sanitation Department Superintendent.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also allegedly failed or refused to take appropriate action to remedy the effects of the discriminatory treatment of the employee.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree, which was entered by Judge Frank H. Seay on February 26, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to: (a) hire and promote the employee, (b) pay the employee accordingly, (c) provide training with respect to Title VII, and (d) implement nondiscriminatory employment policies and practices that treat all employees in the same way, regardless of national origin.[SENTMARKER]Without admitting or denying the allegations of discrimination, the parties agreed to the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered with the consent of the parties and was entered in no way to constitute an adjudication finding on the merits of the case, nor to be construed as an admission by the parties of any applicable federal or state law or regulation.

gold_sents:
On November 3, 2003, African-American employees of Kraft Foods filed a lawsuit against their employer in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. 2000e, contending that Kraft had discriminated with regard to discipline and hiring.[SENTMARKER]

The court approved a preliminary settlement agreement on May 1, 2007 in which Kraft agreed to pay $1.325 million and grant other forms of non-monetary relief.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 3, 1999, two current and one former African-American hourly employees of Kraft Foods filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against Kraft Foods North America, Inc. (Kraft) alleging that Kraft had discriminated against African-Americans with respect to job discipline and classification.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Kraft's alleged conduct violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Equal Pay Act of 1991.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and equitable financial relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on December 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement, all present hourly employees at the Philadelphia bakery shall be annually and anonymously surveyed to determine their attitudes with regard to workplace fairness.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval, and the parties have agreed that there will be no further litigation.

gold_sents: Four plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and others similarly situated, filed a lawsuit against Latrobe Specialty Steel Company for violations of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA).[SENTMARKER]All four plaintiffs were over the age of fifty and were terminated following the discovery of inappropriate emails on their work email accounts.[SENTMARKER]Despite the plaintiffs' claims that the emails were a pretext for age discrimination, the court held that there was no evidence that but for their ages, the plaintiffs would not have been terminated.[SENTMARKER]Thus, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendant, which was affirmed by the appellate court.[SENTMARKER]Taxation was assessed against the plaintiffs in the amount of $21,863.88.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2007, a group of former employees of Latrobe Specialty Steel Company (LSS) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania, alleging that LSS violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) by terminating their employment based largely, if not exclusively, on their age.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their termination was based on the fact that they had repeatedly sent sexually oriented and pornographic emails through LSS's email system to other employees as well as outside third parties which violated the company's policies, practices and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of LSS, concluding that the plaintiffs had failed to demonstrate that "but for" their ages, LSS would not have terminated their employment.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court's decision, finding that plaintiffs had not shown that their age was a factor in their termination.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 30, 2010, the plaintiff, an African American job applicant with a felony criminal record, filed this class action lawsuit against the defendants, a company and its affiliates which specialized in training truck drivers and placing them with trucking companies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants refused to procure placement for applicants with a felony conviction, and because of this practice, disparately impacted African American and Latino applicants.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on August 17, 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2012, a truck driver filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against Driver Solutions, Inc., Driver Holdings, LLC, and C&S Acquisitions, Inc, alleging that they violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by denying employment opportunities to African American and Latino applicants based on criminal histories.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on January 17, 2012 involving monetary relief of $475,000 and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was entered into voluntarily between the parties and their attorneys without any findings of liability.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff retained Kurtzman Carson Consultants LLC, an experienced class action claims administrator, to administer the settlement.

gold_sents: This sexual harassment case was brought by the Memphis office of the EEOC in 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case was resolved by Consent Decree in November 2007 which provided individual relief and also required anti-discrimination training, posting of policies and reports to the EEOC.
pegasus_output_sents: This is an action under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C.  2000e et seq., to correct unlawful employment practices based on sexual harassment and retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission brought this suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee on behalf of two female employees of A&I Products, Inc., a Memphis, Tennessee-based warehouse company.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendants subjected Ann Boyd and Jennifer Wilson to sexual harassment by a co-worker and retaliated against them after Boyd filed a charge of discrimination with the Commission complaining of the sexual harassment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion for summary judgment on the EEOC's retaliation claim.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion, but the EEOC appealed, and the case was settled on December 7, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to pay a total of $15,000 to each of the two employees.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the defendants to train all employees at their Memphis facility on Title VII policies and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed not to discriminate on the basis of sex, create a hostile work environment, or retaliate against employees who complain of sexual harassment or retaliation.

gold_sents: The Memphis Office of the EEOC brought this suit against Paramount Staffing, Inc. in September 2006 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee (Memphis).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged discrimination and retaliation based on race (African American) and national origin (American).[SENTMARKER]The parties settled out of court on a two-year consent decree.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 19, 2010, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against Paramount Staffing, Inc., a Memphis, Tennessee-based temporary staffing agency.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Paramount discriminated against African-American and Hispanic employees by failing to place them into temporary positions because of their race and national origin, and by retaliating against one employee who complained about the discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by the court on August 19, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The decree requires Paramount to post its hiring and placement policies and procedures in English and Spanish, and to give each employee a neutral reference to any potential employer who may request a job reference.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Paramount will not retaliate against any employee who participated in the EEOC’s investigation or who otherwise may complain about any discrimination in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]The decree is in effect two (2) years from the date of entry and is being posted as part of the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) brought this suit against Sharp Manufacturing Company in the U.S. District for the Western District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Sharp violated the Americans with Disabilities Act by failing to provide the complainant with reasonable accommodation and discharged her because of her disability.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive and monetary relief as well as punitive damages against the defendant.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the court approved the parties’ consent decree.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of one year and instructed the defendant to: refrain from unlawful employment discrimination and retaliation; report to the EEOC on compliance with Title VII; revise its policies on reasonable accommodations; post notices of this agreement in their offices; pay $30,000.00 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE ||| CIVIL DOCKET ||| ORG||| DATE [CONTRACTED] On September 19, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against Sharp Manufacturing Company of America, a division of Sharp Electronics Corporation. The complaint alleged that the defendant failed to provide a reasonable accommodation to an employee with a disability under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and discharged her because of her disability, osteoarthritis. The parties entered into a consent decree on January 23, 2009. The decree required the defendant to post a notice at its Memphis, Tennessee facility for six months, post a copy of the decree to all current employees, distribute a copy to all new employees upon the employee's hire, and provide a written policy on reasonable accommodations. The consent decree was entered by Judge S. Thomas Anderson on January 22, 2009. The parties filed a motion for summary judgment on October 31, 2009. The court granted the defendant's motion, and the parties entered a final judgment on January 25, 2009.

gold_sents: On January 22, 2004 a group of Fairfield Resorts employees filed this class action lawsuit against Cendant Corporation, Fairfield Resorts, and 15 individuals working at Fairfield Resorts in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Nashville Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were filing suit over alleged sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation they experienced on the job.[SENTMARKER]On October 28, 2005, Judge William J. Haynes approved a consent decree granting monetary relief to plaintiffs and other female employees.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 22, 2004, six former and current female employees of Fairfield Resorts, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee alleging sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Tennessee Human Rights Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their employer, Cendant Corp., violated Title VII by failing to provide them with a work environment free of sexual harassment and gender discrimination and by subjecting them to other adverse terms and conditions of employment.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $50,000.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by the District Court on February 18, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to: (i) modify their complaint processing system so that any complaints of harassment, discrimination, or retaliation can be made; .[SENTMARKER](ii) publicize in each of their work locations the specific identity of the individual(s) who complained; .[SENTMARKER](iii) provide each employee with a copy of the complaint; and (iv) post the complaint on their website.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed not to discriminate on the basis of gender, sexual orientation, age, or disability.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants in June 2005.

gold_sents: On September 28, 2006, The Dallas District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued Beall Concrete Enterprises, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of U.S. Concrete, Inc. under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act. On April 3, 2008, Judge Reed O'Connor approved a consent decree over the remaining claim that the defendant had violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to pay the complainant $50,000 in backpay, conduct ADEA training for its employees for two years, and post a notice about federal anti-discrimination employment laws.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas on April 17, 2006 against Beall Concrete Enterprises, Inc., a Dallas, Texas-based concrete company, alleging that the defendant violated the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA) by failing to provide reasonable accommodation and then terminating their employment due to a record of a disability.[SENTMARKER]The defendant moved for partial summary judgment on the EEOC's claims under the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to pay $50,000 to the EEOC for its costs associated with the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed not to appeal the court's summary judgment ruling on the ADA claims until the term of the consent decree expired.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On November 9, 1999, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a female employee, filed a lawsuit in the Northern District Court of Texas, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, as amended, against Parfumes De Couer Limited, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought reinstatement of the applicant, injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant fired the complainant based on her sex because she was pregnant.[SENTMARKER]On March 23, 2001, the District Court entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $5,000.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE ||| CIVIL ||| ORG [CONTRACTED] On February 6, 1998, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against Parfumes De Couer, Ltd., Inc. (Parfums de Coeur) alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 when it discharged a female employee based on her sex, female, and because of her pregnancy.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Confidential Settlement Agreement in which Parfums de Couer agreed to implement policies, practices, and programs that provide equal employment opportunities for all of its female employees, and eradicate the effects of the Defendant's past and present unlawful practices.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, the parties agreed to pay a total of $9,900 to the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the agreement are subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to further approval.

gold_sents: On September 19, 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a black employee, filed a lawsuit in the Western District Court of Texas against Union Pacific Railroad Company.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2004, the District Court (Judge David Briones) entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the plaintiff-intervenor $84,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 19, 2002, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Union Pacific Railroad Company (hereafter "Union Pacific"), alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Section 102 of the civil rights act of 1991 by discharging an African-American employee on the basis of his race.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, in April 1998, Union Pacific began to perform criminal background checks on all employees whose background investigation revealed them to have a felony conviction in the seven year period preceding their application for employment and who did not disclose that information in their application.[SENTMARKER]In accordance with a two-year consent decree, the defendant is required to pay $84,000 to the charging party, who had been reinstated to his job (without back pay) through defendant's internal complaint process approximately 20 months after his discharge.[SENTMARKER]The defendant is enjoined from retaliating in any manner whatsoever against any employee employed by the Railroad in the El Paso, Texas Transportation Department for the duration of this Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The Railroad is also required to mail or e-mail copies of its Equal Employment Opportunity policies, which are attached hereto as Exhibit A, annually to its management and supervisory employees, and provide training to its managers and supervisors that explains the damaging effects of race discrimination and retaliation.

gold_sents: This class action suit was filed on January 12, 2006, under 38 U.S.C. § 4301, et seq. ("USERRA") in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff class consisted of all past and present pilots of American Airlines who are or were members of the United States Armed Services and who took military leave from January 2001 to 2006.[SENTMARKER]They asked the court for injunctive and declaratory relief, alleging that American Airlines had violated USERRA by discriminating against pilots who took military leaves of absence.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that they were unfairly charged fewer "in service" days which prevented them from bidding on a number of benefits including flight schedules, paid vacation time, and earned sick leave.[SENTMARKER]Pilots who had taken comparable types of non-military leave were not similarly penalized.[SENTMARKER]After filing two amended complaints, and the court denying the defendants' second motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs motion to certify class, preliminarily approve settlement agreement, and approve forms of class notice.[SENTMARKER]This motion was granted by U.S. District Court Judge Barbara M.G.[SENTMARKER]Lynn in a final order on August 1, 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 28, 2008, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas entered a Final Order enjoining American Airlines Inc. and certain of its pilots from violating the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 ( 4301 et seq.) by denying them the ability to bid on flight schedules based on their seniority status and to earn other employment benefits, including paid vacation time and earned sick leave.[SENTMARKER]The Final Order was entered in response to a class action brought by three former American Airlines pilots on behalf of all current and former pilots who took military leave after January 2001 on "leave of absence" status pursuant to the 1997 Collective Bargaining Agreement negotiated by American and the Allied Pilots Association.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that American's policy of placing pilots on leave of absence status effectively denied them the opportunity to bid for flight schedules and earned vacation time.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, granted their motion for class certification, and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The final order was entered on September 21, 2008 and is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a female employee, filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of Washington, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended by Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Huntwood Industries, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant subjected the plaintiff-intervenor to a sexually hostile work environment because of her sex, female, resulting in her constructive discharge.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2004, the District Court (Judge Frederick Van Sickle) entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $100,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 20, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington against T R A Industries, Inc., a Spokane, Washington-based manufacturer of custom cabinets.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by subjecting a female employee to a sexually hostile work environment because of her sex, resulting in her constructive discharge.[SENTMARKER]The defendant entered into a consent decree with the EEOC to further the objectives of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to implement anti-discrimination and anti-sexual harassment policies, 23 procedures and training for employees, supervisors and management personnel, to the extent not already established, and to provide equal employment opportunities for all 25 employees.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendant agreed not to impose any discipline upon any supervisor or manager who discriminates against any applicant or employee on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendant on July 21, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $100,000 to the plaintiff and to implement the terms of the consent decree for three years.

gold_sents: In March 2002, the Seattle District Office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Laidlaw Inc., a school bus company, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington for alleged violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complainant intervened in May 2002, alleging that the defendant violated the Washington Law Against Discrimination and state tort law by discriminating against her on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The defendant moved for summary judgment, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial in June 2003.[SENTMARKER]The court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs on their federal and state law claims and in favor of the defendant with regard to punitive and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court awarded $3,029.78 in economic damages and $30,000 in non-economic damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed in September 2004, but the appeals were dismissed in October 2004.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||||| DATE [CONTRACTED] In May 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against Laidlaw Transit, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Laidlaw Education Services Corp., alleging that Laidlaw violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Washington Law of 1991 by discriminating against female employees on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The parties stipulated to the dismissal of these appeals with prejudice, and the issues have been tried and the jury has rendered its verdict.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: In June 2006, the EEOC filed suit in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the restaurant chain International House of Pancakes (IHOP), its former president, and another company that together with IHOP operated restaurants throughout Illinois and Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sued under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e) and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 (42 U.S.C. § 1981a) on behalf of two female employees and similarly situated employees of the Defendants.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the EEOC alleged that the Defendants engaged in unlawful employment practices on the basis of sex and retaliation, and that they had subjected female employees to a sexually hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the jury held for the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the parties settled, and the Court approved a Consent Decree/Settlement Agreement (lasting 2 years) that awarded monetary damages to two female claimants and promised injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 27, 2007, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on behalf of two female servers at an International House of Pancakes (IHOP) franchise in Racine, Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the servers were sexually harassed in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by an assistant manager at the IHOP restaurant who subjected them to a sexually hostile work environment based on their gender.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, Management Hospitality of Racine, Inc. d/b/a IHOP, did not provide a point person to air complaints to the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The jury found in favor of the two servers and ordered the defendants to pay them $50,000 in damages and to create a sexual harassment training program for all employees under its direct or indirect supervision that emphasizes the responsibility of supervisors to prevent and correct promptly and sexually harassing behavior.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants were ordered to post, at all restaurants that it manages, a toll-free number for harassment and discrimination complaints by employees and a written anti-harassment and anti-discrimination policy.

pegasus_output_sents: On or about April 13, 2000, Sierra Club Lone Star Chapter filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) alleging that the EPA's permitting process and ultimate decision to permit an oil-refinery expansion in a low-income and African American community in Beaumont, Texas violated Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that during the permitting process for the 17 Genesee Power Station in Genesee Township, Michigan, the EPA failed to consider the facility's impacts on the surrounding community, which is 19 predominantly African American and low income Id att.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD), California Air Resources Board (CARB), and the California Energy 20 Commission (CEC) discriminated against residents of the City of Pittsburg, California, on the basis of race, color, and national origin in violation of Title VI.[SENTMARKER]The parties engaged in extensive settlement discussions, which were ultimately unsuccessful.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the EPA’s failure to act, the plaintiffs filed the instant action against the EPA and its Administrator, Scott Pruitt, pursuant to the 9 Administrative Procedures Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss for lack of standing, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit reversed, citing the voluntary cessation exception.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On July 2, 2013, a Christian college and a Christian university filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Iowa against the Departments of Health and Human Services (HHS), Labor, and Treasury.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, Dordt College and Cornerstone University, objected to the Affordable Care Act (ACA) mandate requiring that group health plans and health insurance issuers provide coverage, without cost sharing, for certain female contraceptives, including so-called emergency contraceptives that cause early abortions.[SENTMARKER]They argued that the mandate chills their religious exercise.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted their request for a preliminary injunction, enjoining the government from enforcing the mandate and the accommodation process, and remanded the case to the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 21, 2012, Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend, Inc. and Franciscan Alliance Inc. filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Indiana under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the First Amendment against the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) under the Affordable Care Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HHS violated their religious rights by requiring them to offer health care plans that included or facilitate coverage for abortifacients, sterilization, contraception, or related education and counseling about those practices.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for dismissal on the basis that the court lacked jurisdiction because the plaintiffs lacked standing and the case was not ripe.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a joint stipulation agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that HHS would not require Catholic Charities to offer any health care plan that covered abortion, sterilization or contraception, and that Catholic Charities would not inquire about the religious persuasion of its applicants for employment.[SENTMARKER]Catholic Charities agreed to pay $3 million in costs and fees.

gold_sents: This case was filed by the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts on May 16, 2005 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the department's provision of more than a million dollars of public funds to a ministry called "The Silver Ring Thing" (SRT) that uses federal abstinence education funding to bring "unchurched" students to Jesus Christ constituted an unlawful establishment of religion and a governmental endorsement and preference for religion in general and specific tenets of the ministry in particular.[SENTMARKER]The ministry developed a three hour presentation that was meant to occur directly following a mandatory abstinence education assembly in public schools and which, according to the plaintiff, was "permeated with religion."[SENTMARKER]In a two-year settlement agreement entered on February 22, 2006, the defendants acknowleged that they had terminated the SRT grant effective January 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The agreement provided that defendants would not fund SRT's abstinence eduction as it had been structured and implemented during the fiscal year 2005, that strict requirements would be made before considering funding any future proposals from SRT, and that extensive monitoring of SRT's activities would occur if SRT was given a grant.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 16, 2005, the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts (ACLU of Massachusetts) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Administration on Children, Youth and Families (ACF), the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), and the Administration for Children and Families Special Congressional Initiative Project Grants (SCF) alleging that the federal government's funding of the Silver Ring Thing Ministries (SRT) violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' funding of SRT violated the Constitution's Establishment Clause by funding religious activities and religious content.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to stop funding SRT for the next three years and to provide the Plaintiff with notice that SRT had received a Congressional earmark, or will otherwise be awarded a grant by ACF for abstinence education no later than 30 days after the date of the grant award.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into on June 23, 2006, and the parties agreed to dismiss the case without prejudicing the settlement agreement.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 1, 2010, a Boston resident filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the City of Boston and three Boston police officers for violating his First and Fourth Amendment rights under the Massachusetts Civil Rights Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his civil rights when they arrested him for recording his oral communications while they were arresting him without his consent or knowledge.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment on the grounds that the officer was entitled to qualified immunity based on the absence of a clearly established First Amendment right to videotape police officers on public business.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the district court's decision.[SENTMARKER]The First Circuit held that the First Amendment protected the right to record and display video of police carrying out their duties in a public place.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss the case, and the parties agreed to settle the case for $170,000 in damages and legal fees.
