pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2010, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) issued certain rules as part of the 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (the "Affordable Care Act" or the "Act"), that would require many Catholic and other religious organizations to provide health plans to their employees that include and/or facilitate coverage for abortion-inducing drugs, sterilization, and contraception in violation of their sincerely held religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, 2012, Catholic Charities, Vicksburg Catholic School, and St. Dominic Community Health Services filed a lawsuit in the Southern District of Mississippi, alleging that the rules violated their First Amendment rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 20, 2012, without prejudice.

gold_sents: In 2012, evangelical Christian business owners filed a RFRA challenge to rules adopted pursuant to the 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, arguing that the rules infringed on their religious freedom by requiring them to provide coverage for emergency contraception through their group health insurance plan.[SENTMARKER]In November 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the contraception mandate did not substantially burden the plaintiffs' religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit granted expedited en banc review, and oral arguments occurred on May 23.[SENTMARKER]On June 27, 2013, the 10th Circuit reversed the District Court's injunction denial and sent the case back to the District Court, with instructions to consider two prongs of the injunction inquiry and to rule on the plaintiffs' injunction motion.[SENTMARKER]The next day, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' emergency motion for a temporary injunction pending the full injunction hearing.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted cert., and on June 30, 2014, affirmed the 10th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Court said other ways were open to the government to reach its asserted interest of ensuring the availability of contraception coverage.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2012, Hobby Lobby and Mardel filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma against the federal government under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 (PPACA) and the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 (RFRA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the government's regulations requiring them to provide health insurance coverage for contraceptive drugs and devices in violation of their religious beliefs violated their First Amendment rights and their rights under the RFRA.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the court stayed all district court proceedings pending the resolution of their appeal to the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals or further order of the court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court reversed the district court's denial of the preliminary injunction and remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2013, a group of religious-based universities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Western District of Oklahoma under the First Amendment, Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause, Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act against federal government.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged the Affordable Care Act's requirement that employee and student health plans provide coverage of contraception violated their religious foundings.[SENTMARKER]On November 6, 2015, the Supreme Court granted certiorari on the question of whether the accommodation to the contraceptive services mandate as applied to religious nonprofits violates the RFRA.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated with six others.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court issued a per curiam order remanding all seven cases to their respective courts of appeals, and ordered that the parties be given time to come to agreement on ensuring contraceptive access without burdening religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]Following revised HHS policies, the District Court permanently enjoined the defendants from forcing religious organizations to provide contraceptive care.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed
pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, Oklahoma Baptist University, Southern Nazarene University, and Mid-America Christian University filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs object to the mandate that requires their employee and student health insurance plans to provide free coverage of contraceptive services, including so-called emergency contraceptives that cause early abortions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argue that the mandate chills their religious exercise, burdens their religious rights, and violates the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA).[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The parties are appealing the district court's decision.

gold_sents: In 2013, Bishop Zubik, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Pittsburg and the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Pittsburg filed a U.S. District Court lawsuit in the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Federal Government challenging the the contraception mandate of the Affordable Care Act. After the Trump Administration took office, the parties settled and dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2010, Congress enacted the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, Pub L No. 111-148, 124 Stat.[SENTMARKER]1029 (the "Act"), which required employers with religious objections to cover certain contraceptive services in their employee health insurance plans, including contraceptives that "may act after fertilization," such as emergency contraceptive pills and intra-uterine devices.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, 2012, Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Erie and the Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Act violated their religious rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 ("RFRA") and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, converted the preliminary injunction to a permanent injunction, and granted the government's motion to dismiss for lack of standing and ripeness.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the government agreed to pay $3 million in costs and fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

gold_sents: On November 22, 2013, a group of nonprofit religious organizations filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, the Administrative Procedure Act and the First Amendment against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]On December 26, 2013, United States District Court (Judge Todd J. Campbell) denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The same day, the plaintiff filed an appeal with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit (No. 13-6640).[SENTMARKER]On June 11, 2013, the 6th Circuit affirmed, holding that the ACA did not unlawfully burden the plaintiffs' religion.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded back to the 6th Circuit in light of a Supreme Court case Zubik v. Burwell.[SENTMARKER]Following the Zubik decision, the Departments of Health and Human Services, Labor, and Treasury adopted new rules on October 6, 2017 that allowed for religious and moral objections to providing contraceptives under the ACA.[SENTMARKER]As a result, on January 28, 2018 the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2012, the Michigan Catholic Conference filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, alleging that the Affordable Care Act's contraceptive coverage mandate violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, the Free Speech, Free Exercise, and Establishment Clauses of the First Amendment, and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the mandate required them to provide, pay for, and facilitate access to contraceptive services related to abortion-inducing products, contraception, and sterilization for their employees.[SENTMARKER]The district courts denied the plaintiffs' motions for a preliminary injunction on all of their claims.[SENTMARKER]In November 2013, the plaintiffs filed a petition for a writ of certiorari in the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals for the United States, which remanded the case back to the district courts for further consideration in light of the Supreme Court's decision in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc., 135 S. Ct. 1528 (July 1, 2014), in which the high court held that religious organizations could not be required to provide contraceptive coverage.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a temporary injunction on the defendants' request for a permanent injunction, which was granted by the district court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed not to appeal.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2012, Criswell College, an evangelical Protestant college located in Dallas, filed a lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas against the Federal Government seeking to enjoin enforcement of provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) extending universal contraception coverage in employer-sponsored private health insurance coverage.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs contend that this mandatory contraception coverage violates their sincerely held religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2013, the case was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction because it was not ripe for review.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2010, The Criswell College filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the Departments of Health and Human Services and Treasury alleging that the Affordable Care Act of 2010 (ACA) violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the First and Fifth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the RFRA by requiring the college to provide health insurance coverage for abortion, abortifacients, embryo-harming pharmaceuticals, and related education and counseling, or providing plans that cause access to the same through its insurance company.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the college's group health plan is not grandfathered under the ACA.[SENTMARKER]On February 10, 2012, the Department of Health finalized a rule that imposes a definition of preventive services to include all FDA-approved "contraceptive" drugs, surgical sterilization, and education, and counseling for such services.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice, finding that the mandate violated the religious exercise clause of the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on April 9, 2013.

gold_sents: The lawsuit was based on fair housing testing that DOJ had conducted between July 2008 and January 2009, in which rental agents made a series of racialized remarks, steering white testers away from certain locations, and implying that black applicants were more likely to fail criminal background checks.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2009, the United States Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama under the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. §3601, against operators of the Rolling Oaks Apartments, seeking injunctive and monetary relief for race discrimination.[SENTMARKER]After the court (Judge Mark Fuller) denied cross-motions for summary judgment, the matter settled.[SENTMARKER]In February 2011, the Court entered a four-year consent decree enjoining the Defendants from discriminating on the basis of race in the operation of the Rolling Oaks Apartments and ordering  $15,500 in civil penalties.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2009, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this civil rights lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the owner, manager, and assistant manager of a residential apartment complex in Clanton, Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that the defendants had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race or color, in violation of 42 United States  3601, et seq., in the rental of dwelling units at Rolling Oaks Apartments.[SENTMARKER]According to the DOJ's complaint, the defendants made statements indicating that a sign for a credit check and police background check was adopted to discourage black potential tenants from applying for an apartment, and that there was a preference against black tenants at the apartment complex.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also allegedly made false and misleading statements about the number of individual dwelling units available for rent.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on February 3, 2011, and the defendants entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the defendants to: (a) provide and process rental applications on a non-discriminatory basis; .[SENTMARKER](b) maintain all rental applications, whether deemed complete or incomplete, and any correspondence about the availability of dwellings at the subject property; .[SENTMARKER](c) hold in-person training for all new management agents on the Fair Housing Act; .[SENTMARKER](d) post an easily readable "For Rent" or "Vacancy" sign or notice at each apartment building in which the dwelling unit is available; .[SENTMARKER](e) maintain a list setting forth the occupancy of all dwelling units; .[SENTMARKER](f) conduct fair housing tests at any office where the defendants conduct rental activities; and (g) ensure that all applicants or tenants are not denied the right to apply for a dwelling unit because of their race, color, or any other factor.

gold_sents: On September 30, 2009 the United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against First United Security Bank under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. claimed that the Bank had engaged in a pattern or practice of home-mortgage lending discrimination against black applicants.[SENTMARKER]On November 18, 2009 an agreement was entered that required the Bank to change several of its practices and to pay monetary damages to some African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the agreement were satisfied and the case dismissed in April 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Alabama filed this lawsuit against First United Security Bank in the United States District Court for the Alabama Southern District on November 12, 2012 alleging that the bank violated the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act by charging African-American borrowers higher rates than similarly situated white borrowers on home mortgage-related loans.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant charged African-Americans higher rates for first-lien refinance loans originated in 2004 for owner-occupied one-to-four family houses in west central Alabama on an equal basis with majority-white tracts.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendant failed to serve the lending needs of majority African- American census tracts in the area on a basis of racial discrimination in the setting of interest rates for the loans.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, the bank agreed to post and display a notice of non-discrimination in each of its branches and to post an equal housing opportunity, slogan, or statement in all of its print advertising and promotional materials.[SENTMARKER]The agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In November 2011, two undocumented Mexican immigrants and three fair housing groups filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the State of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that a state statute violated the Fair Housing Act and was preempted by federal immigration law because it required mobile home owners to pay for a government-issued registration while prohibiting undocumented residents from making payments to government officials.[SENTMARKER]Because the law made it illegal to possess a mobile home without registration and because it was illegal for undocumented residents to obtain the registration, the law effectively made such persons homeless.[SENTMARKER]The District Court (Judge Myron H. Thompson) enjoined the State from enforcing the law.[SENTMARKER]The State appealed, but the Eleventh Circuit rendered it moot because in May 2012 the Alabama legislature amended the statute to exclude mobile home registration.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the case in May 2014, upon stipulation of the parties.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 18, 2011, the plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama against the state of Alabama and the revenue commissioner for the state.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the federal Fair Housing Act and the Supremacy Clause and Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution by enforcing  30 of the Beason-Hammon Alabama Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, 2011 Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, with the order set to expire on December 7, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On December 12, 2011, the defendants filed a motion to dissolve the order, which was denied by the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case resulted in the largest residential fair lending settlement in U.S. history, with $335 million being paid to compensate African-American and Hispanic borrowers who were allegedly charged more based on their race or national origin.
pegasus_output_sents: The Department of Justice's Office of Civil Rights filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against Countrywide Home Loans, Inc. (collectively, "Countrywide"), alleging that Countrywide violated the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act by charging more than 200,000 African-American and Hispanic borrowers higher fees and interest rates than non-Hispanic white borrowers in both retail and wholesale lending.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that these borrowers were placed into subprime loans because of their race or national origin, and not because of the borrowers’ creditworthiness or other criteria related to borrower risk.[SENTMARKER]Countrywide's policies and practices, as described herein, were intentional, willful, or implemented with reckless disregard for the rights of Hispanic and African- American borrowers and non-applicant spouses of married mortgage loan applicants.[SENTMARKER]As a result of that review, the 22 Federal Reserve Board determined that it had "reason to believe that 23 Countrywide engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination based on 24 race and national origin" in violation of the federal housing laws.[SENTMARKER]The FRB referred the matter to the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division for further investigation.[SENTMARKER]The Justice Department filed a motion to dismiss the case, and the parties agreed to a settlement in which Countrywide agreed to pay $500,000 to the government.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Southern District of California against Plaza Home Mortgage, Inc., under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On December 1, 2013, the District Court entered a consent order that prohibited the defendant from discriminating on the basis of race or national origin and required the defendant to  place $3 million into a settlement fund.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2016 after the defendant had substantially complied with the consent order.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 26, 2013, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of California and the Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) filed this civil rights case in the United States District Court for the San Diego District against Plaza Home Mortgage, Inc. (Plaza) alleging that Plaza discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its residential mortgage lending by allowing its wholesale mortgage brokers to charge higher broker fees for residential real estate-related loans than non-Hispanic white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, from 2006 through at least 2010, Plaza discriminated on the basis of race and national origin in its mortgage lending practices.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, African-Americans and Hispanics paid, on average, hundreds of dollars more for a Plaza loan than white borrowers because of Plaza's discriminatory practices.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 29, 2016 and the parties entered a consent order.[SENTMARKER]The consent order requires Plaza to comply with the Fair Housing Act, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, and the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Plaza will have to post a notice of its loan pricing policies in each location where applications for its loans are accepted.[SENTMARKER]The order also requires the lender to retain a national non-profit fair housing organization to review and recommend initiatives designed to prevent discrimination by the lender.

gold_sents: On May 30, 2014, the City of Los Angeles  filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against JP Morgan Chase Bank, under Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) and Fair Housing Act/Fair Housing Amendments Act (FHAA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought damages, declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the defendants lending practices were predatory and intentionally discriminated against minority borrowers, and had a disparate impact on minorities.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 2015, the plaintiff field an ex parte application to stay the case pending appeal of related action.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, 2015, the case was dismissed as stipulated.
pegasus_output_sents: The City of Los Angeles filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against JPMorgan Chase Co., JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., and Chase Manhattan Bank USA, alleging that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by denying credit to certain neighborhoods based on race, color, or national origin in their 27 residential real estate-related lending transactions.[SENTMARKER]The City's damages include lost tax revenues and the need to provide 21 increased municipal services.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the defendants agreed to a global settlement with the Department of Justice, HUD, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and the 25 state attorneys general.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement prohibited the defendants from discriminating on the basis of race or color, inter alia, in their mortgage lending transactions, and required the defendants to pay the City $3 million in damages.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice, and each party shall bear its own costs, expenses, and attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: This sex discrimination fair housing case was brought by the United States in 2010 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Iowa against the owners of an apartment complex and their manager, alleging sexual harassment by the manager of two female tenants.[SENTMARKER]The women claimed they were subjected to offers of maintenance services in return for sex, pervasive, unwanted touching, gestures and remarks.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff claimed these actions constituted a pattern and practice of sexual discrimination in violation of the Fair Housing Act.[SENTMARKER]Though the owners had gone out of business during the course of the litigation, they entered into a five-year Consent Decree that included detailed prohibitions against sex discrimination, should they ever again engage in the business.[SENTMARKER]The manager was forever banned from any job involved in any aspect of the operation of any dwelling.[SENTMARKER]Defendants agreed to pay $80,000 in compensatory damages to aggrieved persons identified by Plaintiff and $15,000 in civil penalties.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2011, the U.S. Department of Justice filed this civil action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Iowa against Property Management, L.C., and Elders, Inc. for violating the Fair Housing Act of 1968 (the "Fair Housing Act") by engaging in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of sex in the rental of units at Park Towers Apartments in Waterloo, Towa (''Park Towe rs').[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' conduct constituted a pattern of discrimination based on sex or a den ial of rights to a group of people that ra ises an issue of general public importance.[SENTMARKER]The defendants entered into a consent order on September 22, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The consent order required the defendants to adopt a written Nondiscrimination Policy, provide a copy of the HUD booklet, Fair Housing; Equ.al Opportunity for A ll," to each household occopying a unit at each rentn l property, and conduct in-person training on Fair Housing.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on September 23, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice five years after the entry of the consent order.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, minority homeowners on behalf of similarly situated minority homeowners filed a class-action complaint in U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against H&R Block Inc., H&R Block Bank and its wholly-owned subsidiary,under the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1691, et seq. ("ECOA") and the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. § 3601 et seq.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants maintained a pattern or practice that had a discriminatory impact on minority applicants in their home financing policies and practices.[SENTMARKER]On August 21, 2013, the plaintiffs filed a stipulation to dismiss the case with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2013, a group of African-American homeowners brought suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against H&R Block, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries, San Canyon Corp., f/k/a Option One Mortgage Corporation and Ada Services Corporation, alleging that the defendants violated the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, the Fair Housing Act, and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that, between January 1, 2001 and the date of the suit, the defendants charged higher discretionary charges on their home loans than similarly situated white borrowers because of the defendants' policy of granting local managers discretion over pay and promotion decisions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, disgorgement, and injunctive and declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: The defendant to this 2008 family-status discrimination lawsuit brought by the United States in the District of Nebraska, was a condominium association whose "Amended Master Deed and Declaration" stated that no unit should be "sold or leased to a person who has a child under the age of 16 who will occupy or reside in the unit 180 days or more a year."[SENTMARKER]The suit's complainants alleged that this clause posed an obstacle to their intended sale of their condo units.[SENTMARKER]After discovery, the parties entered mediation, and on March 3, 2010, District Judge Warren K. Urbom approved a three-year consent decree.[SENTMARKER]In addition to a general prohibition against discrimination in the sale or rental of the condominium units, the decree required the defendants to develop and post a non-discrimination policy and to amend the master deed to excise  the prohibition against families with children.[SENTMARKER]Defendants agreed to pay $77,500 to the complainants, an additional $35,000 to other aggrieved parties, and a $15,000 civil penalty to the United States.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 29, 2008, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of Nebraska against The Latvian Tower Condominium Association, Inc. (LTCA) and its president, Karl Tegtmeyer.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 and the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988 by discriminating on the basis of familial status with respect to the sale of units in the Latvian Tower condominium complex in Omaha, Nebraska.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants adopted and enforced a Master Deed and By-Laws that prohibited children under the age of 16 from occupying or residing in a condominium unit in the complex.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the allegations of the complaint and entered into a consent order on November 12, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The consent order requires the defendants to post a fair housing sign in all common areas of the condominium complex, post a notice that they operate and manage the property on a nondiscriminatory basis, post an anti-discrimination policy, and pay the complainants' attorney's fees and court costs.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent order are subject to court approval.

gold_sents: An association of residents of a New Jersey neighborhood filled a lawsuit claiming that the defendants' redevelopment plan for the Gardens neighborhood represented a violation of the Fair Housing Act and the United States and New Jersey Constitutions.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendants' redevelopment plan, which razed numerous homes in a minority neighborhood, was discriminatory.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed the District Court's pretrial decision in favor of the town to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, which reversed, and found that the plaintiffs were entitled to a trial.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari to review the question whether disparate impact claims were available under the Fair Housing Act.  About two weeks prior to the scheduled argument, the parties settled; the city will construct 44 new homes, 20 for current residents in exchange for allowing redevelopment.[SENTMARKER]Seven households that elected to relocate will be compensated.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2005, a group of residents of the Mount Holly Gardens neighborhood of Mount Holly, New Jersey, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the Township of Solebury.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Township had violated the Fair Housing Act by denying them a building permit for the redevelopment of the neighborhood.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims without prejudice as unripe.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the Third Circuit, which reversed the district court's dismissal of the claims.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit held that there was no evidence of discrimination and that the District Court had not established a prima facie case of disparate impact sufficient to withstand summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the terms of the settlement agreement, which included the creation of a non-profit corporation to represent the community and the development of a community center in the community.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to approval by the community center's board of directors.

gold_sents: Low-income minority individuals in need of affordable housing filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1871, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the Town of Smithtown, complaining that  Smithtown operated its voucher program with a residency preference that discriminated on the basis of race, color, and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The court entered an order and final judgment approving the parties' settlement agreement under which the Town of Smithtown agreed to implement an anti-discrimination educational program, to affirmatively market the Section 8 Program to minority persons, to inform the public of its non-discriminatory policies, to maintain and preserve records for purposes of recordkeeping and reporting, and to pay $925,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]This settlement remains in effect until 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 2007, a group of African-American and Hispanic residents of Smithtown, New York filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York alleging that the town had violated the Fair Housing Act and the equal protection clause of the United States Constitution by using a residency preference for allocation of Section 8 housing vouchers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Smithtown's policies and practices in connection with the Section 8 program discriminated in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the rental of a dwelling because of race, color, and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which Smithtown agreed to: (i) provide mandatory training to all of its current employees and agents involved with the Program, which shall cover the requirements of the federal fair housing laws, Defendant's policy of equal housing opportunity, and the policies, operation, methods, and procedures governing the Program; .[SENTMARKER](ii) pay a settlement fund to the plaintiffs; and (iii) promote the program to minority applicants.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice as to Smithtown without costs.

gold_sents: On December 06, 2010, the United States filed suit under 42 U.S.C. 3601 of the Fair Housing Act against the owner of the Burgundy Gardens Apartments, LLC in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (Judge Kenneth Karas).[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff, represented by the Untied States Department of Justice asked the Court to 1) declare the Defendant's conduct a violation of the Fair Housing Act, 2) enjoin the Defendant from discriminating on the basis of race in the rental of dwellings, 3) award monetary damages and 4) assess a civil penalty.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the Plaintiff claims the Defendant's rental practices discriminated against African American prospective tenants.[SENTMARKER]On April 4,2012, the parties reached a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant was enjoined from further discriminatory rental practices on the basis of rate, and paid $150,000 in damages and $25,000 as a civil penalty.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 5, 2010, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York filed a lawsuit against Burgundy Gardens Apartments, LLC, d/b/a Burgundy Gardens, alleging that Burgundy Gardens discriminated against African Americans who were seeking rental housing because of race or color.[SENTMARKER]Burgundy Gardens agreed to pay $150,000 into a victim fund that will be available to compensate people who were harmed by the discriminatory rental practices of BURGUNDYS, and to pay a civil penalty of $25,000.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on April 16, 2012 (the "Consent Decree"), which enjoined Burgundy Gardens from discriminating in any aspect of the rental of dwellings against qualified applicants or tenants because of color or race.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required Burgundy Gardens to educate its employees on federal and state housing discrimination laws, and submit periodic reports to the Government containing information about its rental activity.[SENTMARKER]The Court retained jurisdiction for the duration of the Consent Decree, after which time the case shall be dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: The United States filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act against architects and developers of an apartment building claiming that the defendants designed and constructed the building so that it was inaccessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff entered into two separate three-year consent decrees; one requiring the architect to make all of its future designs compliant with the FHA and to pay a $20,000 civil penalty; the other with the developers requiring extensive retrofits to the building, $60,000 in damages and a $35,000 civil penalty.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 2011, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Manhattan District.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by failing to design and construct The Larkspur, a residential apartment complex in Manhattan, so as to be accessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to pay a total of 35,000 dollars to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered into by Judge Deborah A. Batts on October 5, 2011 and will remain in effect for three years following entry of the consent decree by the Court.[SENTMARKER]In addition to the money, the parties agreed to: Affirmative marketing of the apartment complex to the general public and to governmental and charitable groups that assist persons with disability; and the provision of apartment listings to Disabled American Veterans, New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, and the mayor's office for people with disabilities for publication on each group's respective website.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On April 12, 2012, the United States sued GFI Mortgage Bankers under the Fair Housing Act and Equal Credit Opportunity Act for charging African American and Hispanic borrowers higher fees and costs for home mortgage loans than it charged similarly situated white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a Consent Decree on August 27, 2012, which required GFI to pay $3.555 million and implement fair lending policies and a fair lending monitoring system.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 2, 2012, the Department of Justice and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York filed a lawsuit in federal court in Manhattan against GFI Mortgage Bankers, Inc., a New York-based mortgage banker, alleging that GFI engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination by charging African-American and Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates and fees on home mortgage loans because of their race or national origin, not based on their creditworthiness.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, from 2005 through at least 2009, GFI charged higher fees and interest rates to African-Americans than to similarly-situated non-Hispanic white borrowers in violation of the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the disparities were statistically significant because of GFI's home-loan pricing policy.[SENTMARKER]GFI entered into a settlement agreement with the Justice Department in which it agreed to adopt policies and procedures that require its employees and agents, in the process of an applicant's selection of a loan product, to explain the benefits and consequences of each loan product discussed.[SENTMARKER]In addition, GFI agreed to develop a fair lending program designed to ensure compliance with the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In 2014, a non-profit organization that provides housing assistance to formerly incarcerated individuals filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant, who owned and managed a multi-building apartment complex, had a discriminatory policy that unlawfully prohibited anyone with a criminal record from renting an apartment.[SENTMARKER]After years of discovery and litigation, the parties settled for over $1 million.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2014, The Fortune Society filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against Sandcastle Towers Housing Development Fund Corporation, Sarasota Gold LLC, E M Associates LLC, and Weissman Realty Group LLC.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and color at The Sand Castle, a multi-building apartment complex they own and manage in Queens, New York.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, defendants maintained and enforced a policy of automatically excluding any person with a record of a criminal conviction from renting or living in an apartment at the complex.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that defendants' policy of categorically excluding applicants who have felony or non-traffic misdemeanor convictions from tenancy, which causes an unjustified disparate impact on African-American and Hispanic applicants in violation of the Fair Housing Act, violated the New York State Human Rights Law, and violated the Federally-Assisted Housing Act. After discovery, both parties moved for summary judgment on this disparate impact claim.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 12, 2005, individual New York residents and the New York ACORN local chapter filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Easter District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Nassau County and the Village of Garden City under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to enjoin the defendants from proceeding with discriminatory zoning practices; to order Garden City to approve a proposed zoning that would allow for affordable housing; and to order the defendants to take all actions necessary to assure that the Social Service Site be redeveloped to maximize the availability of affordable and integrated housing.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2012, Judge Arthur D. Spatt granted defendant County's motion for summary judgment dismissing all claims against it.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 2014, Judge Spatt issued a final order for the plaintiffs and ordered Defendant Garden City to take a number of steps to prevent discrimination and to increase access to affordable housing.[SENTMARKER]After Judge Spatt's order, both parties appealed the decision.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit affirmed in part and remanded in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is back in the lower courts on remand.[SENTMARKER]On remand, Judge Spatt found that the plaintiffs had met their burden at trial in demonstrating that the Garden City’s proffered reasons for its chosen zoning change could have been met by another practice, such as R-M zoning, that had a less discriminatory effect.[SENTMARKER]Magistrate Judge Arlene R. Lindsay thereafter awarded plaintiffs $5,255,108.94 in attorneys fees and costs from Garden City.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 2019, Judge Spatt signed the parties’ stipulation of discontinuance with prejudice, except without prejudice as to the court’s jurisdiction for the purpose of interpretation or enforcement of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the County to pay $5,400,000 to the plaintiffs to be used for the purpose of furthering and promoting mixed-income affordable housing; $120,000 to NYCC to be used for activities related to fair and affordable housing; and $400,000 to plaintiffs’ counsel for attorneys’ fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2005, the New York Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now (NY ACORN) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the Village of Garden City and the Garden City Board of Trustees (collectively, the "Village Defendants"), alleging that the Village violated the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Protection Clause of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Civil Rights Act") by changing the zoning of a certain area of the Village.[SENTMARKER]The Village Defendants moved to dismiss the case for lack of standing and failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the County's motion for summary judgment in part and dismissed the case against the County on February 12, 2012.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2016, the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's final judgment, in part, and remanded the case to the Court for further proceedings.

gold_sents: This 2011 federal fair lending lawsuit in the Western District of Texas was brought by the United States against a local bank the U.S. alleged had engaged in a pattern or practice of providing loans to Hispanics only at higher rates than to non-Hispanics, without justification.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement, submitted simultaneously with the complaint, the bank agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures designed to ensure nondiscriminatory pricing, and to numerous other implementation provisions, including fair credit training, systemic monitoring, complaint resolution processes, and $91,000 in damages to aggrieved persons.[SENTMARKER]The provisions of the order were scheduled to last 4 and 1/4 years.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) is a federal law that prohibits discrimination on the basis of national origin in the pricing of unsecured consumer loans.[SENTMARKER]The complaint, filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas, alleged that Nixon State Bank discriminated against Hispanic borrowers by charging higher rates of interest than non-Hispanic borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The court entered an order requiring the bank to pay $91,600 to Hispanic borrowers and to implement a complaint resolution program to address the alleged discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The bank also agreed to implement new policies and procedures to improve its overall fair lending program, including new loan procedures for obtaining loan applications, financial statements, and cr edit reports.

gold_sents: The United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing and Equal Credit Opportunity Acts against PrimeLending, claiming that the defendant displayed a pattern or practice of discrimination in lending on the basis of race against African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in which Primelending agreed to refrain from practicing race based discrimination, submit to a monitoring and reporting program, provide borrowers with a general notice of nondiscrimination, provide equal credit opportunity training to its employees, provide a total of $2 million to be distributed among those aggrieved,  allocate any unclaimed portion of the $2 million to organizations that provide general financial education to African-American borrowers, and maintain a complaint resolution program to resolve discrimination claims.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Texas brought this suit against Prime Lending, Inc., a Texas-based retail mortgage lender, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged discrimination on the basis of race in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the provision of services in connection with sale of a dwelling.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $22,000 to the plaintiff, the Urban League of Greater Dallas, and to implement a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination regarding loans secured by residential real estate originated by the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendant's policies and practices constitute violations of Fair Housing and Equal Credit Act provisions, and the defendant also agreed to compensate certain African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2013,  the U.S. Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Fort Davis State Bank, alleging that it charged Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans compared to the rates it charged white borrowers, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]In January 2014, the District Court (Judge Robert A. Junell) approved a consent order in which the bank agreed to implement a variety of practices to address these alleged violations and to pay damages to aggrieved borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The consent order remained in effect until early 2017.[SENTMARKER]Since there has been no substantive docket activity after 2014, the case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) prohibits financial institutions from discriminating on the basis of, inter alia, national origin in their lending practices.[SENTMARKER]The complaint, filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas, alleged that Fort Davis State Bank (FDSB) charged higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans to Hispanic borrowers than to similarly situated non-Hispanic white borrowers from January 1, 2008 to December 31, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that FDSB did not properly instruct its loan officers regarding their obligation to treat prospective customers without regard to national origin, and the Bank failed to supervise or monitor the performance of its loan officer to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2011, the FDIC referred the lending practices of FDSB to the United States Department of Justice for investigation.[SENTMARKER]On December 30, 2010, the FDIC filed a consent order in the court, which was approved and entered by Judge Robert A. Junell.[SENTMARKER]The consent order provides for the Bank to pay $159,000 in monetary damages to aggrieved persons and to implement a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination regarding loans.[SENTMARKER]The Bank also agreed to a monitoring program designed to monitor the Bank's lending practices for potential disparities based on national origin.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent order are subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Wisconsin against Southport Bank, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, sought a declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, compensatory damages to all of the victims of the defendant's discriminatory policies, and a civil penalty, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On October 11, 2013, the District Court (Judge Joseph Peter Stadtmueller) entered a consent order between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not admit to any pattern or practice of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendant from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the Fair Housing Act or any credit transaction in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.  Among other things, the defendant's employees will have to participate in a fair lending training program and will be subject to monitoring and reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also has to place $687,000 into a settlement fund to compensate for monetary damages that aggrieved persons may have suffered.[SENTMARKER]The order terminates after three years if the defendant has complied during that time period.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 11, 2013, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Wisconsin filed this complaint against Southport Bank of Kenosha, Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that from 2007 to 2008, Southport charged hundreds of African-American and Hispanic wholesale borrowers higher fees than non-Hispanic white borrowers because of their race and national origin.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Southport's business practice was to allow its mortgage brokers to vary their fees and thus alter the price set based on a borrower's objective credit-related factors.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2008, Southport closed its wholesale mortgage lending program and closed its credit reporting unit, ComCor.[SENTMARKER]The FDIC found reason to believe that Southport had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination by allowing wholesale brokers to charge higher fees for home loans than white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Southport did not conduct any type of broker monitoring to determine whether there were disparities between the total fees charged to minority and white borrowers in violation of the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. On October 13, 2013, Judge J. Stadtmueller entered an order enjoining Southport from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction.[SENTMARKER]The order also requires Southport to maintain data on the race and ethnicity of each borrower.[SENTMARKER]The court will retain jurisdiction for the duration of the order, after which time the case shall be dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: Following an investigation by the United States Department of Justice, the U.S. filed this lawsuit against the State of Connecticut, its Department of Mental Retardation, and the Director of Southbury Training School (Southbury) on July 25, 1986, alleging that living conditions at Southbury placed residents in grave danger of bodily harm and death.[SENTMARKER]On the same day, the parties also entered into a consent decree that required Southbury to provide better programming, disciplinary procedures, medical care, recordkeeping, and increase staffing.[SENTMARKER]After some problems with compliance and placing the state in contempt, the Court assigned a special master to monitor Southbury.[SENTMARKER]After making significant progress, on March 25, 2006, the court ended judicial oversight, but retained jurisdiction over the consent decree and remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]On November 2, 2009, the Court granted a joint motion to dismiss the case because the parties agreed that the consent decree and remedial plan were fully implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 11, 1985, a resident of the Southbury Training School, a Connecticut institution for persons with developmental disabilities, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut against the State of Connecticut, its governor, the Department of Mental Retardation, and the Director of the St. Louis Public Schools.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA"), 42 U.s.C.  1997 et seq., by the state of Connecticut of the living conditions at the institution.[SENTMARKER]The court found the defendants in contempt of the consent decree, which required the defendants to submit an implementation plan addressing the procedures by which the consent consent decree would be effectuated.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the district court on October 6, 1991.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed this appeal in the United States Court of Appeals for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]On June 19, 1996, the court dismissed the case, finding that the defendants had not complied with the decree.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Supreme Court, which remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: Disability Rights Washington filed this class action on behalf of individuals with intellectual disabilities in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington in April 2014.[SENTMARKER]They sued the State healthcare authority and department of social services, alleging that budget cuts resulted in inadequate services in violation of the Nursing Home Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement one year later and the final settlement was approved in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is ongoing and under court supervision through September 30, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] On April 16, 2014, a resident of a private nursing facility filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Secretary of the Washington State Department of Social and Health Services (DSHS) and the Director of Washington State Health Care Authority (HCA) alleging that the defendants did not have an adequate system in place for persons with intellectual disabilities and related conditions living in privately-operated Medicaid-certified nursing facilities to be screened, assessed and/or receive specialized services, in violation of the Medicaid Act and the Nursing Home Reform Act (NHRA).[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in December 2016, which required the defendants to implement a pre-admission screening and resident referral system for those with disabilities living in private nursing facilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to post a notice on the defendants' website to ensure compliance with the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 28, 2016, and the parties filed a petition for early termination of the agreement, which the court denied.

gold_sents: Individuals with intellectual disabilities residing in the Wyoming State Training School filed this lawsuit in 1990 to challenge conditions at the School and a lack of community placement options.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed in 1991 to a settlement that was designed not only to improve conditions in the institution, but also to prevent unnecessary institutionalization and create options for community living for individuals with intellectual disabilities in Wyoming.[SENTMARKER]The court's jurisdiction was ended in 1994.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 3, 1990, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Wyoming against the Wyoming State Training School, the Wyoming Department of Health, and the Wyoming School Nurses Association.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the rights of individuals with developmental disabilities by failing to provide alternative services for them in their communities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Stipulation Agreement on June 15, 1990.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would engage in good faith negotiations to resolve this dispute.[SENTMARKER]On April 30, 1990, the case was certified by the Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On October 12, 1994, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The motion was denied and the parties entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to provide adequate transportation and services for individuals with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The final decision was entered by the District Court on October 12, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement on October 26, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $75,000.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to provide the plaintiffs with an individual education plan.

gold_sents: These 2007 consolidated cases were brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona to challenge the "Legal Arizona Workers Act", which mandates investigation and prosecution of employers who knowingly or intentionally employ unauthorized aliens and requires the revocation of the licenses of employers found to have done so.[SENTMARKER]It also makes mandatory a previously voluntary verification process.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court affirmed the lower courts' rulings, holding that the Act fell within ICRA's savings clause and thus was not expressly preempted by federal law.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE ||| CIVIL ||||| DATE [CONTRACTED] On September 17, 2008, a group of business, labor, and civil rights organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the Arizona Attorney General, the Governor of Arizona, the Arizona Farm Bureau Federation, and the Director of the Department of Revenue of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Arizona Migrant and Seasonal Worker Protection Act (AWPA), which seeks to regulate employment eligibility and immigration status verification, was preempted by federal immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the law was not preempted and dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the district court's dismissal of the case on the grounds that the Attorney General lacked subject matter jurisdiction to bring enforcement actions.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court declined to hear the appeal and the case was closed on March 9, 2009.

gold_sents: On July 6, 2010, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Supremacy Clause and the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution against the state of Arizona and the Governor of Arizona in her official capacity in the U.S. District Court of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070, which contains several provisions designed to "discourage and deter the unlawful entry and presence of aliens" in Arizona, impermissibly infringes on the federal government's right to enact and enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2010, the district court issued a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed the grant of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On April 11, 2011, the U.S. Court of Appeals, 9th Circuit, issued an opinion upholding the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court granted cert on December 12, 2011 and issued their opinion on June 25, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court affirmed in part and reversed in part, striking down most of the challenged provisions of S.B.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2010, the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona entered a preliminary injunction against Arizona's "alien smuggling prohibition" in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA") and the Constitution of the United States ("Clause").[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 was not preempted by federal law, but the district court declined to enjoin certain parts of it.[SENTMARKER]The parties then appealed to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit held that the District Court did not abuse its discretion, and the case was dismissed on the merits.

gold_sents: On May 17, 2010, a group of organizations and individuals filed a lawsuit against the Sheriff and Attorney of each of the 15 counties in Arizona, in their official capacities, in the U.S. District Court of Arizona, Phoenix Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by organizations such as the ACLU and the National Immigration Law Center along with private counsel, sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 was a violation of the Supremacy Clause of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiff contends that S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 conflicts with federal law and procedures and that local law enforcement agencies are ill equipped to deal with the complexities of immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction in February 2012, which the defendants appealed.[SENTMARKER]In a related case, Arizona v. United States, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down most of S.B.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction against the remaining provisions of S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 and while the parties were going through discovery disputes, the defendant filed a motion for summary judgment on March 17, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a response to the defendant's summary judgment and on September 4, 2015, the district court ruled in favor of the defendant with regard to plaintiff's claims under the Supremacy Clause, Equal Protection Clause, the Fourth Amendment, Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, the Due Process Clause, and 42 U.S.C. §1981.[SENTMARKER]Notably, the court also entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on count three claim which was appealed.[SENTMARKER]Finally, on September 15, 2016, both parties conferred and filed a joint case disposition in which the plaintiff settled for $1.4 million.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] On May 17, 2010, a group of civil rights organizations and individuals filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the State of Arizona, the City of Chandler, and the Maricopa County Sheriff's Office alleging that Arizona's Senate Bill 1070, as amended ("S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070"), a comprehensive set of state immigration laws, violated the First Amendment right to free speech.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on June 21, 2010, and the Ninth Circuit upheld the district court's injunction on September 16, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2012, the plaintiffs filed this interlocutory appeal, which was dismissed on December 7, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a final judgment on July 11, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their First Amendment claim.[SENTMARKER]The case is now resolved.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2015, civil detainees confined in the Tucson Sector of the U.S. Border Patrol filed a class action lawsuit, alleging violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the APA due to inhumane and punitive conditions while they were detained in holding cells.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a PI mandating that defendants must maintain conditions of confinement adequate for the detainees' physical needs and provide detainees with mats and blankets after 12 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the PI order.[SENTMARKER]In 2018 the plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of defendants' obligation to provide raised beds for detainees held for any period requiring sleep; the district court denied this motion.[SENTMARKER]After a 7-day trial in January 2020, the district court held that these extended confinement conditions violated the Constitution and issued an order enjoining the defendants from holding detainees for longer than 48 unless they provided conditions of confinement that meet basic human needs.[SENTMARKER]This permanent injunction was ordered and has been in effect since April 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 8, 2015, three civil immigration detainees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona, alleging that the conditions of their confinement at the Tucson Sector Border Patrol facility violated their Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The district court certified a class of all individuals who are now or in the future will be detained at a CBP facility within the Border Patrol’s Tucson Sector.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in part, but denied the motion for reconsideration.[SENTMARKER]On March 21, 2018, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the district court's summary judgment for the defendants.

gold_sents: In 2018, former Latino/a guests at Motel 6 locations in Arizona filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that Motel 6's policy of disclosing guests' information to DHS and ICE agents without requiring a warrant or reasonable suspicion of criminal activity violated the United States Constitution and federal and state law.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged Motel 6 conspired with DHS and ICE agents to violate guests’ Fourth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, the parties agreed to class action settlement terms and the district court approved the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court retains jurisdiction over the matter for the duration of the consent decree.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 24, 2018, Motel 6 Operating, L.P., G6 Hospitality LLC, and Does 1-10 ( collectively referred to as "Motel 6") filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against Motel 6 for violating federal and state law by disclosing guest registration information, including personal information, to federal immigration agents without a warrant or reasonable suspicion of criminal activity.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Motel 6's policy and/or practice of disclosing personal information to immigration agents violated the company's written assurances that it protects the privacy of its guests, and to assist DHS and ICE agents in unlawfully arresting or detaining guests.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2018, the parties engaged in a day-long mediation before a professional mediator.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which Motel 6 agreed to: (i) allocate thirty-five percent 21 (35%) of the Cy Pres Fund to FIRRP; .[SENTMARKER](ii) provide training to its employees that if they have 10 questions about this policy, they should call the 24-Hour Hotline; .[SENTMARKER](iii) allocate fifteen percent 11 (15%) of Cy Pres to TheDream.US.[SENTMARKER]; and (iv) allocate ten percent 20 (15%), fifteen percent, ten percent, and five percent, respectively, to The Dream.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Senior Judge David G Campbell on February 18, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice on August 31, 2019.

gold_sents: Following his arrest and confinement at the Coconino County Detention Facility (CCDF), plaintiff challenged the prolonged detention of inmates at CCDF triggered by detainer requests from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agency (ICE).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff claimed this policy violated Article II, section 8 of the Arizona Constitution and the Fourth   and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]He sought class-wide declaratory and injunctive relief for all CCDF detainees subject to this prolonged detention policy despite their eligibility for pretrial release.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the district of Arizona denied the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, citing his inability to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits of his claims.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff moved to dismiss the case thereafter, which was accepted by the court.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2018, a Mexican national arrested in Coconino County, Arizona, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the County, the County Sheriff's Office, and the County Board of Supervisors challenging the County's unconstitutional policy of prolonging detention of inmates for whom it receives a "detainer" request from ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the policy violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, and Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, which provides that "No person shall be disturbed in his private when Plaintiff actually posts bond and ICE takes custody of him."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought a preliminary injunction and injunctive relief, seeking to enjoin the County from detaining an unauthorized immigrant at the request of federal immigration authorities.[SENTMARKER]On May 8, 2018, the District Court denied the plaintiff's motion for a temporary restraining order and dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In June 2017, the Center for Biological Diversity sued DHS and CBP, bringing challenges to the Trump Administration's proposed border wall (FOIA, environmental statutes, APA, IIRIRA).[SENTMARKER]After consolidation with several cases, on Feb.[SENTMARKER]2018, the Court granted the government's motion to dismiss (except for the FOIA claim) and denied plaintiffs' SJ cross-motions.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to dismiss the FOIA claim.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Lastly, the Supreme Court denied the plaintiff's petition for writ of certiorari regarding the constitutional issue of separation of powers in the IIRIRA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 2, 2017, the Center for Biological Diversity filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking declaratory and/or injunctive relief under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) for the San Diego and Calexico border barrier projects.[SENTMARKER]The Center's FOIA requests sought records related to the agencies' compliance with NEPA and other laws in relation to the border wall prototype project.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the FOIA requests for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that the plaintiffs' claims were precluded by the Secretary's waiver of NEPA, the Coastal Zone Management Act, and the APA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's summary judgment on the environmental claims to the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit reversed the decision by the District Court and held that it did not have jurisdiction to consider MCorp's challenge Id.[SENTMARKER]1995) and Organized Vill's appeal.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court granted summary judgment to the defendants on the non-constitutional challenges to the waiver determinations.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 23, 2018 the ACLU of Northern California filed this lawsuit against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) under the Freedom of Information Act, alleging that ICE had not provided the ACLU with documents they had requested related to ICE's purchase of automated license plate reader data.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a schedule for the documents to be released on a rolling basis, which was completed in November 2018.[SENTMARKER]A settlement also required ICE to pay attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 23, 2018, the ACLU of Northern California filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking records relating to contracts between ICE and private companies for access and use of automated license plate reader (ALPR) technology, along with relevant training material, privacy guidance, audit logs, and other guidance regarding the appropriate use by ICE of ALPR technology.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE wrongfully withheld the requested records in violation of FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which ICE agreed to release the requested documents to the ACLU.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on July 20, 2018, provided for the release and disclosure of 17 of the requested agency records, as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the ACLU's motion for partial summary judgment, and the parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: Two San Francisco Bay Area fathers filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after being detained for over 6 months in ICE custody without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction and class certification ordering that individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(6) pending a determination as to whether they can remain in the United States with “live claims”  before an adjudicative body cannot be detained for more than 180 days without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed both orders to the Ninth Circuit, and on April 7, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Following plaintiffs' motion to enforce the preliminary injunction, the court granted it in part, finding that the defendants had not substantially complied with certain requirements, but denied it in part.[SENTMARKER]As of April 16, 2021, this case is pending a writ of certiorari in front of the Supreme Court.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of noncitizens detained pursuant to the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were detained without being given a 20 bond hearing, where an immigration judge determines whether they pose a flight risk or a danger to the community.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a class certification on their statutory and constitutional claims, and a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit reversed the district court's grant of the preliminary injunction, and the Supreme Court granted the government's writ of certiorari.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded for consideration of the plaintiffs’ constitutional due process challenges to the statutes at issue Id.[SENTMARKER]2005, that Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) requires only a showing that disability was a motivating factor to prove a violation of the statute.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
