pegasus_output_sents: On March 2, 2017, Community Legal Services in East Palo Alto and the National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild (NIPNLG) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Department of Justice (DOJ) alleging violations of the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that DHS and DOJ violated the FOIA by failing to respond to a FOIA 10 request sent to DHS in March 2017 and failing to search for and disclose the requested records, as well as other appropriate relief.[SENTMARKER]On January 25, 2017, President George H.W.[SENTMARKER]Trump signed an Executive Order, "Enhancing Public Safety in the Interior of the Interior," announcing an expansion in interior immigration enforcement.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants failed to respond in a timely manner to the FOIA request, failed to conduct a reasonable search for records, and failed to produce any records responsive to Plaintiffs' request.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment and ordered DHS to pay $16,350.10 (Sixteen thousand three hundred-fifty dollars and ten four cents) to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the court of appeal.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which DHS agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees, costs, and litigation expenses.

gold_sents: A group of Iranian refugees and their U.S. sponsors filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) denied their refugee resettlement applications en masse in February 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs applied for refugee resettlement through the Vienna, Austria-based Lautenberg-Specter program for Iranian religious minorities, but received mass denials with the sole explanation that they were denied "as a matter of discretion."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Lautenberg Amendment, which mandates that the denial state "to the maximum extent feasible, the reason for the denial," as well as Fifth Amendment due process and DHS's own regulations.[SENTMARKER]On July 2018, the court declared the denial notices unlawful, and ordered DHS to re-issue new notices.[SENTMARKER]As of June 3, 2020, the case is still ongoing.

gold_sents: On June 16, 2019, plaintiffs--three immigration attorneys and two noncitizens who filed FOIA (FOIA) requests for individual immigration case files (known as A-Files)--filed this class-action suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs, represented by the American Immigration Council and the Northwest Immigrant Rights Project, sought declaratory relief that defendants’ failure to make timely determinations on plaintiffs’ and proposed classes’ A-File FOIA requests violates FOIA, and a nationwide injunction requiring defendants to make timely determinations.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for declaratory and injunctive relief and ordered the defendants to provide quarterly reports on their compliance with the FOIA.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 2019, three immigration attorneys and two noncitizens filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of individuals who filed Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests for individual immigration case files, also known as Alien 4 Registration Files or A-Files.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had a pattern or practice of failing to meet the statutory deadline with respect to A-File FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in 1992, in which the parties agreed to implement expedited processing of FOIA requests where the requester demonstrates that an individual’s life or personal safety would be jeopardized or that substantial due process rights would be impaired by the failure to process a request immediately.[SENTMARKER]On August 28, 2020, the Ninth Circuit reversed the settlement agreement and remanded on a separate issue.[SENTMARKER]On March 29, 2020, the court granted preliminary injunctive relief to plaintiff organizations that serve low-income applicants for immigration benefits and stayed USCIS rule fee changes for immigration benefit requests.

Plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order and an order vacating and setting aside the policy.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declarative relief and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]In a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, the plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 6, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2020, the Regents of the University of California filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security and the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP), a division of ICE.[SENTMARKER]The Regents alleged that the SEVP's July 6, 2020 memorandum and news release requiring schools to certify to SEVP for each F-1 visa student attending such school that, among other things, the student is not taking an entirely online course load for the fall 2020 semester, was arbitrary, capricious, or otherwise not in accordance with law.[SENTMARKER]The Administrative Procedure Act (APA) provides that federal agencies are accountable to the public and their actions subject to review by the courts.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, 2020, The Regents served Defendants with the summons and complaint filed in this matter, as well as a Motion for Temporary Restraining Order and Order to Show Cause re: TRO Motion to enjoin Defendants from implementing the Directive.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Regents' motion for a preliminary injunction and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Seven unnamed individuals sued ICE and DHS over their new directive that would effectively force international students to take in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought injunctive relief prohibiting the enforcement of the directive and an order vacating the directive.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance, but the plaintiffs in this case filed an amended complaint that sought a formal declaration that the July 6 directive was improperly issued and an order that the government administer the student visa program in accordance with the March guidance for the duration of the emergency.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the students' claims were mooted by the rescission and granted the government's motion to dismiss on October 1, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 10, 2020, a group of graduate students studying at California universities on F-1 visas filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the Department of Homeland Security's Student and Exchange Visa Program (SEVP) and the acting director of the SEVP.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order (TRO) enjoining the implementation of a July 6 policy change that barred student visa holders from remaining in the United States during the upcoming fall semester if their universities cancelled in-person classes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The TRO sought relief on the grounds that the policy change was unlawful and unlawful promulgated.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.

gold_sents: In 2020, the State of California, the City of Los Angeles, the City of Long Beach, the City of Oakland, and the Los Angeles Unified School District filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that President Trump's Memorandum violated the constitutional mandates for the census (actual enumeration and apportionment) and separation of powers, as well as violating the Census Act and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of September 28, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 12, 2019, the City of Los Angeles and the Los Angeles Unified School District filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the U,S.[SENTMARKER]Census Bureau, the Department of Commerce, and the Secretary of Commerce.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive, mandamus, and other relief to prevent Defendants from taking any action to exclude undocumented immigrants from the 2020 3 Census apportionment count.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs are entitled to a declaration that the Constitution and the Census Act require the apportionment base used to apportion congressional representatives to include all persons 15 counted in each state, including undocumented immigrants.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed and affirmed the vacatur of the Secretary's decision to add a question to the 2020 Census questionnaire on citizenship status, but the President issued an executive order to allow the exclusion of 27 undocumented immigrants in his apportionment report to Congress.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, granted their motion for injunctive relief, and granted their request for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 3, 2017, the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee ( ADC) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on behalf of ADC, an organization primarily involved in the dissemination of information about the Global Entry System (GES) for certain Arab and Muslim citizens and Lawful Permanent Residents (LPRs) in the United States.[SENTMARKER]ADC sought expedited processing of records related to GES revocations, suspensions, terminations, confirmations, and policy practices, citing the urgent need to inform the public about CBP’s actions in suspending, revoking, or terminating GES authorization for Arabs and Muslims.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2019, the parties filed a joint status report in which the parties resolved their differences as to the parties’ search for and production of non-exempt, responsive records subject to the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the ADC attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the ADC.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on July 5, 2019.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2018, Muslim Advocates, a not-for-profit legal advocacy and educational organization, filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice (DOJ) and the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking documents related to the federal government's denaturalization efforts, including but not limited to "Operation Janus," a joint initiative between DOJ and ICE.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOJ's National Security Division (NSD) and ICE's Civil Division (Civil Division) violated the FOIA by failing to process and release to Muslim Advocates all responsive documents that they had unlawfully withheld.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2018, the NSD issued a final determination on Muslim Advocates' FOIA request, and the parties filed a joint status report on or before April 10, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2018, the court dismissed the case, finding that the Civil Division's withholding of responsive documents was improper and that Muslim Advocates was a member of the news media.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to a fee waiver pursuant to FOIA  552(a)(4)(II) because disclosure of documents pertaining to Denaturalization and Operation Janus is in the public interest and because Muslim Advocates is a news media member.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the parties to file another Joint Status Report by May 29, 2018.

gold_sents: 37 families detained at three ICE-managed family residential centers sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security alleging violations of their Fifth Amendment constitutional rights, violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, and violations of the Flores Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the congregate environment and unsanitary conditions of the detention centers make them a tinderbox for a COVID-19 outbreak.[SENTMARKER]They sought immediate release until proper protocols could be implemented.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order which was granted in part and denied in part on March 30.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered ICE to provide appropriate infection protocols for the adults (a similar order from another case, Flores, applies to the children), to comply with CDC guidelines for congregate institutions, and to file a report regarding FRC capacity, implementation of the CDC guidelines, the number of detainees released, and videotape of the living conditions at the FRCs.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss and a motion in opposition to the temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the plaintiffs' later motion for a preliminary injunction demanding wholesale release of detainees on July 22.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, the court dismissed the claim under the APA and the writs of mandamus.[SENTMARKER]A hearing is scheduled for February 16, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2020, a group of transgender immigrants filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security's Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking the release of all transgender people in ICE detention facilities nationwide during the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ICE violated their Fifth Amendment due process rights and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by failing to adequately protect transgender immigrants from the virus, which causes severe illness and death.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) directing ICE to immediately release all transgender detainees across the country and to refrain from detaining any additional transgender detainees until the pandemic ends.[SENTMARKER]The TRO also certified a class of all civil immigration detainees being held at one facility in Aurora, Colorado, and ordered ICE to provide adequate medical care to transgender immigrants in its custody.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Non-citizen soldiers in the U.S. military brought this lawsuit in May 2017, challenging policies of the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Defense that unlawfully delayed their naturalization applications.[SENTMARKER]The court certified a class and granted a preliminary injunction against the agencies on October 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2019, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, ruling that the agencies’ policy of delaying naturalization applications was arbitrary and capricious, in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a permanent injunction on August 20, 2020, and retained jurisdiction to enforce the injunction.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 8, 2019, Human Rights First filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Attorney General of the United States (AG) seeking declaratory, injunctive, and other relief under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), and the Federal Vacancies Reform Act (FVRA) against the DHS and the AG.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff's complaint alleges that the DHS's attempt to abrogate the asylum protections codified in the INA by issuing a final rule in violation of the APA and the FVRA is unlawful in many respects.[SENTMARKER]The final rule was published in the Federal Register on December 11, 2020, and lists an effective date of January 11, 2021.[SENTMARKER]In the alternative, Plaintiff seeks a stay of implementation of the rule pending final adjudication of this matter.[SENTMARKER]On January 10, 2019, the court granted a preliminary injunction against the rule, and the case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 13, 2020, 341 civil immigration detainees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida alleging that they were being held by the Miami Field Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and housed at three detention centers in Miami, Florida.[SENTMARKER]The detainees alleged that the detention centers were ill-equipped to deal with the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction requiring Miami-Dade County to employ numerous safety measures to prevent the spread of COVID19, as well as imposing extensive reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Eleventh Circuit, which granted a stay of the injunction pending an appeal by the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties have not been able to reach a mutually agreeable resolution as to the ongoing conditions at the facilities.[SENTMARKER]ICE reports that it has complied with the TRO in this regard.

gold_sents: On May 25, 2011, three foreign residents of Indiana filed a class action lawsuit against the cities of Indianapolis and Franklin and the counties of Marion and Johnson, seeking to enjoin enforcement of Indiana's Senate Enrolled Act 590, which would allow local law enforcement officers to make warrantless arrests of people who were subject to a removal order issued by an immigration court or a detainer or notice of action issued by the Department of Homeland Security, or who had been indicted or convicted of an aggravated felony, and would make the use of consular identification cards for identification within the state a civil infraction punishable by fine.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2013, the District Court (Judge Barker) ruled in favor of plaintiffs, granting their motion for summary judgment, and permanently enjoining defendants from enforcing Sections 18 and 20 of SEA 590.[SENTMARKER]Because plaintiffs' suit was dependent upon enforcement of these sections, the matter was dismissed without prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 25, 2011, two immigrants filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the City of Indianapolis, the Johnson County Sheriff, and the Indiana Attorney General challenging the constitutionality of two provisions of the recently enacted Senate Enrolled Act 590 (SEA 590).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of a class of persons who regularly use their consular identification cards for identification purposes, including, among other things, when banking or interacting with consular officials.[SENTMARKER]On June 24, 2011, the Court entered a preliminary injunction, enjoining the State of Indiana from enforcing the two challenged provisions of SEA 590 until further order from the Court.[SENTMARKER]On November 20, 2011, the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment, requesting that the previously entered preliminary injunction be made permanent and that judgment be entered in their favor against all Defendants.[SENTMARKER]In its response, the Office of the Attorney General requested not only that Plaintiffs’ motion be denied but also that summary judgment be issued for the state officials.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court clarified the scope of its Coleman holding in Raines and granted summary judgment in the case.

gold_sents: In February 2018, an undocumented immigrant who was married to a U.S. citizen filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that her unexpected arrest and detainment without notice or a hearing violated her due process rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]In April 2018, nine more plaintiffs were added, and they sought class certification, which was approved on May 17, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On June 27, the district court instructed the defendants to begin providing monthly reports to class counsel regarding class members.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a motion for immediate release of that class member because he was detained in a facility where an employee tested positive for COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]On April 16, the parties filed a joint status report that altered the terms of release for the class member and the court lifted the stay on the class member's removal by ICE.[SENTMARKER]ICE imposed conditions of supervision pursuant to the parties' agreement.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on November 18, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On Jan.[SENTMARKER]24, 2018, the NAACP sued the DHS over its Nov. 2017 revocation of Temporary Protected Status (first implemented after the Jan.[SENTMARKER]2017 revocation of Temporary Protected Status (first implemented after the Jan.[SENTMARKER]2010 Haitian earthquake) for Haitians living in the United States.[SENTMARKER]The NAACP alleged that DHS violated the 5th Amendment by relying on racially discriminatory stereotypes to deprive Haitians of rights and sought mandamus and declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which was granted in part and denied in part by the court on March 12, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The court allowed the plaintiffs' 5th Amendment claims to move forward.[SENTMARKER]Due to ongoing parallel litigation over the revocation of TPS for Haitians, the defendants requested a stay in this case.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the stay in March 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2020, a class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the Howard County Department of Corrections (HCD) alleging that the defendants violated the Fourteenth Amendment due process rights of immigration detainees by putting them in extreme danger of exposure to COVID-19, a lethal virus with no vaccine or cure.[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2020, the Court issued a memorandum opinion and order denying without prejudice a Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) in which Petitioners Coreas and A G C sought their immediate release from ICE detention.[SENTMARKER]The Court held that Petitioners had not yet shown they were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims that their continued ICE detention violated their right to due process under the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2020, Petitioners filed a petition for a writ of Habeas and a complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief, along with a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO), seeking their release from the two Maryland detention facilities as they await adjudication of their immigration cases.[SENTMARKER]In a published order, the Ninth Circuit ordered the release of an immigrant detainee because of the danger posed by COVID19, for which there is no known vaccine, treatment, or cure, on March 23, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On April 4, 2020, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for TRO, but denied the TRO on the basis that the plaintiffs had not shown that they would succeed on their claim that their detention violated due process.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On July 17, 2006, the City of Valley Park, Missouri passed an ordinance that required landlords to provide the City with an array of immigration-status documents with their application for an occupancy permit, and the implicit admission that certain noncitizens with legal status would be denied residency in Valley Park.[SENTMARKER]On September 22, 2006, Windhover, Inc. and others filed suit in the Circuit Court for the County of St. Louis alleging that the ordinance violated the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C.  3601, et seq., and Missouri state law.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2007, the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment in the Missouri Court of Appeals for the Middle District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]On August 3, 2007, the court dismissed the case with prejudice, holding that there was no longer a case or controversy.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened on October 2, 2007, and the parties agreed to settle the case.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 1, 2020, a group of immigration detainees filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, alleging that their detention at Adams County Detention Center in Natchez, Mississippi violated their right to substantive and procedural due process under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution and the right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were particularly vulnerable to serious illness or death if infected by COVID-19, an Unprecedented and Lethal Global Pandemic, and that their conditions of confinement were inadequate to protect their health and safety.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2020, the court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, finding that the plaintiffs had not shown that the conditions of their detention were unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied the defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending appeal to the Fifth Circuit.

pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| DATE ||| LAW ||||| DATE [CONTRACTED] On June 16, 1997, a group of foreign nationals seeking asylum in the United States filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against a private detention center in Elizabeth, New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention center violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1988 (RFRA) by denying them access to a law library and other legal materials, failing to provide them with personal property confiscated or destroyed while they were detained, and failing to pay them for their legal fees.[SENTMARKER]The district court awarded the plaintiffs nearly $5 million in general negligence damages and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed and the Fifth Circuit reversed the district court's judgment of fees, holding that the plaintiffs were not prevailing parties, and were thus ineligible for fees under the First Circuit's fee statute.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit remanded the case to the District Court to make a discretionary determination as to whether or not the plaintiffs had a right to fees under RFRA.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a declaratory judgment, and the case was dismissed on appeal.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 20, 2007, the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund (PRLDEF) and the international law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene MacRae LLP filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the New York Regional Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and the City of New Haven.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their constitutional rights by unlawfully searching their homes and targeting Latinos for arrest.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction, and granted the defendants’ motion for summary judgment on the pleadings.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 2, 2009, and the defendants appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On May 19, 2011, the Supreme Court ruled that the plaintiffs had standing to sue the DHS and ICE.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' appeal was denied and the case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In March of 1998, a group of lawful permanent residents of the United States filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the New York City District Office of Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Administrative Procedure Act, 551, 706(1) and 553, and the Immigration and Nationality Act  336(b) in the district court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DHS and USCIS failed to meet their clear obligations to adjudicate applications for naturalization in a timely manner.[SENTMARKER]In July 2007, the DHS issued a regulation requiring that a complete FBI criminal background investigation be conducted on each applicant for citizenship.[SENTMARKER]The fee charged by USCIS for naturalization applications prior to July 2007 was not adequate to cover the costs of processing the applications, resulting in widespread delays.[SENTMARKER]In May 2007, USCIS increased the fee it charges for the processing of naturalization applications by approximately 80 percent.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered judgment dismissing the case on September 11, 2008, and the case was remanded to the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit vacated the judgment in part, and remanded the case to consider the merits of the class certification motion on January 26, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The case is now in abeyance until July 29, 2011.

gold_sents: On May 18, 2010, two organizations comprised of day laborers and/or predominately Latino immigrant workers filed a class action lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of New York under the First and Fourteenth Amendments against the Town of Oyster Bay.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU and LatinoJustice PRLDEF, sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs, claiming that the defendants, through the passage of an ordinance prohibiting the solicitation of labor from the town's streets and sidewalks, unlawfully prohibited speech related to employment and had a discriminatory animus against predominately Latino immigrant day laborers.[SENTMARKER]After defeating the defendant's partial motion for summary judgment due to lack of standing, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment was successful.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the District Court enjoined the ordinance and declared it unconstitutional as it violated the first amendment.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2017, the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's decision.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court assessed attorney fees against the defendants, and the case closed later that year.
pegasus_output_sents: This is a civil rights action about the ability of predominantly Latino, immigrant day laborers to exercise their right to solicit work on the streets and sidewalks of their towns and villages without fear of being targeted because of their race and national origin.[SENTMARKER]On May 18, 2010, two organizations of day laborers sued the Town of Oyster Bay and its Supervisor in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York, alleging that the town's law prohibiting day laborers from standing near a public right-of-way from stopping or attempting to stop vehicles for employment-related purposes violated their constitutional rights to free speech and equal protection of the laws.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2013, the district court entered a preliminary injunction on free speech grounds, and the parties agreed to leave the injunction in effect.[SENTMARKER]The parties then appealed to the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit granted the Town's motion to dismiss the case on the basis that the District Court's preliminary injunction did not violate the free speech rights of the day laborers.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On July 29, 2014, the American Immigration Council, the National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild, and the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its component agencies, Office for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL), and United States Customs and Border Protection (CBP).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought expedited processing records related to the implementation of expedited removal policies under the Immigration and Nationality Act and the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the plaintiffs' request for expedited processing and denied their fee waiver request.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and dismissed the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: Sixteen states filed this lawsuit against the federal government on September 6, 2017 in response to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) memorandum issued on Sept.[SENTMARKER]5 ending Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA).[SENTMARKER]The states sought to enjoin the federal government from carrying out portions of the DHS memorandum and from using information about DACA grantees gathered in their applications to enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]While the district court granted in part the government’s motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs obtained a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the Supreme Court held that DHS's decision to rescind DACA was subject to judicial review under the APA and that the rescission was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]Shortly thereafter, the Acting DHS Secretary issued a memorandum suspending DACA while DHS reviewed it.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint alleging that the Acting Secretary lacked the authority to issue the memorandum because he had not been lawfully appointed to his position.[SENTMARKER]The district court agreed.[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court vacated the memorandum and ordered DHS to resume processing DACA applications.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 5, 2017, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) announced that it would end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.[SENTMARKER]On September 6, 2017, a number of states and the District of Columbia filed suit against DHS in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, alleging that DHS violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by rescinding the DACA program.[SENTMARKER]The parties alleged that DHS's policy regarding the use of DACA applicants' information for immigration-enforcement purposes was arbitrary and capricious under the APA.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction, and the Fifth Circuit affirmed the district court's judgment by an equally divided vote.[SENTMARKER]In a related case, the District Court of Maryland granted partial summary judgment to the plaintiffs on their equal protection claim, finding that the rescission was inadequately explained.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]In the second case, a group of individuals and a civil rights organization challenged the government's decision to end DACA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government failed to notify certain DACA applicants of the October 5, 2017 renewal deadline.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment and denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and granted a stay pending appeal.

gold_sents: In 2018, several states filed a complaint against the Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the immigration-related conditions being placed on funding disbursed by the Department of Justice violated the Separation of Powers, the APA and the Tenth Amendment Anti-Commandeering.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, a judge granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the defendants appealed this judgment.[SENTMARKER]And later, the plaintiffs made a motion for summary judgment on the 2018 immigration-related conditions.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, a Second Circuit panel reversed the district court's order granting partial summary judgment, vacated the mandate and injunction, and remanded the case to the district court, concluding that the Attorney General was statutorily authorized to impose the challenged conditions and that the imposition of these conditions was not arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment is currently pending before the district court.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] In 2017, the State of California and the City of San Francisco sued the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, seeking declaratory and permanent injunctions enjoining the DOJ from imposing certain immigration-related conditions on the Byrne Program Criminal Justice Assistance grant funds.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied California's request for a preliminary injunction enjoining DOJ from enforcing the Section 1373 condition on the State and its subdivisions, finding that the record was insufficient at the motion to dismiss stage to 79.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court granted partial judgment to plaintiffs, enjoined the enforcement of the challenged conditions, and mandating the release of 2017 Byrne grant funds to plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties' cross motions for summary judgment were granted and the case was remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

gold_sents: In July 2020, several immigration advocacy and nonprofit organizations filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that by excluding “undocumented immigrants from: (a) the tabulation of the total population of the states; .[SENTMARKER](b) the calculation and statement of the whole number of persons in each state; and (c) the calculation and statement of the apportionment of the House of Representatives among the states” the federal government were violating the Enumeration and Apportionment clauses of the United States Constitution, Equal Protection under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, the Separation of Powers, the Census Act, and.[SENTMARKER]In August 2020, this case was consolidated with State of New York v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]For additional information, on this case, please see State of New York v. Trump.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2020, the Immigration Coalition of the United States (ICC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Commerce (D.C.), the Census Bureau, and President Donald Trump.[SENTMARKER]The ICC sought declaratory, injunctive, and/or mandamus relief in violation of the Constitution, the Census Act, and the Administrative Procedure Act. Specifically, the ICC alleged that the President's July 21, 2020 Memorandum on Excluding Illegal Aliens From the Apportionment Base Following the 2020 Census violated the Constitution and the Constitution's separation of powers.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the ICC's motion for a preliminary injunction on July 28, 2020, and the case was closed on September 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The ICC is represented by the ACLU, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), and the National Immigration Law Center.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, national, state and local chambers of commerce and other nonprofit organizations advocating for their members' business interests filed a lawsuit against the State of Oklahoma, claiming that Sections 7 and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, which impose tax penalties on businesses that don't check the work eligibility of all of their employees in a federal database and allow discharged employees to bring discrimination suits against their employers for employing unauthorized workers, were preempted by the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs a preliminary injunction on June 4, 2008, and on appeal to the Tenth Circuit the injunction was upheld except for as to the verification requirement.[SENTMARKER]On remand to the District Court, the case was stayed pending the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Whiting, which Supreme Court later held that an Arizona law requiring employers to use E-Verify was not preempted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]Pursuant to this decision, the district court entered in a judgment on December 19th, 2012, holding that Oklahoma can require persons to contract with the State to use the employment authorization system.[SENTMARKER]However, the provision creating a cause of action for discrimination against employers who terminate an authorized employee while retaining an unauthorized employee and the provision requiring businesses to verify individual independent contractors’ authorization status and creating a withholding for work performed by individual independent contractors, were both struck down.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE ||||| DATE [CONTRACTED] On February 1, 2008, the Tulsa Chamber of Commerce and the Oklahoma Hotel and Lodging Association filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Supremacy Clause.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that Section 7(b), 7(c), and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act of 2007 were preempted by federal law and thus unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that there was a conflict between the Social Security Administration laws (which forbids the use of social security numbers to verify immigration status) and those state statutes which require use of Social Security numbers for employment purposes if the employer wishes to do business with the State.[SENTMARKER]On June 4, 2008, the district court granted a preliminary injunction against enforcement of the law, but the case was appealed to the Tenth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On February 2, 2010, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties agreed to a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2008, two detainees filed a habeas petition and class action suit in the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Warden of Allegheny County Jail challenging their continued detention pursuant to immigration detainers and alleging violations of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought habeas relief and class certification.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2008, the district court (Judge David S. Cercone) denied the habeas petition as moot, dismissed the action, and denied the motion for class certification because ICE had assumed custody of both petitioners.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| CLASS [CONTRACTED] On July 23, 2008, Wilmer Urbina and Omar Romero-Villegas filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania on behalf of a group of individuals who were detained in the Allegheny County Jail without due process and based solely on an immigration detainer which does not authorize their detention.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, 2008, Judge David S. Cercone entered an order denying the class's motion for a writ of habeas corpus and dismissed the case as moot.[SENTMARKER]Judge Cercone's order was entered on July 23, 2009, and the case was closed on July 24, 2009.

gold_sents: On August 23, 2012, ICE Agents and the State of Mississippi filed claims alleging that deferred action Directive commands ICE officers to violate federal law, compels them to violate their oaths of office, violates the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA"), unconstitutionally usurps and encroaches upon the legislative powers of Congress, as defined in Article I of the United States Constitution, and violates the obligation of the executive branch to faithfully execute the law, as required by Article II, Section 3, of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2013, the Court found that ICE Agent Plaintiffs had standing to proceed, but the State of Mississippi did not.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, 2013, the Court dismissed Plaintiff's claims without prejudice for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, finding that the dispute must be governed by the Civil Service Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed the judgment of the District Court.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2012, a group of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents and deportation officers filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the State of Mississippi, challenging the constitutional and statutory validity of the DHS’s Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the program violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs’ claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, but the case made its way to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court upheld the district court's dismissal of the plaintiffs' claims, finding that the plaintiffs had not alleged a sufficient injury to satisfy the requirements of constitutional standing.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]7, 2013, 16 Indian guestworkers filed a lawsuit in E.D.Tx.[SENTMARKER]for harm suffered as a result of an allegedly fraudulent and coercive employment recruitment scheme by Defendant Signal International.[SENTMARKER]As of July 5, 2018, 20 of the 21 plaintiffs had reached a settlement with the Burnett defendants; the remaining plaintiff's claim was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as to the Signal defendants and Dewan defendants.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 17, 2015, a group of African-American workers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas against Signal International LLC, Signal International Texas, L.P., Global Resources, Inc., and J M Associates of Mississippi, LLC, alleging that they were subjected to a hostile and abusive work environment on account of their race and alienage.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), the Civil Rights Act of 1866, and the federal Occupational Health and Safety Act (OSHA) by failing to provide them with adequate housing, failing to pay them for their work, and failing to allow them to live and/or pay for accommodations in their labor camps.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the District Court and the parties agreed to a plan of settlement.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on May 4, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the plaintiffs would receive a safety bonus in addition to their regular hourly wage, and that the parties would pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement amount is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the parties' motion to transfer the case to the Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit, which approved the transfer on July 20, 2018.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2015, sixteen undocumented immigrants formerly detained in Dallas County, Texas, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Dallas County and the Dallas County Sheriff under 42 USC §1983 for violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought damages and an injunction preventing the defendants from detaining the plaintiffs solely based on a request from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), an immigration hold, or an immigration detainer.[SENTMARKER]Over time, the case was consolidated with two other lawsuits with identical claims.[SENTMARKER]The state of Texas also intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The district court initially granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but allowed the plaintiffs to file an amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The court then dismissed the plaintiffs' due process claims, allowing them to move forward only with their Fourth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]By October 18, 2018, only one plaintiff was still represented by counsel and pursuing a claim (26 had dismissed their claims with prejudice, and 18 had fallen out of contact with counsel and were designated as pro se; their claims were later dismissed).[SENTMARKER]That plaintiff reached a private settlement with the defendants and the court ordered entry of the final judgment on December 4, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was to be paid $9,500.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 7, 2019, a group of immigrants filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against Dallas County, Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Dallas County violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by refusing to grant them immediate release on bond and by detaining them based on immigration holds after they were otherwise eligible for release.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they were held in detention by Dallas County in connection with state criminal charges, while they were subject to federal immigration detainers issued by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Form I-247.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a motion for new trial in April 2015, and the case was transferred to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This suit challenges Texas's "Sanctuary City" legislation, Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the other suits in this special collection, this suit does not challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]This case was quickly consolidated with the two other before Judge Orlando L. Garcia; please refer to El Cenizo v. Texas for further information and updates.[SENTMARKER]This case was administratively closed on Oct. 24, 2017 in light of the consolidation.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 7, 2017, the Texas Organizing Project Education Fund ( TOPEF) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the State of Texas, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, and the Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief for violations of Senate Bill 4 (SB 4), also known as the "Show Me Your Papers Bill" and the "show me your papers" law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, El Paso County and Sheriff Richard Wiles, alleged that SB 4 is unconstitutionally vague and violates the Fourteenth Amendment's guarantee of the equal protection of laws and the Supremacy Clause of the First and Fourth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the plaintiffs alleged that El Paso's current policies regarding federal immigration enforcement comply with state and federal law and do not violate SB 4.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Chief Judge Orlando L. Garcia, who granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and a temporary restraining order.

gold_sents: An individual unlawfully detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act for damages.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in November 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2017, the Plaintiff filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Bexar County, and other federal defendants.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that he was unlawfully detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center (BCADC) from March 24, 2016 until June 8, 2016 without his consent, without notice of any charges, without a warrant, notice to appear in removal proceedings, or an order of removal, and in violation of law.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE is liable under the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) for falsely imprisoning the Plaintiff pursuant to a detainer request issued by the ICE San Antonio Field Office.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment in part and denied the motion for declaratory relief in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is one in a series of cases challenging comprehensive state immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]In this case, a coalition of immigrant rights groups and individual immigrants challenged Utah's law, HB 497, on preemption grounds and as a violation of equal protection, the right to travel, and the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]A preemption case brought by the Department of Justice was later consolidated with this case.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the District Court for the District of Utah has issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the statute.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Arizona, the Court ruled on the motions for preliminary injunctions in June 2014 and ruled against the key provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]In November 2014, the parties filed a joint report, in which the State of Utah agreed to permanently scrap the key problematic provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]On December 4, 2014, the Court entered a judgment per the parties' proposed final agreement and dismissed the remaining claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on attorney fees and costs and the case closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2011, the Utah Coalition of La Raza, Service Employees International Union (SEIU), and Centro Civico Mexicano filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of Utah against the State of Utah, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Governor of Utah.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's immigration enforcement law, House 4 Bill 497, violated the Supremacy Clause, the Fourth Amendment, the Right to Travel, and Section 10 of the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief and a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]On June 25, 2012, the Supreme Court of the United States ruled in Arizona v. Arizona that the federal government could not enforce immigration laws that conflict with federal law.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On November 22, 2011, the parties agreed to settle the case and the parties filed a parallel motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion, enjoining the state from enforcing the law, and enjoined the government from enforcing Section 10 and Section 11 of the federal immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 25, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a second motion to consolidate the case, which was granted on November 22, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 24, 2018, the ACLU of Vermont and Migrant Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Vermont against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DHS and DMV had violated the rights of migrant farm workers in the state by targeting and detaining them in violation of the federal immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' conduct has caused a number of Vermont-based farm owners to discourage their employees from participating in Migrant Justice activities for fear that their workers would be detained.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On July 31, 2018, two non-profit organizations and fifteen individuals filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Trump Administration's implementation of the waiver provision of the Travel Ban (Presidential Proclamation No. 9645), alleging that it violates the Administrative Procedure Act and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]After the Trump Administration concluded, President Biden revoked the Travel Ban and ordered that visa applications resume processing on January 20, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 13, 2018, a group of individuals and organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) alleging that the DHS had violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Constitution by failing to follow its own policies and procedures in implementing a waiver provision of President Trump's travel ban.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government had failed to provide notice or an opportunity to apply for a waiver, and that the waiver process was arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on the grounds that there were no agency decisions subject to review under the APA.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was sent to the district court for the Northern District of California by electronic transfer 15 days from the date of the filing of the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on August 1, 2018.

gold_sents: In March 2020, during the outbreak of COVID-19 in the Seattle area, persons critically vulnerable to the disease and held in an immigration detention facility near Seattle filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued ICE and its directors for violation of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that continued detention in the face of a potential outbreak in the detention facility would expose the plaintiffs to substantial harm and amount to punishment in violation of the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]On March 19, the court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order seeking immediate release.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied the plaintiffs' second motion for a temporary restraining order on April 8.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on April 30, which the court has not yet resolved.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2020, a group of immigration detainees filed a petition in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington, seeking a writ of habeas corpus, or injunctive relief, against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and The GEO Group, Inc., a private detention center run by ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ICE's conditions of confinement at the Tacoma Northwest Detention Center subject them to heightened risk of serious illness or death if exposed to COVID-19, for which there is no vaccine, known treatment, or cure.[SENTMARKER]The BIA dismissed the plaintiffs' appeal on December 2, 2019, and the case was dismissed on April 3, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending before the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.

gold_sents: This class-action case was brought challenging the Santa Cruz County Jail's practice of strip searching individuals held in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The case settled and was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 28, 2009, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the County of Santa Cruz, the Santa Cruz County Sheriff's Office, and the San Jose Division of the United States Department of Justice (USDC) alleging that the defendants violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments by subjecting detainees in their custody to strip and/or visual body cavity searches without reasonable suspicion that the searches would be productive of contraband or weapons.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant's policy, practice, and custom of subjecting arrestees to strip searches prior to arraignment resulted in the plaintiffs suffering actual damages as a result of being subjected to the searches.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay a maximum of $3,875,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the Court.

gold_sents: A female arrestee filed this strip search case against the Humboldt County Jail and various officials challenging the jail's mandatory, blanket strip search policy.[SENTMARKER]The court found no pattern or practice.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff refiled, naming the deputy sheriff who conducted (and videotaped) the search, and the case was settled.[SENTMARKER]We have no further information about this case.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] On September 23, 2004, a woman arrested for allegedly driving under the influence of alcohol brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Humboldt County Sheriff's Department, alleging that the defendant violated her Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by subjecting her to a strip search without reasonable suspicion that the search would be productive of contraband or weapons.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment on May 23, 2006, and the case was dismissed on June 23, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed an appeal on June 26, 2006, which was denied by the Ninth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: On April 16, 2007, Plaintiff, represented by private attorney Mark E. Merin, filed a 42 U.S.C. § 1983 class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California challenging the Solano County Sheriff's policies and practices concerning the use of strip and visual body cavity searches in Solano County Jail.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged that such searches, conducted in the absence of any reasonable suspicion of contraband or weapons, violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]In September 2009, two years after the defendants revised their search policies to comply with federal law, the parties settled with the defendant paying $110,000 in damages and $100,000 in attorney fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 1, 2008, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the Solano County Sheriff's Office and Solano County Jail, alleging that the defendants' policy of subjecting pre-arraignm detainees to strip and/or visual body cavity searches before arraignment violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the searches would be productive of contraband or weapons, and that defendants had a policy of conducting the searches in the presence of persons who were not participating in the searches.[SENTMARKER]The class sought injunctive and class relief, injunctive relief, and attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 28, 2009, and the parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay each of the plaintiffs $12,500 in return for the dismissal of the claims.

gold_sents: In 2011, several inmates of the Fresno County Adult Detention Facilities filed a lawsuit against the County of Fresno, California, alleging that it violated prisoners' Constitutional rights by maintaining dangerous facilities and failing to provide basic health care.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties settled the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to implement a remedial plan and to pay $900,000 in attorneys' fees and $40,000 per year for monitoring fees and expenses.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 2011, two prisoners in the Fresno County Jail filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California alleging that the conditions of confinement in the jail violated the constitutional and statutory rights of all prisoners who were or will be incarcerated there.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to provide timely access to health care and that the jail did not provide prisoners with any services to ensure that their health care was not disrupted.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by the Court in May 2015.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to provide all prisoners with access to timely health care.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay plaintiffs' counsel $40,000 per calendar year, or a pro-rated portion thereof, for all fees and expenses related to monitoring the implementation of the consent decree and the consent plan.[SENTMARKER]The court also approved a settlement agreement that required the defendant to pay the plaintiffs $40,000.00 per year for the interests of their class, and to retain the Prison Law Office as class counsel.

gold_sents: This is a class action suit brought in 1993 by prisoners at the Merced County Jail to challenge their conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The District Court for the Eastern District of California issued some initial injunctive relief to prevent overcrowding, and a settlement was preliminarily approved but seemingly never finalized.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in 2000.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 4, 1993, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the Merced County Sheriff's Office and the County of Merced on behalf of all inmates of the County's jail system.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail system violated the civil rights of inmates by not allowing them to sleep on the floor and by failing to provide them with adequate beds.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the Sheriff to release inmates from the jail whenever the county jail system, or any specific housing unit therein, is filled, and to refuse to accept newly-committed inmates whenever all beds in the Main Jail are filled.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to post a copy of the settlement agreement on every floor level of the jail facility and that the inmates of said institution have access to the postings.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on August 5, 2000 and the case was re-opened on October 2, 2000.

gold_sents: This 2011 lawsuit alleged that Alameda County had violated the decedent's constitutional rights in its agents' use of excessive force.[SENTMARKER]The suit further alleged that Corizon Health, Inc. was negligent in its failure to provide decedent with treatment for alcohol withdrawal.[SENTMARKER]In February, 2015, the parties settled for $8,300,000 in damages and injunctive relief that included health training.[SENTMARKER]The injunctive relief is set to end February 1, 2019, and little activity had appeared on the docket since 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: This is a civil rights wrongful death/survival action arising under Title 42 of the 7 U.S. Code, Sections 1983 and 1988, and the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, a pretrial detainee in the Alameda County Sheriff's Department, alleged that the defendant, Corizon Health, Inc., violated his civil rights by denying him access to appropriate, competent, and necessary care for serious medical and psychiatric needs.[SENTMARKER]The defendant moved for summary judgment on all of the plaintiff's claims.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendant's motion for partial summary judgment, and the case was transferred to the district court.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 5, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: The defendant agreed to provide all inmates in the county jails with adequate medical and mental health care.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay $20,000 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, prisoners in the Santa Clara County Jail System filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the jail facilities were not accessible to inmates with mobility disabilities in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and state law.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the parties jointly settled the case under a consent decree which would force Santa Clara County to make its jails accessible.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing
pegasus_output_sents: On November 14, 2016, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of inmates with mobility disabilities incarcerated in Santa Clara County's Main Jail North, Main Jail South, and Elmwood Correctional Facility (collectively, the "Jails").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Jails violated the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA") and the Rehabilitation Act ("Rehabilitation Act") by failing to provide accessible facilities, programs, services, and activities to inmates with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree (the "Conviction Decree"), which was approved by the Court on November 14, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the County to: (1) provide a safe and secure shower chair in lieu of a bench in the X-ray changing room; .[SENTMARKER](2) provide a chair for an inmate with a mobility disability in the jails; .[SENTMARKER](3) provide access to religious programming; .[SENTMARKER](4) provide accessible transportation to inmates; and (5) provide an accessible shower chair.[SENTMARKER]The Court has preliminarily approved the consent decree, which is subject to court approval.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 1, 2018, three pretrial detainees filed a civil rights class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Alameda County Sheriff's Office and the Santa Rita Jail in Dublin, California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by depriving them of a minimal level of night time sleep.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 2019, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $75,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to the court's approval.

gold_sents: On November 11, 2019 prisoners at Santa Rita Jail in Dublin, California filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Alameda County Sheriff’s Office, the California Forensic Medical Group and Aramark Correctional Services under 42 U.S.C. § 1981, 1983, and 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that defendants acted in violation of the First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, plaintiffs alleged that Santa Rita’s unsanitary confinement conditions, wrongful denials of attorney visits, failure to provide medical care, and retaliation against inmates for speaking out and filing grievances violated these constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 30, 2019, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Alameda County Sheriff's Office and the Santa Rita Jail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution by failing to provide adequate outdoor recreation, inadequate medical care, unsanitary conditions of confinement, and requiring inmates to provide the medical care for newly booked, detoxing detainees.[SENTMARKER]The class was made up of all male inmates incarcerated at Santa Rita jail, who were either kitchen workers, or who received a disciplinary citation, and who were unable to tolerate the conditions of their confinement.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, for the first time ever, inmates began a hunger strike against the jail, refusing to go to Court, refuse to eat the Jail’s food, and refuse to perform work.[SENTMARKER]The jail does not provide soap in the bathrooms.[SENTMARKER]In addition, these problems are exacerbated by the jail’s policy of not providing soap for inmates in the 23 bathrooms.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the cost provisions of ACSO’s contract with For Profit CFMG, medical care provided 2 to SRJ inmates at SRJ is grossly inadequate.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the class's motion for class certification and ordered the defendants to pay the class attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
