pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Alameda County Sheriff's Office, the California Forensic Medical Group, and Aramark Correctional Services, LLC.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution by mistreating women prisoners at the Santa Rita Jail in Santa Rita, California.[SENTMARKER]According to the plaintiffs, the defendants' treatment of women prisoners resulted in two recent miscarriages, and a third woman giving birth, alone and 4 unattended, in a solitary confinement cell.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the plaintiffs the same educational classes and opportunities available to male prisoners, and denied them the use of a breast pump.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the parties settled the case on June 25, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to a permanent injunction against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $75,000.

gold_sents: This putative class-action lawsuit, brought by inmates in Orange County Jail, argued that county and the sheriff violated the U.S. Constitution, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act in failing to provide adequate care amidst the 2020 coronavirus pandemic.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought habeas corpus, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted class certification and partially granted a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction, which mandated more social distancing, providing for more PPE, and improved sanitation policies.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed this decision to the Ninth Circuit, and applied in both the district court and the Ninth Circuit to stay the case in the lower court until the appeals court had ruled.[SENTMARKER]Both denied these applications, however the Ninth Circuit remanded to the district court saying that the defendants could try to modify the injunction if there were any changed circumstances.[SENTMARKER]Defendants did so, but the district court denied any modifications once again.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed this decision to the Ninth Circuit, which likewise rejected the defendants' motion.[SENTMARKER]Finally, the defendants went to the Supreme Court and asked them to stay the injunction while the Ninth Circuit heard the case on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court obliged on August 5, staying the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of February 17, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2020, a group of inmates at the Orange County Jail filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California, alleging that the conditions of confinement at the jail violated their constitutional and other statutor rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to take adequate measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 within the jail.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on May 26, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On June 2, 2020, the defendants filed an appeal with the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit granted the defendants' motion to stay the case pending an appeal.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed an emergency motion to dissolve the district court's preliminary injunction order in light of the evidence of changed circumstances they presented in support of the emergency motion.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the request for a writ of certiorari, and the parties filed re: Notice of Appeal to implement protections against COVID.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion for an emergency stay of the injunction and a stay of entry of the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, 2020, the court issued an injunction against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2013, a class action lawsuit was brought in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia by a group of former inmates who alleged that the District's Department of Corrections (D.O.C.)[SENTMARKER]had a practice of overdetaining and strip searching inmates past their release dates.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' and class members' due process rights were violated for the period September 1, 2005 to December 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The District says that the DOC began videotaping strip searches in April 2008, i n response to a complaint from a trans-gender inmate.[SENTMARKER]The District will pay up to $250,000 for each class member who qualifies as an Overdetention Class Member a sum of $370.00 for the first calendar day, plus $250 per day for each calendar day for which they were supposed to be released, or subjected to a strip search after they had been to court appearance and were entitled to release because of their appearance.[SENTMARKER]The district will also pay a third-party reviewer up to $75,000 to review all claims made by the named plaintiffs and the defendant.[SENTMARKER]The case is still pending.

pegasus_output_sents: In 2002, a class of women arrested in the District of Columbia were taken to the Superior Court for presentment on D.C. warrants or code offenses and were subjected to blanket strip, visual body cavity, and/or squat searches while being held in the cell block awaiting presentment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief and monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied both motions and certified two classes: a Fourth Amendment Class and a Fifth Amendment Class.[SENTMARKER]The parties spent the time between April 2003 and April 2006 attempting to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the District's motion for summary judgment and dismissed the District as a party in this case.[SENTMARKER]After the parties filed briefs in this matter, the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit dismissed the case for lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 4, 2009, two inmates of the Manatee County Jail, Florida, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida, alleging that the jail's Postcard-Only Mail Policy violated their First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the policy limited the ability of family members and friends of inmates to fully express the messages they wish to convey by drastically limiting the amount of space available on which to place a message, which for many friends and family members is the only available method to communicate with the inmate.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice, stating that the plaintiffs were purporting to bring the case for themselves and all others similarly situated.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, pending a decision on whether the case is moot.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 1999, a group of HIV-positive inmates at the Fulton County Jail in Atlanta, Georgia filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by failing to provide constitutionally adequate medical care to the inmates.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, Fulton County, and Correctional Healthcare Solutions, Inc. ("CHS"), a private correctional medical care company, agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide all necessary medical care, including HIV-related care, to all inmates in the jail.[SENTMARKER]According to the settlement agreement, the defendants were required to provide adequate nutrition and dietary supplements for many of the inmates, and to provide medical appointments for all inmates with HIV.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendants to monitor the quality of healthcare services provided at the jail and to ensure that the jail was not overcrowded.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on April 16, 1999, and the parties submitted for the Court's approval and entered a consent order on April 22, 1999.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 2002, the parties filed their response to the consent order, which was approved and entered into by Judge Marvin H. Shoob.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the court would retain jurisdiction to enforce the terms of this settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]On May 6, 2002, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered on May 10, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion to dismiss the case, and the case was closed on May 12, 2002.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 27, 2009, a former inmate at the Cook County Jail brought a class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois alleging that the defendants showed deliberate indifference in its administration of dental care.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary and permanent injunction against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to decertify the class, and the district court granted a motion for summary judgment in favor of the defendants in that case.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to provide dental care to all detainees at the jail.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to implement the terms of the settlement.

gold_sents: In June 2014, an inmate at the Cook County Jail filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Cook County.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and costs, alleging overcrowding and lack of funding that led to violations of Indiana state law and the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case based on counsel's representation that the alleged counts were unsupported.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2014, a pre-trial detainee at Cook County Jail filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois alleging that he was subject to barbaric living conditions in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that he and other similarly situated pretrial detainees were forced to sleep in the common area of a cell block which was under construction without any mattress, pillows, or blankets, was moved after two hours’ sleep to a day room where he again was required to sleep on the floor, and was frequently moved thereafter to various holding areas over several days, at least one of which did not have access to a bathroom, forcing Plaintiff to urinate on himself.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff further alleged that as a result of the policy and custom of instituting and allowing cruel and unusual conditions of confinement at the Jail, pretrial detainees have been subjected to barbaric and unusual living conditions.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Defendants' motion to dismiss on the grounds that they were improper defendants; .<n>Plaintiff did not allege that Defendants’ operation of the Jail was unconstitutional, he alleges that the Defendants’ underfunding of the jail is unconstitutional; and, the Court denied the motion for leave to file an amended complaint on this ground.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on October 15, 2015.

gold_sents: In 2014, individuals who were incarcerated in the Marion County correctional system filed this class-action lawsuit in the US District Court for the Southern District of Indiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Marion County sheriff under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought monetary relief pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Marion County Sheriffs Office.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that they were incarcerated for longer than legally authorized as a result of unreasonable processing and release procedures.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] In December 2014, a class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the Marion County Sheriff's Department and the City of Indianapolis.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the sheriff's practice of not releasing inmates at the conclusion of their sentences, but rather keeping them in jail until Community Corrections is "ready" to process them as a group, is unreasonable and results in substantial delays in the release of these individuals.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied certification of the class because it held that the class was not "identifiable," but the district court granted certification as to two of those subclasses but denied it as to the remaining three.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Indiana Supreme Court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Indiana Court of Appeals granted the defendants' motion to transfer the case to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case for a hearing on the issue of class certification.

gold_sents: Built in 1991, the Campbell County Detention Center was designed to hold 135 prisoners.[SENTMARKER]It quickly became overcrowded.[SENTMARKER]In the weeks before this lawsuit was filed in the district court for the Eastern District of Kentucky, on April 29, 2005, the jail's population reached a high of 276 prisoners, many of whom were forced to sleep on the floor.[SENTMARKER]Many of the inmates were awaiting transfer to the Kentucky Department of Corrections (KDOC), which was also named as a defendant in the lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]The KDOC addressed overcrowding at the jail by simply reducing the required floor space for each prisoner from 50 to 40 square feet.[SENTMARKER]This lawsuit, filed pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1983 by attorney Robert B. Newman of the Cincinnati, Ohio, law firm Newman & Meeks, alleged the overcrowding violated the prisoners' Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, the class of inmates at the detention center, sought injunctive relief and nominal damages.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2005, several inmates at the Campbell County Detention Center in Newport, Kentucky, filed a federal lawsuit against Campbell County, Campbell County Jailer Greg Buckler, and the Kentucky Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the detention center was overcrowded and that such overcrowding caused unconstitutional conditions of confinement to exist at the Detention Center.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was certified as a class action, which means that it has been brought on behalf of all persons currently incarcerated at the jail and all persons who will in the future be incarcerated there.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was signed by Judge William Ovington of the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky on November 30, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a process for and implement a Retrial Conditional Release Program, and to work with the Pretrial Services Division of the Administrative Office of the Courts in order to develop a protocol for the medical treatment of convicted felons housed in their facilities.[SENTMARKER]As part of their participation in the agreement, the parties also agreed to submit a proposed consent decree on or before 11/30/2005.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In April 2020, pretrial and post-conviction detainees at Prince George's County Jail filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that in light of COVID-19, they were being held in conditions that violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]A subclass of pretrial, medically vulnerable plaintiffs also alleged that they are being held in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, the court granted in part the plaintiff's motion for temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]Defendant appealed and were denied a stay pending their appeal.[SENTMARKER]On July 7, the plaintiffs submitted an amended complaint, pointing to the lack of mental health services during an indefinite lockdown.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion to stay proceedings on August 27 pending settlement talks.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 21, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Prince George's County Department of Corrections (PGCDOC) and Mary Lou McDonough, the Director of the PGCDOC.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail's inadequate response to the COVID-19 pandemic violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought injunctive relief to address the Jail's conditions of confinement, including the confinement of COVID-positive prisoners who have paid bail until it deems them non-contagious.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the parties entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the jail to: Limit the number of operational entrances and exits to the facility; provide adequate medical monitoring of sick prisoners in isolation; limit the use of solitary confinement; and provide access to health care among participants in the New Haven Syringe Services Program (SA-15).[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case as moot because the plaintiffs failed to exhaust the administrative grievance procedures available to them through the grievance process.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 2003, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey on behalf of individuals arrested in the City of Camden, New Jersey, who were strip searched by corrections officers at the Camden County Correctional Facility.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Constitution by strip searching all individuals charged with non-indictable or minor offenses upon their entry into the correctional facility.[SENTMARKER]The defendants maintain that their current written policy is constitutional, and has been reviewed by the New Jersey Department of Corrections for compliance with state law.[SENTMARKER]The proposed settlement does not include individuals who were charged with indictable offenses at the time of their admission to the prison, or who were not strip searched when they entered the prison.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also addresses the alleged practice of Camden County in unlawfully detaining many members of the settlement class after they posted bail in the city.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to pay $7,500,000 to resolve this litigation, after payment of administrative costs, incentive awards to the representative plaintiffs, and attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: In March of 2002, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice, acting pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA"), 42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq., commenced an investigation into the conditions of confinement at the Santa Fe County Adult Detention Center in Santa Fe, New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ concluded that the conditions and practices at the Detention Center violated the constitutional rights of convicted inmates and pre-trial detainees.[SENTMARKER]On November 11, 2004, the DOJ and Sante Fe County entered into a Memorandum of Agreement, which detailed the agreed reforms and set forth timetables for completion.[SENTMARKER]By its terms, the Agreement was to last for a period of three years, and remedy unconstitutional practices relating to: (1) medical and mental health care; .[SENTMARKER](2) suicide prevention; .[SENTMARKER](3) protection of inmates from harm; .[SENTMARKER](4) fire safety; .[SENTMARKER](5) sanitation; and (6) inmate grievance procedures (including court access).[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2009, after a two year extension to compel Santa Fe County to meet the benchmarks in the agreement, the DOJ allowed the terms of the agreement to expire.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ is no longer monitoring the county.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2002, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico against Santa Fe County, the Santa Fe Adult Detention Center, and the County Board of County Commissioners.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the detention center failed to provide a medically appropriate diet for inmates with conditions that require the inmates to receive special diets, inadequate prenatal care for pregnant inmates, and inadequate treatment, housing, and medical supervision for drug and alcohol withdrawal.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the District Court on November 1, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following conditions: The detention center must provide appropriate treatment for drug withdrawal, appropriate housing, medical supervision, and treatment for the identification, treatment, and control of Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA) at the Detention Center.[SENTMARKER]The plan shall include provisions for the treatment and treatment of pregnant women as medically indicated, including discharge planning.[SENTMARKER]The County shall implement timely and appropriate care for all inmates, including those confined to SFCADC.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

After two years of settlement talks, the parties reached a settlement agreement..
pegasus_output_sents: This is a class action brought on behalf of people with mental disabilities arrested and detained in the Doa Ana County Detention Center (DACDC) to redress violations of their rights by the DACDC and the Las Cruces Police Department (L.C.PD) of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the New Mexico Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide adequate mental health services to individuals with disabilities in the detention center.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also allegedly failed to transport these individuals to appropriate community-based services or divert them from the criminal justice system.[SENTMARKER]The District Court for the Third Judicial District of New Mexico granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and the case was transferred to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on January 15, 2010.

gold_sents: This case was brought by a woman who was arested, subjected to excessive force and a strip/cavity search all on the basis of a false complaint filed by a family member.[SENTMARKER]A jury awarded her $19,645 in compensatory damages and $5,000,000 in punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed the punitive damages award as not available against municipalities, and reduced the compensatory damages award because Plaintiff had been offered slightly more as settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought under 42 U.S.C.  1983 against the City of New York, the NYPD, and the individual officers involved in her arrest and strip search.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that she had been falsely arrested, that the police had employed excessive force during the arrest, and that her strip search violated her Fourth Amendment right against unreasonable search and seizure.[SENTMARKER]The jury found in favor of the defendants on the claims of unlawful arrest, excessive force, and battery, and awarded her $5,000,000 in punitive damages, as well as $19,645 in compensatory damages.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case, but the Supreme Court reversed the district court's decision on the issue of punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the City appealed to the Second Circuit, which denied the City's motion for writ of certiorari.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2009, former inmates at the Delaware County Jail filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Sheriff's Office of Delaware County was guilty of rape, sodomy, sexual battery, and blackmail.[SENTMARKER]The alleged negligence and misconduct of jailers deprived inmates of their the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments Rights.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in 2011 for monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in May 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: This complaint was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma on December 1, 2011 on behalf of several female inmates of the Delaware County, Oklahoma jail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jailers would "bargain" with the female inmates to show their breasts in exchange for cigarettes, cupcakes, snacks, candy, personal items, and other things they could not obtain for themselves while in the jail.[SENTMARKER]In response to the retaliation, the women who came forward with the complaints wrote a letter, which they all signed, begging for help from the outside.[SENTMARKER]The letter resulted in an investigation by the Sheriff and the Sheriff determined that the women were not being discriminated against.[SENTMARKER]The women filed a motion for summary judgment, which was granted by Judge James H. Payne.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]Judge Payne entered a final judgment in favor of the Sheriff on January 29, 2009.

gold_sents:
On April 21, 2005, a woman filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]She alleged that the City of Philadelphia of had an unconstitutional practice of strip searching all pre-trial detainees, regardless of criminal charge or reasonable suspicion.[SENTMARKER]On February 20, 2009, the parties entered into a $5.9 million settlement.[SENTMARKER]
The Court entered final approval of the settlement on November 3, 2009.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2006, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the Philadelphia Prison System and the City of Philadelphia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant's policy of strip-searching all pretrial detainees upon admission to the prison system was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay $5,900,000 to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on February 20, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The settlement requires that all correction officers have access to the strip search policy.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2007, the plaintiff filed suit against the County of Lancaster and the Lancaster County Prison Board in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that his constitutional rights were violated when he was strip searched in front of other inmates upon arrival at the Lancaster County Prison after being arrested for a parole violation.[SENTMARKER]He sought class action certification, declaratory judgment, a preliminary and permanent injunction, and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement with the court on July 29, 2009 that affirmed a new policy of not strip searching detainees arrested for minor offenses and created a fund to compensate those who had been strip searched.[SENTMARKER]The case ended on April 9, 2010 when the court certified the class and granted final approval to the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2007, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the County of Lancaster and the Lancaster County Prison Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fourth Amendment by conducting strip searches of all individuals who enter the county prison and are placed in prison clothing, regardless of the nature of their charged crime or violation, and without the presence of reasonable suspicion to believe that the individual was concealing a weapon or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on July 28, 2009, which provided for a $2,507,200 settlement fund, with an initial contribution of $1,946,860, and required the defendants to retrain their Corrections Officers to ensure compliance with the new strip search policy.[SENTMARKER]On September 1, 2009, Judge Paul Diamond granted the parties' motion for preliminary approval of the settlement and conditionally certified the class.[SENTMARKER]On November 11, 2007, the parties filed a motion for class certification, which was approved by Judge Diamond and the parties agreed to suspend litigation while the parties engaged in settlement discussions.[SENTMARKER]On March 23, 2009, Judge Diamond approved the settlement agreement, and it was entered into into effect on April 6, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed an amended motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, seeking to change the policies and procedures of the county and the prison board, and for the payment of attorney's fees and costs.

gold_sents: Plaintiff, a county jail inmate who suffered scarring and isolation from multiple MRSA infections was successful in obtaining a settlement against county defendants for their alleged failure to implement appropriate quarantine protocols and correct medical care, and for maintaining unsanitary conditions at the jail.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 19, 2009, an inmate at the Northampton County Prison in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania filed this civil rights lawsuit against the county and its private contractor, Prime Care Medical, Inc., in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his Eighth Amendment rights under the Civil Rights Act of 1866, as amended, 42 U.S.C.  1983 by failing to provide him with adequate medical care and failing to adequately treat him for his medical needs and well-being.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants failed to provide sufficient antibacterial soap for plaintiffs personal use, preventing him from properly cleaning himself to prevent contracting diseases such as MRSA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also failed to generate, maintain, and/or preserve accurate medical records.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that they had not violated the plaintiff's constitutional rights.

gold_sents: This class action case was brought by prisoners of the Dauphin County Prison against the County of Dauphin, PA, seeking monetary, declaratory, and injunctive relief for conducting unconstitutional and unnecessary strip searches upon all persons placed in the Dauphin County Prison, as of September 16, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in 2009, resulting in monetary and injunctive relief granted.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 2007, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the County of Dauphin and the Dauphin County Prison.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants strip-searched all individuals who were charged with misdemeanor offenses, violations of probation or parole or intermediate punishment, or other minor offenses upon their admission to the County Prison, in violation of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay $2,160,500 to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 26, 2009, which was approved by Judge Thomas I. Vanaskie on March 12, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The settlement fund will be used to pay for the claims of the class members, the administrative costs of the settlement, an incentive award to the named plaintiffs, and the attorneys' fees and expenses.

gold_sents: The ACLU of Pennsylvania filed this class action suit on behalf of pretrial detainees in a PA jail with subclasses of those who were at a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the conditions in the jail failed to meet CDC recommendations and amounted to a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on April 9, 2020 seeking immediate release from ACJ.[SENTMARKER]The parties then began working on a consent order to implement public health measures to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 in the jail, which was approved by the court on May 27.[SENTMARKER]The consent order was extended on August 24 and the plaintiffs habeas and ADA claims remain in dispute.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2020, three individuals held at the Allegheny County Jail in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their rights under 42 U.C.[SENTMARKER]1983 and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to protect them from constitutionally deficient conditions that place them at a substantial risk of severe injury or death from COVID-19 while at the jail.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement in March 2020 to implement measures to protect inmates and employees from the virus.[SENTMARKER]On April 7, 2020, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief and granted their motion for release from ICE detention.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on April 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to implement the following measures:  Stricter intake testing policies with a significant reduction in the number of inmates who test positive for the virus;  Special precautions shall be taken with females who are pregnant.[SENTMARKER]The defendants have not implemented social distancing practices at ACJ.

gold_sents: On October 6, 2010, the Prison Legal News filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for South Carolina under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Berkeley County.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel, asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as damages, claiming that the defendants' unlawfully censored and excluded the plaintiff's books and magazines protected by the 1st and 14th Amendments, which are sent to individual subscribers in custody at the Berkeley County Detention Center (BCDC).[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2011, the United States filed a Complaint in intervention pursuant to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act, 42 U.S.C. § 14141, and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized 42 Persons Act of 2000, U.S.C. § 2000cc.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2012, Judge Sol Blatt, Jr., issued the consent injunction requiring the defendants to implement new policies regarding incoming mail and access to religious materials.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2018, the Human Rights Defense Center and Prison Legal News filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina against the Berkeley County Sheriff's Office and the Sheriffs Office for violating the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Act of 1994 (RLUIPA) by denying inmates access to books, magazines, and other expressive material.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought injunctive and declaratory relief for the detention center's policy of prohibiting all publications sent by mail to detainees, as well as access to non-Christian religious texts.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment, and the parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed to allow detainees to receive books and magazines in the mail.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: This 2017 class action lawsuit was brought by a former inmate of the Davidson County Jail in the U.S. District for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments in failing to prevent the spread of scabies in the prison.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff has not yet filed a motion to certify class.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2017, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee on behalf of inmates housed at the Metro-Davidson County Detention Facility in Nashville, Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to adequately screen those entering its facility, respond to inmate requests for medical attention, treat those infested with the parasite, quarantine the infected individuals in its care, or to take any other precautions to prevent the spread of scabies outside the facility.[SENTMARKER]The class was made up of all male inmates exposed to and infested with Sarcoptes scabiei (hereafter "Scabies"), who were housed in the Defendant's 1,300-bed jail facility in Nashville.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff and other inmates were forced to endure painful, itching rashes and sleeplessness while in the custody of the state.[SENTMARKER]The defendants retaliated against other inmates, including inmate J.N., for requesting medical treatment.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant failed and refused to train its employees upon the proper methods and means to detect, prevent, and treat scabies within its facility.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the defendants' actions, the Plaintiff and the class members were deprived of fundamental rights guaranteed by the United States Constitution, including the right to adequate medical care for their serious medical needs while in custody.[SENTMARKER]The District Court entered a final judgment in favor of the Plaintiff, and the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs over $1 million in damages.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: A deaf prisoner of the El Paso County jails sued the County in the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas for their failure to accommodate his disability.[SENTMARKER]He was held for eleven days without access to an attorney or an interpreter, in violation of the Americans With disabilities Act ans Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. A private settlement was reached in July 2012 which, according to reports, required installation of videophones in the County jails.[SENTMARKER]We have no further information about this case.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE ||| CIVIL ||| ORG||| DATE [CONTRACTED] On January 9, 2012, a deaf man filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the County of El Paso, Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, Jose Luis Rodriguez, was in custody awaiting trial on a criminal charge.[SENTMARKER]The defendant, El Paso County, failed to provide him with reasonable accommodations during his arraignment and subjected him to discrimination in the provision of services, programs, and activities on the basis of his disability.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for injunctive and declaratory relief and ordered the defendant to pay his attorney's fees, costs, litigation expenses, and damages.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 15, 2012, a group of juvenile prisoners filed a lawsuit in the Middle District of Florida against the Polk County Jail, claiming violations of their physical and medical care.[SENTMARKER]Preliminary injunction was denied.[SENTMARKER]Class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]A bench trial was held on from November 18, 2013 to December 18, 2013.[SENTMARKER]On April 16, 2015, Judge Merryday issued an opinion denying relief to the plaintiffs, holding that plaintiffs failed to show defendants' violations of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: The Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Polk County Sheriff's Office, the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice, and Corizon Health, Inc., a health care provider retained by the Sheriff.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Eighth Amendment rights under the Fourteenth Amendment by denying them access to food, medical care, education, recreation, and communication with their families.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment for the Sheriff but denied the officers' claim of qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court reversed the Fifth Circuit and addressed the question whether an application of excessive force can result in an Eighth Amendment violation "if the inmate does not suffer serious injury."[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Three minors represented by the Southern Poverty Law Center, Florida Justice Institute, Inc., and Florida Legal Services, filed suit on September 4, 2019 in the Northern District of Florida against the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought class action certification to represent children subject to solitary confinement in DJJ-run detention centers.[SENTMARKER]The defendant's summary judgment motion on the merits was denied on December 6, 2019, and the case is in ongoing mediation talks.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 24, 2018, the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ) was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida for violating the rights of children in solitary confinement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DJJ was subjecting children diagnosed with serious mental illness, trauma, learning disabilities, intellectual disabilities, and who had engaged in acts of self-injury or attempted suicide to a risk of harm by placing them in punitive isolation in dangerous conditions.[SENTMARKER]They sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring DJJ to cease the challenged unlawful policies and practices, including the use of solitary confinement in Secure Detention where children are isolated from others in a locked cell with no meaningful social interaction, environmental stimulation, outdoor recreation, schooling, or property.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the DJJ.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: DOJ's investigation of the conditions at the Hawaii Youth Correctional Facility ("HYCF") in August 2004 concluded that the facility lacked policies to protect the detained youth from abuse or suicide risks.[SENTMARKER]DOJ recommended reforms at the HYCF through a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) that was executed by the parties.[SENTMARKER]This case was brought to retain jurisdiction of the district court of Hawaii's jurisdiction over the case until a final order is entered to dismiss the case with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 16, 2004, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Hawai'i filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Hawaii against the State of Hawaii, the Department of Human Services, and the Hawaii Department of Education.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Hawaii Youth Correctional Facility (HYCF) in Kailua, Hawaii violated the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), the pattern or practice provision of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994, and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1974 by failing to provide access to medical and mental health care, adequate special education instruction, and supervision for youth in the facility.[SENTMARKER]On February 9, 2006, the parties entered a memorandum of agreement, which was approved by the Judge Samuel P. King of the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the terms of the agreement were not subject to State or federal court enforcement other than the reinstatement of the complaint that this Agreement settled, and that the DOJ would have the right to conduct unannounced visits to the facilities, provided that the Special Litigation Section would notify the State in the event that it accessed youth or records at the facility, and would have no remedy or action available for the State's alleged breach of this Agreement other than to reinstate the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on February 9, 2006.

gold_sents: The Attorney General filed suit against the state of Ohio, its governor, the director of youth services, and the superintendents of its juvenile correctional facilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141 for an alleged pattern or practice of violating the rights of juvenile detainees under the 14th Amendment, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The United States alleged that Ohio failed to protect the youth at its facilities from harm and undue risk of harm, failed to meet their medical and mental health needs, and failed to provide adequate special education services.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed as a result of Department of Justice (DOJ) investigations into the conditions of confinement at the Scioto and Marion centers that began in 2005.[SENTMARKER]The Marion facility closed soon after the first injunction in this case.[SENTMARKER]Ohio achieved substantial compliance in 2015, and the consent decree was terminated on December 3, 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2005, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) notified the State of Ohio of its intent to investigate conditions of confinement at the Scioto Juvenile Correctional Facility (Scioto) in Delaware, Ohio, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C.  1997, and the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994.42 U.N.C  14141.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, the Cohen Report addressed issues regarding protection from harm, medical care, mental health care, and special education at Scioto.[SENTMARKER]On June 4, 2008, the Departments of Justice and Ohio signed a stipulation for injunctive relief (the Stipulation) concerning conditions at both Scioto and the Marion juvenile correctional facility.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement on the resolution of the plaintiffs’ claims, which the Court approved on March 29, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties also entered into a consent decree with the State to remedy conditions at all DYS facilities.[SENTMARKER]On December 19, 2012, the parties filed a motion for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the State's motion, and the parties agreed to withdraw the consent decree without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On March 29, 2011, the parties entered a final judgment in favor of the State.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment found that Scioto's medical quality improvement program, environmental conditions, and management of special dietary needs for youth are appropriate.

gold_sents: The juvenile plaintiff brought suit against the Minnehaha County Juvenile Detention Center, challenging the center's policy of strip-searching all juveniles admitted to the Detention Center, without any reasonable suspicion that the juveniles were concealing weapons or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit overturned the District Court's ruling, holding that the search of the named plaintiff did not violate the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the parties reached a monetary settlement before having to relitigate the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 1, 2000, a former juvenile detainee filed this civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Dakota against the Minnehaha County Juvenile Detention Center in Sioux Falls, South Dakota.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that her civil rights were violated by the detention center's policy of strip searches of all minors regardless of the type of offense they were arrested for or whether there was reason to believe that the minors had weapons or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The district court certified two classes of plaintiffs, one for injunctive relief and one for punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2004, the district court granted partial summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Eighth Circuit, which remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with its August 9, 2006 opinion in NG v. Connecticut, 382 F.3d 225 (2d Cir.[SENTMARKER]2004), which held that the JDC's written search policy in effect in August 1999 was unconstitutional and that the subsequent changes to the policy did not cure the constitutional defects.[SENTMARKER]On February 4, 2009, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the terms of the settlement agreement, which included the following: (i) no strip searches, (ii) no questions about the religious beliefs of the detainees, (iii) no use of force, (iv) no searches without probable cause, (v) no search warrants, (vi) no detention time limits, (vii) no civil penalties, (viii) no monetary damages, and (ix) no time limits.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This suit was filed May 7, 2004.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs were individuals who had been involuntarily civilly confined pursuant to Sexually Violent Predator Act into the custody of the Florida Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Children and Families in the Florida Civil Commitment Center (FCCC).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs argued that the State failed to provide adequate rehabilitive treatment necessary for their eventual recovery and release.[SENTMARKER]In November 2009, after five years of discovery and motions practice, the case settled, with the State agreeing to implement policies that addressed all the plaintiffs' allegations.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2004, a group of sex offenders who were civilly detained at the Florida Civil Commitment Center (FCCC) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Florida Department of Children and Families (DCFII) and Liberty Behavioral Healthcare Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their constitutional rights by failing to provide adequate treatment, mental health services, and on-site medical services to the residents confined at FCCC.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the plaintiffs would be permitted to have a total of three experts and five attorneys (three attorneys to accompany the experts and two attorney to review records) to conduct a four-day inspection of the facility.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the motion for approval of a class-action settlement and dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In June 2009, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case, which was approved by the district court.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice and the parties agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On February 27, 2002, four individuals involuntarily detained by the Illinois Department of Human Services ("DHS") pursuant to the Sexually Violent Persons Commitment Act (“SVP Act”) on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for Northern Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants failed to provide adequate and meaningful health treatment to the plaintiffs and those similarly situated and the treatment and care that was given was punitive and Constitutionally inadequate.[SENTMARKER]In 2005, Judge Leinenweber granted the plaintiffs’ demand for declaratory relief concerning the previous Special or Secure Management Status (“SMS”) used at the Joliet Treatment and Detention Facility (the “TDF”) stating that it was unconstitutional; however all of the plaintiffs’ remaining claims were denied including the claim of inadequate treatment.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2003, a group of individuals who had been civilly committed under the Illinois Sexually Violent Persons Commitment Act, 725 ILCS 207/1et seq, filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Illinois Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their civil rights by imposing impermissibly punitive conditions of confinement and the constitutionally inadequate treatment they receive as detainees at the Joliet Treatment and Detention Facility in Joliet, Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice and without costs with leave to move to reinstate on or before October 13, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $0.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]14, 2014, a number of prisoners in Louisiana filed a class action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 claiming that the state violated the ADA, Rehabilitation Act, and their 14th Amendment due process rights by keeping them incarcerated despite their being found not guilty by reason of insanity and committed by the court to the state's mental health facility.[SENTMARKER]On July 18, 2016, the Court dismissed the case without prejudice to the right to reopen it within sixty days if the parties did not settle.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently settled, agreeing to send individuals found not guilty due to insanity to mental health institutions.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2014, the Advocacy Center of Louisiana filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals (DHH) alleging that the defendants violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA), and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (RA) by failing to provide adequate medical and mental health care to individuals who have been found not guilty by reason of insanity (NGRI) in state courts.[SENTMARKER]The class was represented by counsel experienced in the prosecution of class actions.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, 2016, the parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay plaintiffs' reasonable attorney's fees and costs in the event that the parties cannot resolve a future claim for attorneys' fees or costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to submit a report to the court on the first working day of each month beginning November 16, 2016 and the defendants will have thirty (30) days from the date of the report to come into or establish compliance with this settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for judicial enforcement on November 16, 2016.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 31, 2001, a group of Medicaid-eligible children, acting through their parents or guardians, filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Massachusetts Medicaid program failed to provide home-based mental health services to children suffering from serious emotional disturbances (SED) by failing to provide, with reasonable promptness, early and periodic screening, diagnostic, and treatment services, and equal access to crisis services.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on three grounds.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss and certified a class of all current and future Medicaid eligible children in Massachusetts under twenty-one years of age, who were (or might become) eligible to receive, but were not receiving, what Plaintiffs described as "intensive home-base services."[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed and the case was remanded to the First Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The First Circuit affirmed the district court's judgment in January 2006, holding that the Commonwealth had violated the Medicaid Act's provision of services for SED.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint remedial plan, which was largely adopted by the parties, and the parties filed a final judgment in June 2013.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed an appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The U.S. sued the State of Mississippi under the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. alleged that the State knowingly failed to provide adequate mental health programs for adults with mental illness and segregated adults with disabilities in their State-run hospitals.[SENTMARKER]After a four-week bench trial, the court found that the health system violated the ADA and required a special master to determine and oversee the remedial process.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: The Department of Justice filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi in August of 2016 against the State of Mississippi, alleging that the state was violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide services to qualified individuals with mental illness and developmental disabilities in the most integrated settings appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought deintitu tionalization and integration into community-based healthcare programs.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the court granted the State's motion for summary judgment, finding that the United States did not have standing to bring this suit and that the State had not adequately articulated a necessary element of the claim.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: Plaintiff, a student at Hunter College of the City University of New York, brought this action against the College and its administrators on August 20, 2004, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff, who was diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, brought claims under the Fair Housing Act, the ADA, and Section 504 after the College forced her to leave its dormitory following her suicide attempt in June 2004.[SENTMARKER]The case eventually settled, with defendants paying plaintiff attorneys' fees and damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 7, 2004, a student with a disability filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against Hunter College, the owner and manager of Brookdale Residence Hall, a dormitory, and Hunter College's president and vice president, alleging intentional discrimination and disparate impact under the Fair Housing Act, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiff's application for a preliminary injunction, finding that an additional year's delay in her medical studies would irreparably harm her, while he concluded that NYU would suffer no hardships.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit reversed the district court's decision, finding inter alia that the plaintiff had not in fact demonstrated irreparable injury, it was her disability.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 15, 1996, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997, against the State of Tennessee, the Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation (DMH/MR) and the Memphis Mental Health Institute (MMHI), in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee, Memphis Division.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 1996, the same day as the complaint was filed, the parties submitted a joint motion for entry of a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement the defendants agreed to implement all policies, systems, procedures and rules currently in place, to provide quarterly status reports, provide the government access to the facilities, records, patients, and employees of MMHI, and to confer in good faith on the provisions of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, 1997, the Court entered judgment in accordance with the consent decree and terminated the case, retaining jurisdiction for necessary enforcement of the decree.[SENTMARKER]And, on September 18, 1998, the District Court (Judge Gibbons) granted the parties' joint motion for a stipulation and order, effectuating the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On June 21, 2005, the District Court (Judge Bernice B. Donald) granted the parties' joint motion for an order partially terminating the consent decree and approved the parties' stipulation for supplemental relief.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 1990, the U.S. Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against the Memphis Mental Health Institute (MMHI) and the Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), the defendants violated the constitutional rights of patients by failing to provide adequate, professional nursing care to patients and by placing patients in a locked-door room.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was entered on March 15, 1996.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to comply with the terms of the consent decree and to provide patients with adequate medical care, including nursing care, to ensure their safety and freedom from undue bodily and chemical restraints.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants in September 1998, and the parties entered a consent order in March 1996.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed that the consent order is in effect until the parties agree otherwise or until this consent decree is no longer in effect.

gold_sents: On February 17, 2004 the United States filed a complaint against Breathitt County, Kentucky, and Breathitt County Geriatric Corporation for violating CRIPA, 42 U.S.C. §1997, after the county failed to take action to remedy the violations laid out after the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") conducted an investigation of conditions at the Nim Henson.[SENTMARKER]On February 19, 2004, a settlement agreement was entered with the cour, and two years after the settlement agreement, the government found that the Nim Henson Nursing Home had been complying with all the terms of the settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2002, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Kentucky filed this civil rights lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Kentucky Eastern District against Breathitt County, Kentucky and the Nim Henson Geriatric Center in Jackson, Kentucky.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and implementing regulations by failing to provide adequate medical, nursing, nutritional, wound, restorative, and psychiatric care and services to Nim Henson residents and to otherwise protect them from harm.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants also violated the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights of the residents of Nim Henson by not providing them with adequate functional furniture, such as dining room chairs and recliners, and relegating many residents to their wheelchairs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants entered into a settlement agreement with the Attorney General in which they agreed to comply with the ADA and implement regulations.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the settlement agreement in March 2003 and the terms of the agreement are subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to the court's approval.

gold_sents: On January 31, 2006, subscribers to or customers of telephone or internet services that AT&T provided filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against AT&T Corp. and AT&T Inc., claiming that the defendants' participation in the federal government's program to monitor and collect Americans' telephone and internet communications was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The United States quickly intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was dismissed based upon retroactive legislation.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal and the Supreme Court declined to hear the case.
pegasus_output_sents: In December of 2005, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against AT&T and the National Security Agency.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants participated in a government program to intercept and analyze vast quantities of Americans' telephone and Internet communications without the authorization of a court and in violation of the First and Fourth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated in August 2006 and the court dismissed the complaints on the basis that the plaintiffs had not sufficiently alleged that they suffered an actual, concrete injury traceable to the defendants’ allegedly illegal activity.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case in March 2007 and the case was dismissed in April 2007.

gold_sents: In March 2018, the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Transportation Security Administration violated the Freedom of Information Act for wrongfully withholding its records about electronic device searches.[SENTMARKER]The TSA ultimately provided a letter stating it does not conduct device searches, and the ACLU agreed to dismiss the case.
pegasus_output_sents: The American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California (ACLU-NC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on December 20, 2017 against the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking information about the federal government's searches of electronic devices at airports.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU-NC is a non-profit civil rights organization that has its principal place of business in Northern California.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that TSA's policies and procedures regarding the search of airplane passengers' electronic devices violate the First and Fourth Amendments to the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the ACLU's motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the TSA in August 2018, and the case was closed on August 23, 2018.

gold_sents: When the FBI received in 2004 a “FISA Alert Report Form” seeking information on the plaintiff in this case, it was assumed to be related to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, when it was in fact merely from a private company called Financial Institutions Security Association.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the misunderstanding, the plaintiff’s name was erroneously placed on government watchlists, and she was fired from her job as a nurse working at the Federal Reserve Board.[SENTMARKER]After unsuccessfully filing a Freedom of Information Act request seeking records relating to the error, she brought this lawsuit against several federal agencies, seeking to force the agencies to produce the requested records.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 3, 2017, The James Madison Project (JMP) and The Daily Beast's Executive Editor, Noah Shachtman, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice (DOJ) and Department of Homeland Security (DHS) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking the release of documents related to the President's immigration executive order (Executive Order).[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the Executive Order was issued in March 2017 by President Donald Trump and signed by DHS Secretary John Kelly.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that the Defendants failed to comply with FOIA requests submitted to the Office of Legal Counsel (OLC), DHS, and four components of DHS (the Transportation Security Administration (TSA), US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), and U. S.[SENTMARKER]Customs and Border Protection (CBP)) under FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The Defendants' initial search located several thousand pages of records, which require de-duplication and further review to determine how many are actually responsive to Plaintiffs' FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]ICE's search located approximately 3,500 pages of potentially responsive records.[SENTMARKER]The Complaint further alleges that CBP is making rolling productions and uploading records relating to Executive Order to its online FOIA library.[SENTMARKER]The defendants have completed their processing of Plaintiffs' request.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, granted the Plaintiffs' motion to dismiss, and granted the plaintiffs' request for a temporary restraining order.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 27, 2017, Muslim Advocates filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia (D.C.) seeking records related to the government's border searches of electronic devices in the possession of persons from the seven Muslim-majority countries covered by President Donald Trump's January 27, 2017 Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) violated FOIA by failing to determine whether to comply with the request within 30 business days, failing to immediately notify Plaintiff of such determination and the reasons therefor, unlawfully withholding the requested records, and failing to provide reasonable costs and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]On March 7, 2017, the court granted the request for expedited processing and a CIV waiver fee, and the parties filed a joint status report on January 19, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would file additional joint status reports at subsequent intervals of 45 days.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide each other with a copy of each other's FOIA requests.

gold_sents: On May 2, 2017, the Protect Democracy Project sued DOJ under FOIA seeking records on whether DOJ was consulted regarding the travel ban EO.[SENTMARKER]This case has been consolidated into and continues at NS-DC-0112.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 15, 2017, The Protect Democracy Project, Inc. filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking records related to Executive Order 13769, "Protecting the Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into the United States", which was issued on January 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2017, Plaintiff sent a FOIA request to the DOJ's Executive Office for Immigration Review.[SENTMARKER]On March 2, 2017, Plaintiff received a letter from Defendant's Office of Information Policy stating that no responsive records were located and closing the review.[SENTMARKER]On May 4, 2018, the Court granted Plaintiff's request for a fee waiver and ordered the DOJ to produce to Plaintiff any and all non-exempt records or portions of records responsive to the FOIA request within 20 business days.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted Plaintiff an award of attorney fees and other reasonable litigation costs pursuant to FOIA  552(a)(4)(E).

gold_sents: On May 2, 2017, the Protect Democracy Project sued OMB under FOIA to compel disclosure of records about federal agencies consulted prior and subsequent to the implementation of President Trump's Jan.[SENTMARKER]27 travel ban Executive Order 13769.[SENTMARKER]After consolidation with another suit against DOJ.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a rolling production with monthly status reports.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2019 the parties filed a joint stipulation of voluntary dismissal with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 2, 2017, The Protect Democracy Project, Inc. filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia (D.C.) against the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Department of Justice (DOJ) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking the release of certain records regarding Executive Order 13769, "Protecting the Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into the United States."[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint status report in which the parties agreed that none of the material withheld from the FOIA request was appropriate for discretionary release.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that each party would bear its own attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2018, the court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the OMB and the DOJ.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on behalf of an American citizen being detained by the United States military in Iraq.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the Secretary of Defense under the federal habeas corpus statute, 28 U.S.C. §2241, the Non-Detention Act of 1971, and 18 U.S.C. § 4001(a) for injunctive relief, claiming violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Defense Department had detained the plaintiff since on or around September 14, 2017, after Syrian forces transferred him to U.S.[SENTMARKER]Custody.[SENTMARKER]On October 28, 2018, the Defense Department released the plaintiff and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On November 7, 2018, the court dismissed this case with prejudice and order each party to bear its own costs and fees.[SENTMARKER]In April 2019, the plaintiff sought to unseal the documents relating to the government’s proposed forcible transfer of the plaintiff into Syria.[SENTMARKER]The court reissued an unredacted version of the opinion on June 28, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation (ACLU) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Defense (D.C.) seeking habeas relief on behalf of an American citizen detained in Iraq.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU alleged that the government was holding the detainee without charge, without access to a court, or other meaningful opportunity to challenge his detention before a neutral decisionmaker.[SENTMARKER]The Defense Department moved to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, arguing that the ACLU had no standing to bring the action on the detainee's behalf.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the ACLU's motion for a preliminary injunction, and the parties reached an agreement in principle to resolve the case without further litigation.[SENTMARKER]On April 19, 2018, the district court issued a final judgment enjoining the government from transferring the detainee to any other country.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court vacated the final judgment and the case was closed.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in principle in which the government agreed to provide the ACLU with access to the detainee and to provide him with the opportunity to obtain legal representation.

gold_sents: On November 27, 2020, an informal foreign policy advisor to the Trump 2016 presidential campaign filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, alleging that the Department of Justice (DOJ), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and various former DOJ and FBI officials that sought the warrant against him in their personal capacity violated his right to be free of unreasonable searches and seizures in connection with Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrants issued against him during the 2016 campaign.[SENTMARKER]He sought $75 million in compensatory damages, punitive damages, injunctive relief, and attorneys' fees for this case and a related Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) case used to gain information for this litigation under FISA, Bivens, the Federal Tort Claims Act, and the Privacy Act.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
