gold_sents: On September 5, 2012, an individual U.S. citizen residing in Illinois and two organizations that sought to advocate for that individual filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the U.S. Department of Treasury, seeking a declaration that the Defendants' designation of the individual plaintiff as a "specially designated terrorist" was unlawful and an injunction against its continued application.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the lawsuit after the federal government removed the individual Plaintiff's name from the Specially Designated Terror List.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 5, 2012, the American Friends Service Committee (AFSC) and the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee (ADC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the United States Department of the Treasury's Office of Financial Analysis (OFAC) and Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First Amendment rights to free speech and association by imposing restrictions on the plaintiff's ability to work for a living, spend money, or give or accept donations without advance approval by OFAC.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that OFAC's actions violated the Constitution and federal statutes.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, dismissed the case without prejudice, and granted the plaintiffs' request for a declaratory and injunctive injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On October 17, 2013, the ACLU filed a lawsuit requesting an injunction forcing the DOJ to comply with a FOIA request regarding their policy on giving notice to criminal defendants against whom it intends to use evidence obtained from warrantless surveillance, including information obtained under surveillance orders authorized by the FISA Amendments Act § 702.[SENTMARKER]On March 3, 2105, the court granted part of each party's motion for summary judgment, and issued an order requiring the DOJ to conduct a further search for responsive documents, and disclose any that were not subject to FOIA exemptions.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2016, the court granted part of each party's motion for summary judgment, ruling that the DOJ's searches were adequate, and that all but one of the documents found by the DOJ were protected by FOIA's Exemption 5.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2017, the Court granted DOJ's renewed motion for summary judgment, finding that the remaining documents were properly withheld under FOIA Exemption 5.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2013, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Department of Justice (DOJ) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking records related to the government’s use of evidence derived from warrantless surveillance in criminal prosecutions.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU challenged the adequacy of the search and the applicability of Exemption 5 to withheld documents, and the parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment on these two issues.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2016, the Court granted the government's summary judgment motion, finding that Exemption 5 applied only to the documents withheld by the DOJ.[SENTMARKER]The Court also found that the DOJ had improperly limited its search under part 3 of its FOIA request by reading the word "added" into the request where it had not been written, and ordered DOJ to conduct a new search without the improperly-governing term and to release any responsive records not entitled to be searched under the FOIA exemption.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2010, two individuals with spinal cord injuries filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Florida Department of Health and the Florida Agency for Health Care Administration (AHCA) alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (R&A) by failing to provide in-home personal care assistance to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief under the ADA and R&A.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, holding that the State had violated the ADA, and rejected the State’s defense that inadequate funding, rather than discrimination, was the reason for retaining the plaintiffs in an institution.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the district court's judgment, but remanded for a reassessment of the State's cost-based defense.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to this court and the parties disagree as to the nature of the relief sought.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the State agreed to provide the plaintiffs with home and community-based services as part of its Traumatic Brain Injury/Spinal Cord Injury waiver program.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 10, 2010, a group of individuals with mental disabilities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the State of Georgia and the Georgia Department of Community Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief for violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were placing them at serious risk of hospitalization by terminating the Medicaid-funded services they need to remain in their current settings without offering any alternative support services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction on September 18, 2012 and the parties entered a settlement agreement on December 18, 2012.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement, the defendants will continue to provide the plaintiffs with services for as long as they satisfy the eligibility criteria for such services and will pay the Atlanta Aid Society, Inc. a total of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) as attorney's fees and court costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also requires the defendants to comply with the policies and procedures of the SOURCE program and the Medicaid program.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' constitutionality challenge was raised only two days ago and the court granted them permission to submit a brief addressing their constitutional challenge on October 28, 2010.

gold_sents: In September of 2011, one eighteen-year-old and four minor residents of Georgia with significant medical issues sued the agency responsible for administering Medicaid in Georgia.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the agency's decisions to deny or reduce hours of in-home, private nursing care violated the Medicaid act, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]Two of the Plaintiffs settled and some of the Medicare, as well as the Fifth an Fourteenth Amendment Allegations were dismissed on summary Judgment, however, the District Court found for the Defendants on the remaining allegations.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed this decision and the Court of Appeals dismissed the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The district court also awarded attorneys' fees to the plaintiff, which was affirmed by the Court of Appeals.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2010, plaintiffs, minors with serious disabilities who were Medicaid recipients, filed this class-action lawsuit was filed in federal court against the Secretary of the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) and Director of the Office of Medicaid Policy and Planning of FSSA.[SENTMARKER]They all had been receiving medically necessary therapies paid for by the State's Medicaid program, administered by the FSAA, for several years.[SENTMARKER]These therapies were necessary to ensure the plaintiffs' conditions would not deteriorate and that they would not lose functional ability.[SENTMARKER]The FSSA had denied the named plaintiffs and others similarly situated continuing access to these therapies, citing two provisions of the Indiana Administrative Code.[SENTMARKER]On February 10, 2011, the Court granted summary judgment in favor of the Plaintiffs, issuing a permanent injunction preventing the Defendants and their successors from limiting or denying coverage for prescribed physical, occupational, or respiratory therapy, and/or speech pathology, for any person under 21 enrolled in the State's Medicaid program when such denial or limitation was based upon the two disputed provisions.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 25, 2010, a group of seriously disabled Medicaid recipients sued the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that FSSA denied their requests for prior authorization of treatment services for their severely disabled children in violation of federal Medicaid law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit affirmed the district court's decision in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for partial judgment on November 10, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants' standing policy of refusing to provide long-term residential treatment for patients for whom such treatment had been found necessary by an EPSDT had been violated by the federal Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The court granted plaintiffs' request for a permanent injunctive injunction, and the parties agreed not to enforce  (b)(6) or (b)(5).[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 28, 2018, the NAACP and Prince George’s County, Maryland filed a claim against the U.S. Census Bureau and President Donald Trump for neglecting their constitutional duty to administer a fair and accurate census of the US population.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that underfunding and the flawed design of the 2020 Census might lead to undercounts of the US population in violation of the Enumeration Clause and to the detriment of minority populations, as the census count is tied to both public funding and governmental representation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs requested an injunction to require the US to develop a plan to ensure a fair and accurate count.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the claim for injunctive relief as unripe because census preparations were ongoing, but allowed the claim on underfunding to continue.[SENTMARKER]The court also allowed the plaintiffs to add two claims under the Administrative Procedure Act. On April 16, 2020, the court granted the government’s motion to dismiss; the case is closed.

gold_sents: On December 18, 2009 three young adult residents of Maine who were Medicaid recipients and who were diagnosed with cerebral palsy, filed a lawsuit against the Commissioner of the Maine Department of Health and Human Services in her official capacity.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Maine.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHHS had violated Title II of the ADA and other federal laws.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs alleged that the State had failed to accommodate Plaintiffs' disabilities and to provide medically necessary treatment in the most integrated setting possible, instead forcing them into nursing homes where they were functionally segregated from the outside world.[SENTMARKER]In August, 2010, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint reframing the case as a class action on behalf of all similarly situated Maine residents.[SENTMARKER]The parties began settlement discussions shortly thereafter.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2012, the Court (Judge Nancy Torresen) approved the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the State to establish a Medicaid Home and Community Based Waiver (HCBW) program, which would provide a limited number of qualifying class-members the opportunity to live in community-based settings.[SENTMARKER]The case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2009, three individuals with developmental disabilities brought a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine against the Maine Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Medicaid Act, and the Nursing Home Reform Amendments to the federal Medicaid Act (NHRA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHHS violated the ADA by failing to provide them with medically necessary services in a community-based, integrated setting.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which DHHS agreed to provide the plaintiffs with services that could enable them to live in the community.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required DHHS to provide specialized services to the named plaintiffs and other similarly situated individuals, to prevent the unnecessary segregation and institutionalization of plaintiffs and class members, and to provide services in the most integrated setting possible.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on July 15, 1999, and the parties agreed to a one-time notice to all nursing facilities in Maine regarding the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to disclose information about members of the Plaintiff Class.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay the Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

gold_sents: On April 14, 2014, several same-sex couples married in Michigan on March 22, 2014 filed this § 1983 civil rights action against the State in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the American Civil Liberties Union and private counsel, asked the court to declare that the same-sex marriage ban was unconstitutional when applied to Michigan's same-sex couples, to enjoin the State of Michigan from refusing to recognize those marriages, and to award attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On January 15, 2015, the District Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 22, 2014, a group of same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the State of Michigan, the Michigan Department of Human Services, and the Michigan Office of Retirement Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's ban on samesex marriage violated the due-process and equal-protection clauses of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on March 22, 2014.[SENTMARKER]On March 26, 2014, the Sixth Circuit issued a stay of the district court's decision, suspending the benefits of marriage until further court rulings are issued on this matter.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2014, the Supreme Court of Michigan ruled that the federal government should recognize the marriages performed in Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have filed a petition for a writ of certiorari.

gold_sents: This case was brought by individuals in Nebraska who were eligible for and had applied for or attempted to apply for home and community-based developmental disability services.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs brought the case against the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services Finance and Support seeking declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting Defendants from violating the ADA and various Medicaid laws and requiring them to adopt practices aimed at providing eligible persons with developmental disability services in home and community-based settings.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also sought litigation expenses, costs, and attorney's fees.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2003, a group of developmentally disabled Nebraska residents filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nebraska against the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services Finance and Support and two department directors in their official capacities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state had violated the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to properly allocate funding to individuals with developmental disabilities who are eligible for Medical Assistance Home- and Community-Based Services.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice, holding that the plaintiffs were not prevailing parties and denied their application for attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint motion and stipulation for approval of the settlement, which the district court retained jurisdiction to decide.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on various grounds, including that they were not entitled to attorney's fees under the ADA and the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 8th Circuit, which remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court found that the parties had not violated the ADA, the Due Process Clause of the 14th Amendment, or the due-process clause.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2020, Planned Parenthood of Greater Ohio (WMGPC) and its predecessors filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio against the Ohio Attorney General, the Ohio Department of Health, and the Secretary of the State Medical Board of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Ohio Senate Bill 23, 133rd Gen Assemb.[SENTMARKER]was a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment due to a ban on abortion for all patients who are more than ten weeks pregnant.[SENTMARKER]In March 2020, the Ohio of Heruth and Veterans Services issued a Joint Directors' Order to limit access to Ohio nursing homes and similar facilities.[SENTMARKER]On March 30, 2020, the district court granted plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and enjoined the State from enforcing or complying with the TRO.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted Plaintiffs' Motion for a Preliminary Injunction, which the court dismissed as moot.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that there was no need for discovery or an evidentiary hearing.[SENTMARKER]On April 10, 2019, the parties filed an appeal to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals for the United States.[SENTMARKER]The appeal was denied and the case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On December 20, 2010, a group of individuals with developmental disabilities and their families filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the State of Texas and Texas Community Service Programs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act, and the Nursing Home Reform Amendments Act (NHRA) by failing to provide them access to the community-based services and supports they need to live safely in the community.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the plaintiffs claimed that Texas did not comply with Title II's integration mandate.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to abate and stayed all proceedings in the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in November 2015, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2016, a group of employees of Franciscan Alliance, a Catholic organization that provides medical services to women who have miscarried babies, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and HHS Secretary Sylvia Burwell.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HHS's new nondiscrimination in health programs rule (the "Rule") violated their rights under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Religious Freedom Act (RFRA) by denying them health insurance coverage for medical procedures related to gender transition, including abortions.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2016, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' motions for a preliminary injunction, finding they were likely to succeed on their APA and RFRA claims.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, 2017, after a hearing, the Court stayed the case pending further consideration of the Rule.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment, which the Court granted.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the parties' motion to intervene, and granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Same sex-couples filed suit in August 2013 against the State of Virginia challenging Virginia laws denying same-sex couples the right to marry and refusing to recognize same-sex marriages entered into in other states as unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The case is pending but stayed, awaiting the Fourth Circuit's resolution of another case raising the same issue.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2014, a group of same-sex couples filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Virginia against the Commonwealth of Virginia, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth's exclusion of gay couples from marriage and refusal to recognize their valid marriages from other jurisdictions violate the due process and equal protection guarantees of the Fourteen th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on October 6, 2014 by Judge Robert S. gold_sents: On March 10, 1997, the United States filed a complaint against the State of Arizona and Gov. Symington in the District of Arizona (Judge Roslyn Silver), alleging that the Defendants were violating the constitutional rights of female inmates to be free from sexual misconduct and unlawful invasions of privacy.[SENTMARKER]Symington in the District of Arizona (Judge Roslyn Silver), alleging that the Defendants were violating the constitutional rights of female inmates to be free from sexual misconduct and unlawful invasions of privacy.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement, which was filed on March 11, 1999.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, defendants did not admit any constitutional violations, but agreed to adopt policy and procedures from the Federal Bureau of Prisons, improve screening and training of employees, promote inmate awareness and comfort in reporting abuse, and thoroughly investigate allegations of abuse.[SENTMARKER]On December 13, 1999, the parties jointly filed a stipulation to dismiss which Judge Silver granted in a December 17, 1999 order.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 8, 1996, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Arizona filed this suit against the Arizona Department of Corrections (ADOC) alleging that the ADOC violated the civil rights of female inmates by failing to protect them from sexual misconduct by correctional officers and staff.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ADOC and contract employees engaged in sexual misconduct and invasions of privacy in Arizona women's prisons.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the District Court on March 10, 1997.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit reversed, stating that the Attorney General's "reasonable cause" determination under the Fair Housing Act is not subject to judicial review.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which ADOC agreed to conduct an investigation of all allegations of sexual misconduct in ADOC facilities.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required ADOC to implement a program to screen potential employees for sexual misconduct.[SENTMARKER]ADOC will continue its practice of removing staff accused of serious sexual misconduct from all-contact with female inmates pending the outcome of the investigation.[SENTMARKER]A DOC will revise its current training materials to incorporate all of the provisions of this settlement agreement and require each employee to verify that he or she is aware of the changes.

gold_sents: This case litigated by the ACLU in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California dealt with sanitation, classification, legal access and other conditions at the California Institute for Men (Chino).[SENTMARKER]In 1988, the prison and the plaintiffs entered a settlement agreement, which provided for various improvements and compliance monitoring that ended in 1993.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 1988, the ACLU Foundation of 10 Southern California filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the California Department of Corrections and the Director of the California Institute for Men.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution by intentionally inflicting mental stress upon the prisoners confined in the Chino Reception Guidance Center.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' intentional infliction of mental stress violated the cruel and unusual punishment clause of the Fifth, Sixth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties entered into a memorandum of understanding to resolve the remaining issues.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay $22,000 to each of the plaintiffs for their attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 29, 1988.

gold_sents: In 2008, a California inmate filed a lawsuit against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, alleging that the CDCR acted unconstitutionally by segregating the prisoners by race and locking down an entire race of prisoners due to the actions of certain prisoners of that race.[SENTMARKER]The case survived the defendants' motion to dismiss and class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]In October 2014, the parties entered into a stipulated settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, the CDCR agreed to a number of terms, including to cease implementation of race-based modified programs or lockdowns; to provide outdoor activity to prisoners in a modified program or lockdown for longer than fourteen days; to revise its policies concerning modified programs and lockdowns, and to train its staff on modified programs and lockdowns.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay attorneys fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction for 18 months to enforce compliance with the agreement, and on December 20, 2016, the parties filed notice that the court’s jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement had terminated and that the case was dismissed with prejudice in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 18, 2006, a prisoner at High Desert State Prison, California, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) alleging that the defendants' Race-Based Lockdown Policy violated his Eighth Amendment rights to equal protection and due process.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial and a jury found that defendants violated Norwood’s Eighth Amendment right to outdoor exercise by imposing a lockdown on all prisoners who were racially classified as “Other” after an incident involving a prisoner classified as African-American.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case, which the court granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to implement a modified program and lockdown policy.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the defendants to pay the plaintiffs a total of $1 million.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment to the defendants, finding that the price-posting procedure 18 did not constitute per se violation of the Sherman Act.

gold_sents: On May 16, 2020, five individuals filed a class action against Lompoc, a low-security prison facing one of the largest outbreaks of COVID-19 among U.S federal prisons, for immediate relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs proposed a class of all current and future people in post-conviction custody at Lompoc, and sought enlargement of custody to include home confinement, and if the conditions of confinement violated constitutional rights, for prisoners to be released.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO (temporary restraining order), and a preliminary injunction requiring Lompoc to undertake health and safety measures, and attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the court denied the defendant's motion to dismiss the case and on October 8, the court granted plaintiff's motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]In January 2021, the plaintiffs filed another motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 27, 2020, a group of inmates at the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the BOP and the Director of the Bureau of 8 Prisons for failing to respond effectively to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The BOP has failed to respond to the pandemic effectively.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that the conditions at the warehouse are extremely unsanitary, and the warehouse is extremely unsanitary.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also allege that the Bureau's response during the pandemic was inadequate.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to decertify the class, but denied their request for early release from 11 prison.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 22, 1980, inmates filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut against the Connecticut Corrections Department.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated and named lead case with five other cases filed against the defendant in 1981 and 1982.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were represented by the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union and Legal Assistance to Prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the plaintiff's rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments were violated because the facility was overcrowded, unsanitary, lacking in security, and unable to provide adequately the basics of general human living needs.[SENTMARKER]Judgments were reached that required screening of all admitted inmates, individualized health care summaries for HIV-positive inmates, routine health examinations, and the use of drug therapies for HIV-positive inmates; as well as requiring that the prison not increase its inmate population, continue operating as a medium security facility, and allow plaintiffs' lawyers access to the facility.

gold_sents: In 1986, the prisoners at the Occoquan Facilites of the District of Columbia's Lorton Correctional Complex filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District of Columbia government officials' overcrowding of the facility violated their Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the defendants had violated the constitution, and required that the prison minimize its population.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2003.
pegasus_output_sents: In the wake of a prison riot, inmates at the District of Columbia's facilities in Occoquan, Virginia, brought suit in federal court under 42 U.S.C.  1983 alleging that conditions at the prison violated the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted class certification and a preliminary injunction imposing a limit on the number of prisoners who could be housed at the facility.[SENTMARKER]In September, the District Court found that the District had deliberately failed to obey its orders concerning overcrowding at the jail and held the District in civil contempt.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court vacated and remanded, finding that the population cap was too broad a remedy.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the District agreed to pay the National Prison Project the sum of $26,400.00 and to repair all damage to the facility caused by inoperative and leaking plumbing as well as roof leaks.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the District to pay $100,000.00 to the D.C Prisoners' Legal Services Project, Inc., and $53,498.00 for the National Center on Institutions and Alternatives.

gold_sents:
On August 6, 2006, Prison Legal News (PLN) submitted a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) seeking documents related to litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]They asked the BOP to waive all search and duplication fees under the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]BOP refused to grant the fee waiver and PLN appealed the decision to the Department of Justice.

The DOJ upheld the denial of the request, so on September 13, 2005, PLN filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]After several years of litigation, the parties settled in 2017.[SENTMARKER]The BOP produced the requested documents and agreed to pay $420,000 in attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 13, 2005, a non-profit legal journal challenged the Federal Bureau of Prisons under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia (D.C.) for declaratory and injunctive relief and an order compelling the defendants to provide it with all documents responsive to its FOIA requests without any cost.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also challenged the Bureau's search for responsive records and its utilization of the FOIA exemptions to withhold the redacted information and other documents that it claims have not been produced at all.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment and ordered the Bureau to conduct the search without costs to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendant's request for a fee waiver for processing its FOIA request and provided it with copies of the relevant documents.[SENTMARKER]The defendant claimed that the Department of Justice (DOJ) was the only proper defendant in this FOIA action.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the defendant has decided not to appeal this case.

gold_sents: Four overdetained former Delaware prisoners, represented by private counsel, filed this § 1983 action against the Delaware Department of Corrections (DDOC) and Central Offender Records (COR).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that inadequate staff, training, discipline, and hours of operation, along with a host of other policies, caused dysfunction and frequent over-detention.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought suit individually and as a class on behalf of all those incarcerated in a DDOC facility as of October 1, 2008 or later who were not or will not be released within 12 hours of the expiration of their sentence or the forwarding of a court order for release.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment because the plaintiffs' failed to demonstrate that the defendants were deliberately indifferent to the overdetention problem.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court's decision to grant summary judgment to the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 1, 2012, the Delaware Department of Correction (DDOC) was sued in the U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware for violating the Fourth, Fifth, and Eighth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DDOC had a practice of over-detaining inmates and inmates past their release dates, causing them to be injured and other members of the class.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment as to all claims, and the Court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint status report on October 2, 2014 and the parties agreed to a settlement agreement on October 3, 2014.

gold_sents: In 2004, a Mental Health Unit (MHU) prisoner at Georgia's Phillips State Prison brought this §1983 suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]Represented by the Southern Center for Human Rights, , plaintiff contended that the defendant prison administrators denied Eighth Amendment protections against cruel and unusual punishment by understaffing the MHU, as well as by staffing it with correctional officers without adequate mental health training.[SENTMARKER]Class certification was sought but not granted.[SENTMARKER]On January 31, 2005, the day before dispositive motions were due to be filed, the Court approved the parties' joint stipulation for dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 1983, a prisoner at Phillips State Prison in Buford, Georgia, filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the Georgia Department of Corrections, the acting commissioner of the department, and the warden of the prison.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subiect to physical, mental, and sexual abuse, excessive use of force, improper and prolonged placement in administrative and disciplinary segregation, and to an Ion-going risk of suicide, sell injury, and death.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on February 20, 2003.[SENTMARKER]On February 20, 2004, the plaintiffs filed a motion to dismiss due to mootness.[SENTMARKER]On July 9, 2004, the court denied the defendants' motion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have entered into a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In January of 2008, several inmates filed suit against the Georgia Department of Corrections, alleging that it established a pattern and practice of systematic abuse of the inmates.[SENTMARKER]Several claims and defendants were dismissed for failure to exhaust administrative remedies and failure to plead claims in adequate details.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case in July 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Georgia on behalf of the mother of a deceased inmate who was beaten to death by CERT Team supervisors and members at Valdosta State Prison.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the beatings violated the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution and the civil rights laws of the United States.[SENTMARKER]The CERT Teams wearing special black uniforms with hard toe black combat boots for kicking and black leather gloves specially padded on the outside of the knuckles for hitting have a pattern and practice of beating and kicking restrained inmates that serves no penological purpose.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust administrative remedies, which was granted by the district court.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The Eleventh Circuit reversed and remanded the case, finding that the prisoner did exhaust the required administrative remedies.[SENTMARKER]The case will go to trial in July of 2012.

gold_sents: Plaintiff is a trans woman housed in a male prison in Georgia.[SENTMARKER]She filed suit in the Souther District of Georgia alleging prison officials' deliberate indifference to her repeated sexual assault.[SENTMARKER]The district court ruled in favor of the prison administration, grating their motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed, similarly finding that no violation of the Eighth or Fourteenth Amendments.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 6, 2018, a transgender inmate filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Georgia against the Georgia Department of Corrections alleging that the prison officials at Rodgers State Prison had violated her Eighth Amendment rights by failing to protect her from a fellow inmate's sexual assault.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants, finding that the defendants did not violate the Constitution and that they were immune from suit because they were entitled to qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]After careful review of the record and with the benefit of oral argument, we affirm the district court's grant of summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2011, a group of Native Hawaiian inmates filed a complaint in the First Circuit Court of the State of Hawaii alleging that the defendants violated their rights under the federal Constitution and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 by preventing them from practicing the native Hawaiian religion during a Makahiki festival at a CCA correctional facility located in Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to transfer the case to the District of Arizona pursuant to  1406(a) as it could have been brought there.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the action on the ground that the defendant was not, at the time of service of the summons, "doing business" in the Southern District of Florida, and therefore, the venue requirements of 28 U.S.C.  1391(c) were not met.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 23, 2012, a deaf inmate at the Idaho State Correctional Institution (ISCI) filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Idaho against the Idaho Department of Correction (IDOC), the IDOC warden, and the ISCI.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehabilitation Act) by failing to provide the inmate with an opportunity to effectively communicate with persons outside the prison that was equal to that provided to hearing inmates.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to comply with the requirements of the ADA and Rehabilitation Act by ensuring that the inmate was provided the use of a videophone or some other comparable device under the same terms and conditions that telephones are provided to the hearing inmate.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 10, 2017, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois against the Illinois Department of Corrections (IDOC) alleging that the IDOC's use of solitary confinement violated the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to extreme isolation and were denied access to educational programs, the law library, and religious services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the plaintiffs had not shown that their placement in isolation violated their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is now on appeal.

gold_sents: In 2009, a group of Muslim prisoners filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the warden of the Federal Correctional Institute, alleging that the prison's allowance of only one hour of group prayer per week violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.[SENTMARKER]The court ultimately issued a permanent injunction against the Federal Correctional Institute in 2013, holding that the prison's policy violated RFRA and, upon further clarification, ordered that the warden "is to allow group prayer during every Muslim prayer time for which the inmates are not confined to their cell."

gold_sents: In 2007, the Disability Law Center filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the ADA, and the Rehabilitation Act against the Massachusetts Department of Correction.[SENTMARKER]The DLC claimed that the DOC failed to take into account mental illness when subjecting prisoners to long periods of disciplinary and other forms of isolation and segregation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in 2011, and the defendants agreed to make sure that mentally ill prisoners were not placed in isolation or segregation without a full evaluation and determination that such placement would not cause further injury; they also agreed to pay attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed in 2015 as no one had requested to reopen the case since the settlement monitoring date ended.[SENTMARKER]In 2016 one of the prisoners tried to reopen the case since prison officials were violating the settlement agreement, but the judge refused to reopen the case.

pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2018, the Massachusetts Department of Correction (DOC) and Massachusetts Partnership for Correctional Healthcare (MPCH) entered into a settlement agreement in a class action lawsuit brought by deaf and hard of hearing inmates in the custody of the DOC.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C.  12131 et seq., the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 (RLUIPA), and the Constitution of the United States by failing to provide adequate auxiliary aids and services in violation of the ADA and RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the plaintiffs' requests for videophone services, visual alert and notification systems, and by denying their requests for interpreter services, individual hearing devices, and other auxiliary aid and services.[SENTMARKER]According to the settlement agreement, the DOC and MPCH will make videophone technology available at each of its facilities to those inmates who have been identified as deaf or hard-of-hearing and whose primary language is sign language.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide sign language interpreters to communicate accurately and effectively with medical staff.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to the final approval of the court.

Liberty, the commissioner of the MDOC, filed a petition for habeas corpus and complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine (Bangor) on behalf of inmates at the Mountain View Correctional Facility and a putative class of those similarly situated.[SENTMARKER]The Petitioners and Class Members alleged that the confinement of inmates with COVID-19 has become unconstitutional because of the pandemic risk associated with the virus.[SENTMARKER]The Court denied the Petitioners' motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) or preliminary injunction on May 18, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On May 20, 2020, the parties filed a joint status report, as ordered by the Court, and the parties agreed to implement a number of measures to prevent the spread of the virus, including limiting the number of operational entrances and exits to the facility, limiting non-essential vendors, volunteers, and tours, and restricting the use of hand sanitizer in the facility.[SENTMARKER]On June 8, 2020, the Court issued a final judgment in favor of the defendants, concluding that the defendants had complied with the court's orders and that the plaintiffs' claims were unexhausted.

gold_sents: On October 30, 2007, a state prison inmate filed a §1983 lawsuit against the Chief Medical Officer of the Michigan Department of Corrections' Bureau of Health Care Services and three unnamed individual members of the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, who originally filed pro se but was later represented by the University of Michigan Law School General Clinic, sought declarative, monetary, and injunctive relief, claiming that the defendants acted with deliberate indifference to the plaintiff's serious medical needs when they repeatedly denied his request for cataract surgery.[SENTMARKER]On May 30, 2012, following a reversal by the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals, the district court entered an order granting summary judgment in favor of one of the defendants based on qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]As of November 18, 2014, the case is ongoing against the remaining defendants.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| LAW ||| DATE ||| CIVIL ||| ORG [CONTRACTED] This is a civil rights action under 42 U.S.C.  1983 brought by an inmate in the custody of the Michigan Department of Corrections (MDOC) alleging that his Eighth Amendment rights were violated when he was denied cataract surgery in his left eye.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that his request for surgery was denied by the MDOC's Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) on October 26, 2004 and that the defendants sought to dismiss the case in January 2008.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on March 25, 2010.[SENTMARKER]On October 30, 2007, the plaintiff filed a pro se complaint in the Eastern District of Michigan (Bay City) seeking declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff's complaint alleged deliberate indifference based on failure to provide him with cataract surgery.[SENTMARKER]The defendant, Correctional Medical Services, Inc. (CMS), denied the request for cataract surgery for one eye but not the other.[SENTMARKER]In November 2007, the parties completed discovery and the parties filed objections to the Report and Recommendation.[SENTMARKER]The Magistrate Judge entered a Report recommending that Pramstaller's motion to dismiss be denied.[SENTMARKER]On March 25, 2010, the District Court entered a judgment in favor of the defendant.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the case on March 31, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2010, the parties entered a final judgment against the defendant, which was granted.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This 2013 lawsuit was brought by several Muslim inmates of  the Lakeland Correctional Facility in the U.S. District for the Western District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that, in failing to provide adequate nutrition to prisoners observing Ramadan, the defendants, several agents of the Michigan Department of Corrections, had violated the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments as well as the RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Michigan, a group of Muslim prisoners sued the Michigan Department of Corrections (MDOC) for violating their First and Eighth Amendment rights under the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) by failing to provide them adequate nutrition during the Islamic month of Ramadan.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to accommodate the prisoners' requests for nutritionally-adequate meals during Ramadan, as required by MDOC policy, and instead reduced their calories to approximately 1,000 to 1,500 calories per day.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment, claiming that they were shielded by qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion, concluding that the plaintiffs could only obtain adequate nutrition by violating their religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the district court, where the case was dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: In 2016, a transgender prisoner of the Missouri Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the “freeze-frame” policy of refraining from providing transgender prisoners necessary medical care for gender dysphoria unless they previously received such services violated the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, the court declared that the policy violated the Eighth Amendment’s Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause and issued a permanent injunction against the policy.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the defendants to provide the medical care necessary for the plaintiff’s gender dysphoria.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the court awarded the plaintiff attorney’s fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2016, a transgender woman in the custody of the Missouri Department of Corrections (MDOC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the MDOC, Corizon Health, Inc., and the individual defendants for their alleged deliberate indifference to her serious medical needs, which constitutes cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution, made applicable to the State through the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Ms. Hicklin is a thirty-seven year old white transgender woman, diagnosed with gender dysphoria, who is housed at Potosi Correctional Center, a facility for male inmates, in Mineral Point, Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth amendment by knowingly ignoring Ms.Hicklin’s serious medical need and through the enforcement of MDOC policy, practice, custom, or usage of hormone therapy to any transgender inmate who was not receiving such therapy before entering MDOC.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for injunctive and declaratory relief and ordered the defendants to provide hormone therapy for inmates who are diagnosed with Gender Dysphoria and for whom hormone therapy has been recommended by a mental health provider.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiff in January 2017.

gold_sents: In 2005, the ACLU filed a class-action lawsuit on behalf of inmates confined in Unit 32 of the Mississippi State Penitentiary in Parchman, Mississippi, alleging dangerous and inhumane conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The parties initially settled in 2006.[SENTMARKER]Then, the plaintiffs filed a motion for contempt in late 2006, seeking an order to compel defendants to immediately comply with the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]After two more settlements, the defendants agreed to close Unit 32 in 2010 and the case was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2005, the National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), the Mississippi ACLU, and Holland Knight, LLP, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi against the Mississippi Department of Corrections (MDOC) on behalf of prisoners confined in Unit 32 of Mississippi State Penitentiary (MSP), Parchman, Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the MDOC violated the Eighth Amendment by subjecting the prisoners to inhumane living conditions and excessive force, deprives them of medical and mental health treatment, and denies them procedural due process in housing them in MSP.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree on February 20, 2006, which was signed by Judge Jerry A. Davis on April 28, 2006 (Dkt No. 24, attached here as an Exhibit A), after a fairness hearing in compliance with Rule 23 (e) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.[SENTMARKER]Under the consent decree, the defendants agreed to provide prisoners with a means for renouncing affiliation with a security threat group that does not require prisoners to provide identities of gang members as a condition for renunciation.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this consent decree after a fair hearing on the parties' compliance with the terms of the decree.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice on the terms set forth below.

gold_sents: In 2013, prisoners in the East Mississippi Correctional Facility (EMCF) filed a class-action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Mississippi Department of Corrections, claiming that EMCF violated the Eighth Amendment's Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the inhumane living conditions at EMCF, a prison for the mentally ill, harmed inmates.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the court granted class certification.[SENTMARKER]After engaging in discovery and a bench trial, the parties attempted to settle.[SENTMARKER]After the parties submitted their supplemental expert reports, the parties attempted to settle.[SENTMARKER]However, on January 24, 2019, the parties notified the court that the parties were unable to settle and that future settlement conferences would not be productive.[SENTMARKER]As of March 25, 2019, the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2007, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi on behalf of prisoners confined at the East Mississippi Correctional Facility in Meridian, Mississippi, which is designed to provide treatment and housing for mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the conditions under which they were confined violated their Eighth Amendment right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment, and they sought to redress these violations under 42 U. S.C.  1983.[SENTMARKER]The defendants entered into a consent decree that prohibited the housing of seriously mentally ill inmates in long-term solitary confinement in Unit 32 for more than 14 days.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also prohibited the use of chemical agents and physical force on prisoners without warning and in the absence of an immediate threat of danger.[SENTMARKER]After the consent decree was entered, the defendants contracted with a new company, Centurion, to provide mental health care services at the prison.[SENTMARKER]As the case neared trial, the parties met on multiple occasions with the magistrate judge to try to settle the case without success.[SENTMARKER]The case was denied by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

gold_sents: This case is about the refusal of North Carolina's Department of Public Safety (DPS) to recognize Humanism as a faith group within the North Carolina state prison system.[SENTMARKER]On February 2, 2015, an inmate in a North Carolina prison and the American Humanist Association filed this lawsuit in the Eastern District of North Carolina against officers of the North Carolina Department of Public Safety that are involved in policy decisions related to recognition of faith groups in state prison under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]They alleged violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, and on March 29, 2018, Judge Terrence W. Boyle granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied the defendants' motion.[SENTMARKER]He entered a permanent injunction ordering DPS to recognize Humanism as a faith group and to permit a Humanist study group to meet within North Carolina state prisons on the same terms as other faiths are allowed and entered declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]The court also awarded nominal damages and attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]Since the entering of the permanent injunction, there has been no activity in this case.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction remains in effect.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 25, 2015, the American Humanist Association (AHA) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Public Safety (DPS) seeking injunctive and declaratory relief, permanent injunctive relief, nominal damages, and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' refusal to allow a North Carolina inmate with sincerely held Humanist convictions to form a Humanist study group to meet on the same terms that Defendants authorize inmates of theistic religious traditions to meet violated the Establishment and Equal Protection Clauses of the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion for summary judgment was denied, and the case was dismissed on March 29, 2018.

gold_sents: This was a prison medical care case filed in 2002 in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey, seeking damages and an injunction against contract medical care providers and New Jersey corrections officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs that the New Jersey prison system was failing to treat them for Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]By the time the court adjudicated the class action issue, in May 2008, the New Jersey Department of Corrections had adopted major changes in how prisoners with HCV were treated; it updated its procedures to match those of the federal Bureau of Prisons, and "backscreened" all the prisoners willing to be screened for the virus.[SENTMARKER]Given that the injunctive relief requested by the plaintiffs was this same set of reforms, Judge Hillman denied the request for injunctive relief as moot.[SENTMARKER]As to two individual class members who had HCV, the court held there was sufficient evidence in the record to go to trial on their constitutional claims (though not on their Americans with Disabilities Act claims), and denied the state's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2009, the case settled for money damages.[SENTMARKER](However, it seems from some papers filed by one of the plaintiffs that he may never actually have received  his money.[SENTMARKER]But when he sought the assistance of the court in enforcing the settlement against his lawyer, Judge Hillman ruled that the court lacked jurisdiction, and directed him to file a collection action in state court.  )
pegasus_output_sents: On October 16, 2002, a class of former and current inmates of the New Jersey Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act by failing to screen inmates for Hepatitis C and other serious medical conditions.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification on May 15, 2006, but denied their request for injunctive and declaratory relief on the ground that their disability prevented them from serving as class representatives.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case in 2005, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement in 2006.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to provide inmates with Hepatitis C testing, screening, treatment, counseling, and other medical services.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on August 27, 2006, and the case was closed on October 31, 2006.

gold_sents: On December 3, 2008, plaintiff, a prisoner who is an ordained Pentecostal minister, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of New Jersey under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 2000cc, et seq. ("RLUIPA") against the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Corrections and the Administrator at the New Jersey State Prison (NJSP).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, plaintiff claimed that defendants violated plaintiff's First Amendment right by implementing a policy banning all prisoners from preaching in the prison.[SENTMARKER]During the litigation, the state changed its policy to allow the plaintiff to preach to groups of six or fewer prisoners, and on November 25, 2009, the parties filed a Stipulation of Dismissal, as the claims in the action had been resolved by the parties.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 17, 2009, a prisoner at New Jersey State Prison ("NJSP") filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the New Jersey Department of Corrections ("NJ DOC") and the NJSP administrator.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, an ordained Pentecostal minister, alleged that the defendants violated his First Amendment rights under the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 ("RLUIPA"), and the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment by imposing a blanket ban on inmate preaching in the prison.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, but the case was transferred to the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The First Circuit reversed the district court's grant of summary judgment and remanded the case to the lower court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In July 2015, an inmate at the Northern Nevada Correctional Center living with hepatitis C filed this lawsuit in the District Court of Nevada in Reno.[SENTMARKER]Representing himself, he claimed that the defendants, medical and administration personnel at the prison, violated his Eighth Amendment rights through deliberate indifference to serious medical needs resulting from his hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]In May 2016, the parties reached a private settlement agreement, the terms of which are unknown.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York announced today that it has filed a civil action in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the former owner of a New York City apartment complex.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the owner, who has not been identified by name, allegedly defrauded the apartment complex out of more than $1 million.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that the owner used the proceeds from the sale of the apartment to pay for his personal expenses, including a car, credit card, and a house.[SENTMARKER]The case is being handled by the Office of the Inspector General for the Federal Bureau of Investigation (IG), and the case has been closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought, pro se, by a prisoner housed in the Special Housing Unit of New York's Attica prison, and then litigated by NY Prisoners Legal Services.[SENTMARKER]It concerned conditions of confinement in that unit, including excessive force, religion, sanitation and nutrition, access to courts, and medical and mental health care.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, piecemeal, between 1992 and 2002.
pegasus_output_sents: This is an interlocutory appeal pursuant to 42 U.S.C.  1983 from an order of the United States District Court for the Western District of New York granting a preliminary injunction in a class action challenging the conditions at the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Attica Correctional Facility.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that prison authorities and state correctional officials permitted the prison guards to violate many of their constitutional guarantees, including those against cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that they were deprived of their right to free exercise of religion while incarcerated in the SHU.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the intervenors leave to intervene only to the extent necessary to challenge the discovery by the inmates of the guards' personnel records.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the defendants argued that the defendants had failed to meet their burden of showing a likelihood of success on the merits and irreparable injury and that therefore preliminary injunctive relief was not appropriate.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the district court denied the defendants' appeal and set aside the preliminary injunction.

gold_sents: In 1997, prisoners at various facilities within the New York State Department of Corrections filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Department officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Prisoners Legal Services of New York, brought the suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York, challenging the systemic deprivation of religious rights of Native American prisoners, in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In 2000, the parties reached a settlement and the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 1997, the Native American inmates of the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DOCS was violating their religious rights by failing to provide them with the opportunity to participate in religious ceremonies outsjide of the facility.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in September 1999, and the case was closed on September 8, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would hire a part-time minister for adherents of the Nation of Islam Faith once their numbers exceeded 200.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed that members of the Moorish Science Temple of America were expressly permitted to attend prayer services and classes with or without the presence of an outside volunteer.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the defendants agreed that they would impose a limit on the number of guests each inmate may invite to each event.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendants to provide or allow Native American prisoners with the right to wear a Kufi or Yalmaka at all times.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2003, a group of paraplegic prisoners, proceeding pro se, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against prison officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide adequate medical care in violation their rights under the Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]After extensive settlement negotiations and mediation, the parties were unable to reach and agreement.[SENTMARKER]This case is proceeding to trial.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 13, 2007, a group of prisoners with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York State Department of Correctional and Community Supervision (DOCS) alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504) by the DOCS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, monetary damages, and reasonable attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, finding that the defendants had violated the ADA by failing to make their programs, services, and activities accessible to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to make improvements to their facilities.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 21, 2003, an Oklahoma Department of Corrections prisoner filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging that his Constitutional rights under the Free Exercise Clause were being violated by the Oklahoma Department of Corrections' refusal to provide him with a Kosher diet.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated to include the complaints of two other prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The prisoners won both preliminary and permanent injunctive relief requiring the Oklahoma Department of Corrections to provide them a Kosher diet at no personal cost.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction, issued February 8, 2006, ordered the Director of the Oklahoma Department of Corrections 'to immediately provide to the plaintiffs Kosher diets at no cost, [while complying with nutritional requirements currently applicable to all other ODOC prisoners].'[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2012 the Court found that the judgment entered in this case only applies to the claims pursued by the three named plaintiffs, and the permanent injunction relief does not apply to all Oklahoma Department of Corrections inmates.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1996, three inmates of the Colorado Department of Corrections filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado alleging a constitutional and statutory right to receive a kosher diet in accordance with Orthodox Jewish law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their rights guaranteed by the First Amendment's free exercise clause had been violated by the Colorado DOC's failure to provide them free of cost with kosher meals consistent with their Orthodox Jewish faith.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction, finding that the inmates were sufficiently sincere in their religious beliefs and that the cost-sharing program was constitutional.[SENTMARKER]The case was then re-referred to the United States Magistrate Judge for further proceedings, including a determination whether permanent injunctive relief was warranted.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2005, the district court issued a final judgment ordering the Oklahoma Department of Correction to provide the plaintiffs with a Kosher diet at no cost.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the final judgment to the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]In April 2002, the court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss the case, and the case was re-opened.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered on January 21, 2005.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2013, a trans woman housed in a mens prison in Oklahoma filed a pro se case against prison staff and administration in the District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]She claims that she has been denied appropriate transition related care and accommodations, amounting to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]Her request for a TRO and preliminary injunction were denied at the district court level, and the circuit court affirmed the denial of the preliminary injunction without comment on the TRO for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2015, the district court granted defendants' motion to dismiss, dismissing the claims against all defendants in their individual capacities without prejudice, and all the claims against them in their official capacity with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]Though the plaintiff objected to the dismissal, the Court denied her motion and affirmed the dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| ORG||| DATE [CONTRACTED] On March 28, 2014, a state prisoner filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma alleging that the Oklahoma Department of Corrections violated her Eighth Amendment rights by denying her the right to purchase female undergarments, such as bras and panties, and by failing to provide the proper level of hormone treatment for her gender identity disorder.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, but denied the motion for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The case was then transferred to the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals for further proceedings.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2016, a group of Medicaid enrollees with chronic hepatitis C brought suit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (DOC) alleging that the DOC's policy of prohibiting all communication between hospital patients and their lawyers, family, friends, and others not in the employ of the DOC or Geisinger Medical Center was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The defendants argued that the prohibition on visitation and phone calls was the policy of Geisinger and not the DOC.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the two matters should be consolidated and thereafter filed a joint motion for consolidation, which the District Court dismissed.[SENTMARKER]On August 31, 2016, the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit issued an opinion finding that the defendants had a reasonable likelihood of success on the merits of the case.[SENTMARKER]The Court also found that the Defendants had adopted a new Hepatitis C treatment protocol in response to the new antiviral drugs.[SENTMARKER]In a separate case, the defendants appealed the district court's denial of their motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit held that the parties had not exhausted their administrative remedies as required by the PLRA.
