pegasus_output_sents: On June 9, 2017, three prisoners filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP), the Director of the BOP, and the Warden of the Special Management Unit (SMU) at the United States Penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment by failing to provide adequate mental health care to prisoners suffering from mental illness in the SMU at USP Lewisburg.[SENTMARKER]The defendants alleged that there is inadequate screening of the prisoners’ mental illnesses in order to determine their suitability for confinement in an SMU facility.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and denied the plaintiffs' request for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: 47 inmates at the Beaumont Federal Correctional Institution in Midland, Texas filed a complaint against the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act. Plaintiffs alleged that the conditions at Beaumont were unsanitary and inhumane, and that as a result of damage to the building caused by Hurricane Rita, they were subjected to confinement in a building unfit for inhabitants.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also alleged they were entitled to damages for working conditions endured while working in a UNICOR factory manufacturing Kevlar helmets.[SENTMARKER]Defendant moved for dismissal or summary judgment in the alternate.[SENTMARKER]Several years later, but before the district court ruled, plaintiffs' counsel died, and the case was dismissed without prejudice for failure to prosecute.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 25, 2005, inmates at the Federal Correctional Complex Medium in Beaumont, Texas filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas under the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) alleging that the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) violated their Eighth Amendment rights by failing to provide them with adequate quarters, safekeeping, care and subsistence in the wake of Hurricane Rita.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the BOP failed to certify that no part of their contract would be performed under working conditions which are unsanitary or hazardous or dangerous to the health and safety of inmates.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment on the negligence claim, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 21, 2012, a Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed this pro se federal civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]He sued multiple TDCJ employees under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that TDJC policies that prevented his smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, limited his ability to wear a religiously significant medicine bag, and prevented him from growing long hair violated his rights under RLUIPA and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]He sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]An additional Native American prisoner plaintiff joined the suit shortly after filing.[SENTMARKER]In February 2013, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, consented to proceedings before a Magistrate Judge, and voluntarily dismissed all of their claims except their three RLUIPA challenges against the TDCJ Director in his official capacity and their First Amendment claim seeking damages against the Program Analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment was granted and a final judgment entered in their favor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit and were successful in getting judgement on the RLUIPA grooming policy claim vacated and remanded.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the RLUIPA grooming claim was denied.[SENTMARKER]As the RLUIPA grooming policy claim moved towards trial, the initial prisoner plaintiff in the case was released and his claims were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the consolidation of cases Casey v. gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| DATE ||| LAW ||||| DATE [CONTRACTED] On August 10, 1971, a group of African-American students in Jefferson Parish, Louisiana filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Jefferson Parish School Board (JPSB) alleging that the JPSB had violated the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by failing to desegregate the public schools of Jefferson Parish and to eliminate the vestiges of the prior dual school system.[SENTMARKER]The JPSB appealed the decision of the District Court and the Fifth Circuit to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal, and the case was dismissed on July 15, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Final Settlement Agreement (FSA) on June 30, 2008.[SENTMARKER]TheFSA required the School Board to continue its affirmative efforts, in recruiting and outreach, to encourage applications for instructional and administrative positions from qualified Black applicants.[SENTMARKER]The School Board also agreed to pay the plaintiffs' costs.[SENTMARKER]TheFSA was entered into in place under its own terms.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to vacate all prior orders and injunctions in the lawsuit and enter a Final Judgment and Order dismissing the lawsuit with prejud ice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]In a separate action, the plaintiffs filed a motion to intervene, which was denied.

gold_sents: On Dec.[SENTMARKER]3, 1997, Barbara Grutter brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the University of Michigan Law School.[SENTMARKER]She claimed that, in denying her admission, the school discriminated against her on the basis of her race, and violated the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case made its way to the Supreme Court, which held that the law school's desire to obtain a "critical mass" of underrepresented minority students counted as a narrowly tailored use of race in its admissions process and was not unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 14, 2002, the University of Michigan's LS&A undergraduate college and its law school were sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan by two white students who alleged that the law school's admissions policy violated the Equal Protection Clause and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by using race as a factor in its admissions decisions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought compensatory and punitive damages, injunctive relief forbidding continuation of the alleged discriminatory admissions process, and admission to the college.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion, and the court of appeals affirmed the district court's ruling in part and reversed part.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Supreme Court granted the defendants' motion for declaratory relief and remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On Oct. 14, 1997, two applicants who had been denied admission to the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the university.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel, claimed that the university's admissions policy treated race as a predominant factor in granting admission, and that they, as white applicants, had been discriminated against in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case went to the Supreme Court, which held that the school's admission policy that automatically awarded 20 points out of a possible 150 to underrepresented minorities was not narrowly tailored to achieve the compelling interest of diversity in education and so violated the Equal Protection Clause.

Bollinger, which upheld Michigan's new freshman admissions policy and struck down the University's old admissions policy.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2002, the Sixth Circuit issued an opinion upholding the admissions program used by the University and the petitioner in that case sought a writ of certiorari from this Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment, which was granted by the District Court and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On December 13, 2000, the court held that the admissions policy the University instituted in 1999 and continues to use today passed constitutional muster.[SENTMARKER]The court further dismissed the certified class representative, certified Hamacher as the sole representative, and dismissed the claims.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case for further litigation.

gold_sents: On June 20, 1989, foster care children of the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Children's Rights and the ACLU, asked the court to order improved policies related to protective services, family preservation and preventive services, child placement, case reviews, adoptions, and staffing, among other issues, claiming violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (AACWA), the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, the District of Columbia Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, and the District of Columbia Youth Residential Facilities Licensor Act of 1986.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that caseloads were too large, leaving many children in the foster care system for far too long with unresolved cases.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the complaint alleged inappropriate placements for children and inadequate efforts to return children home.[SENTMARKER]In 1993, Judge Thomas F. Hogan approved a consent decree directing DHS to develop policies and procedures to rectify the system.[SENTMARKER]After many years of oversight, and periodic contempt orders, the system has gradually improved.[SENTMARKER]However, there is still a monitor in place reporting on the progress of the Child and Family Services Agency (CFSA) created as a result of this case.
pegasus_output_sents: This is a civil rights action brought on behalf of children in foster care under the supervision of the District of Columbia's Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District's foster care system violated the children's constitutional rights by failing to protect them from abuse and neglect.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a consent decree, which required the District to provide foster care services to children who were abused or neglected and who are or should be known to the Department by virtue of that abuse or neglect.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court denied the district's motion to stay implementation of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit reversed, concluding that the court lacked jurisdiction under the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case to the lower court for further proceedings.

gold_sents: On 2017, foster parents and three states filed a suit challenging the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act (the "ICWA").[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs allege the ICWA violates the Equal Protection Clause and anti-commandeering principles.[SENTMARKER]The district court held the ICWA is unconstitutional which was partially affirmed in a fractured en banc opinion by the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] This case is about the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) and the accompanying regulations (the "Final Rule"), which were applied by the Texas Department of Family Protective Services (DFPS) to the Navajo Nation's proposed placement of a twenty-three-month-old girl in New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas, alleging that ICWA and the Final Rule violated equal protection, the Tenth Amendment, the nondelegation doctrine, and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by denying them the ability to adopt A.L.M., a Navajo child.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on all of their claims, but the district court denied the motion, concluding, as relevant to this appeal, that Plaintiffs had Article III standing.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment in part, finding that Plaintiffs lacked standing to bring each claim, but granted the defendants' motion to dismiss on the basis that they had no standing to do so.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed an appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is pending before the Supreme Court of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court will hear the appeal.

gold_sents: California recipients of Adult Day Health Care services brought this class action to enjoin California from reducing or eliminating the ADHC program, which would put the plaintiffs at risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California granted the plaintiff class a preliminary injunction in September 2009, forbidding California to modify it's adult Day Health Care program until an appropriate alternative could be provided to prevent institutionalization of individuals in the plaintiffs' class.[SENTMARKER]The District Court approved a settlement agreement that created a new program which will help to prevent the institutionalization of ADHC beneficiaries.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 18, 2009, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the California Department of Health Care Services and its Director (Defendants) alleging that the defendants' cuts to Adult Day Health Care (ADHC) services violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the cuts to ADHC services would place them at risk of unnecessary institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the State on the basis that the plaintiffs were requesting "new" services which were not required by the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit reversed the district court's decision and held that the cap on prescriptions 16 could violate the ADA's integration mandate.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on January 25, 2012 and the parties agreed to provide services to replace ADHC in the community.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement, the court ordered the parties to declaratory and in relief the defendants’ alleged discriminatory policies and practices under ABx4 5.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: Two individuals who use wheelchairs for mobility sued the City of Steamboat Springs, for having inaccessible public transportation and facilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree requiring the city to make its services and facilities accessible, pay attorneys' fees and costs, and pay $12,250 to the plaintiffs.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 1999, the City of Steamboat Springs, Colorado was sued in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehabilitation Act) by failing to make its public transportation system readily accessible to and usable by persons who use wheelchairs.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of Title II of the ADA and of Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the City agreed to make certain improvements to its transit system.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was final and binding on the parties, including all principals, agents, and employees of the City.[SENTMARKER]In addition to making improvements to the transit system, the consent decree required the City to provide comprehensive training for all bus and van operators, dispatchers, and mechanics, as well as timely refresher training for any new operator or mechanic who demonstrates a lack of knowledge of proper wheelchair lift operation, maintenance, and repair.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the city to ramp or otherwise provide access to the restrooms at the Alpine Slide/stables area, a men's and a women's restroom on the east side of the rodeo grounds, and to develop and implement a public education program to promote the use of the city's transit system by individuals with mobility impairments.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 12, 2000.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were disabled individuals who sued the Colorado Rockies baseball club after it removed accessible seats in Coors Field and raised prices on others.[SENTMARKER]There was a trial held, after which the court dismissed all claims by stipulation.[SENTMARKER]It is unclear, however, whether the parties settled.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 27, 2003, a group of individuals with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the Denver Metropolitan Major League Baseball Stadium District, the Colorado Rockies, and HOK Sport, the architect of Coors Field, alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide wheelchair-accessible seating in the lower level of the stadium.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that defendants failed to provide a choice of admission prices and lines of sight comparable to those for members of the general public.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for partial summary judgment on a single issue, stating that the only seats in the back are required to be clustered in front of those seating areas.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, but denied the plaintiffs' motion to recover their attorney's fees.

gold_sents: On April 29, four individuals with disabilities and Disability Rights New York filed a complaint against Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the absence of live televised American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation in Governor Cuomo’s daily televised briefings on COVID-19 discriminated against populations with disabilities residing in New York by failing to provide a live ASL interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, declaring the lack of ASL interpretation as a violation under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO and preliminary injunction requiring the defendant to immediately include live in-frame ASL interpretation for all briefings addressed to New York residents.[SENTMARKER]The preliminary injunction was granted on May 11, and the defendant was ordered to immediately implement live, in-frame ASL interpretation for his daily press briefings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2020, Disability Advocates New York (DRNY) filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York County and Governor Andrew Cuomo, alleging that the county violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (RA) by failing to provide an in-frame American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter at every meeting held to discuss emergency decontamination in the plaintiffs’ community.[SENTMARKER]DRNY alleged that Governor Cuomo's failure to provide a live televised ASL interpreter deprived the plaintiffs of effective communication in violation of the ADA and RA.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted DRNY's motion for a preliminary injunction on May 11, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit affirmed the district court's grant of summary judgment for the county, holding in part that the ADA did not require the county to provided an ASL interpreter at each meeting because based on the interpretation services that were provided the county "effectively communicated" the relevant information to the plaintiffs at the large-group meetings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The deadline for fact discovery is June 8, 2020.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 11, 2013, the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island entered into an Interim Settlement Agreement (ISA) with Rhode Island and the City of Providence in violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Supreme Court's decision in Olmstead v. L.C., 527 U.S. 581.[SENTMARKER]L.C., 527 U.S. 581.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree that provided relief to approximately 200 Rhode Islanders with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) who received services from a sheltered workshop and day program provider, and a special education program which ran a segregated sheltered workshop inside a Providence public high school.[SENTMARKER]According to the consent decree, the state was not in compliance with this provision of the ADA and the court ordered remedial action plan to facilitate compliance with the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]On September 24, 2014, the Rhode Island Department of Education (RIDE), the Office of Rehabilitative Services (ORS), and the Providence Public Schools Department (PPSD) entered into a contract agreement to offer training to individuals with I/DD in a demonstration project focusing on three components: (a) Family Employment Awareness Training (FEAT), (b) self-determination and (c) discovery/employment.[SENTMARKER]RIDE, ORS, and the Paul V. Sherlock Center on Disabilities are providing or ensuring the provision of a significant number of training opportunities.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the Department of Justice's Office of Disability Services (ODS) on behalf of individuals with disabilities who received sheltered workshop services from Training Thru Placement (TTP), a private non-profit agency, and Harold A. Birch Vocational Program (Birch) at Mount Pleasant High School in Providence, Rhode Island.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ's complaint alleged that the state violated Title II by unnecessarily segregating individuals in two particular facility-based employment and day programs and placing those individuals at risk of such segregation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that ORS and the PPSD violated the ADA by failing to provide transportation for those individuals to and from the day programs.

gold_sents: In this case, a third-grader plaintiff who had autism and ADHD filed suit against the Kanawha County Schools system under the IDEA, the Rehabilitation Act, Title II of the ADA, the West Virginia Human Rights Act, and West Virginia Policy 2419.[SENTMARKER]The elementary school student had been subject to disciplinary removal from the classroom and his district had failed to provide the behavioral supports and programming required by law.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2018, the United States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia entered a final judgment in the case of G.T.[SENTMARKER]et al v. Kanawha County Schools, a class of students with disabilities who are eligible for special education under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) and the West Virginia Human Rights Act (W.Va.[SENTMARKER]HRA) against the Board of Education (BOE) of the County of Kanawha.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C.  12132, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide their students with effective behavior supports, leading to unjustified disciplinary removals from the classroom due to the students’ behaviors.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought certification of a class consisting of all students who need and are not receiving behavior supports from the BOE, and (2) have experienced disciplinary removal from any classroom.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, dismissed the case for lack of jurisdiction, and denied their requests for additional relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

(SFFA) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina, alleging that the University of the North Carolina at Chapel Hill's use of race in its undergraduate admissions process violated the Fourteenth Amendment and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]SFFA sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a Joint Stipulation of Voluntary Dismissal as to all claims involving UNC-Chapel Hill and its admissions proceedings pending the Supreme Court's decision in Fisher v. Ct. 2198, and the case was stayed until August 1, 2016.[SENTMARKER]On July 20, 2015, the parties filed a motion to intervene in defense of the University's admissions policy, which was denied by the Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On July 30, 2015, the Court granted the parties' motion to dismiss, finding that the parties had not shown that the admissions policy violated the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, allowing the parties to settle the case without further litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Former students and an employee of Rhinebeck Central High School filed suit against the School District and the former principal alleging that the District had violated Title IX of the Education Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to rectify allegations that the principal had sexually harassed the female students.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a Consent Decree in which the District agreed to implement anti-discrimination procedures.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 9, 2003, the United States filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Rhinebeck Central School District and Thomas Mawhinney, then the Principal of the High School.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the District and the former Principal were in violation of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, 20 US.C.[SENTMARKER]1681-88 by failing to prevent, identify, report, and respond to sexual harassment and discrimination on the basis of sex in the administration or provision of educational services, programs, opportunities or benefits.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the District agreed to revise its policies and procedures for preventing, identifying, reporting, and responding to complaints of sexual harassment or discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the District to implement a training program for all employees of the District.[SENTMARKER]The District also agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $25,000.

gold_sents: A 16-year old transgender male student sued Kenosha Unified School District No. 1 (Kenosha) in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on July 19, 2016, arguing that the school violated the Equal Protection Clause and Title IX by denying Plaintiff access to the boys’ restrooms.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiff a preliminary injunction to use the boys' restroom throughout his senior year, which the Seventh Circuit upheld on May 30, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on January 22, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The settlement required Defendant to pay Plaintiff $800,000, enjoined Defendant from prohibiting Plaintiff from using the boys’ restroom, and required the Defendant to notify all staff about the injunction.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 15, 2016, a transgender student at Tremper High School in the Kenosha Unified School District (KUSD) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the KUSD, alleging that the school had violated Title IX by denying him full and equal access to student restrooms and overnight accommodations during school-sponsored trips offered to other male students.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the treatment he received after he started his female-to-male transition violated his equal protection rights under Title IX and the Equal Protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties filed a joint motion for a consent judgment on December 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court found in favor of the plaintiff on each factor, and on January 22, 2018, the parties agreed to settle the case for $800,000, in full and final satisfaction of his claims for compensatory damages and reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The consent judgment is subject to final approval by the court at a later date.

gold_sents: On August 11, 2005 a group of African-Americans filed a consolidated amended complaint Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in United States District Court of the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Wal-Mart discriminated against African-Americans in hiring of over-the-road truck drivers.[SENTMARKER]On May 16, 2007, the court certified a class of African Americans who had not been hired or had been deterred from applying for these jobs.[SENTMARKER]Discovery continued in preparation for trial and on January 13, 2009 the court denied the defendant's motions for decertification and summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties thereafter reached a settlement that was approved by the court on March 5, 2009.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement Wal-Mart agreed to damages in the amount of $17,500,000 to be distributed to the named representatives, class members, and their attorneys.[SENTMARKER]It also agreed to provide EEO training, actively recruit minorities, impose benchmarks for hiring minority drivers, make specific job opportunities open to minorities, and engage in recordkeeping and reporting.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 2005, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas alleging that Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. and WalMart Transportation, LLC discriminated against African Americans in their hiring practices for over-the-road truck driver positions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants recruited new truck drivers by having its current drivers pass out cards with a 1-800 number to call for an application and that the practice of having current drivers distribute this number was discriminatory.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on September 24, 2004, which required the defendants to pay $17,500,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]After May 2007, the parties conducted discovery on the merits of the class claims and the parties agreed that the parties would continue to work together to increase the flow of African American applicants for OTR driver positions at each of the company's distribution centers.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement were as follows: (i) The parties agreed to provide training regarding equal employment and specific compliance with the provisions of Title VII and  1981; .[SENTMARKER](ii) the defendants would pay the plaintiffs a total of $17, $500,000; .[SENTMARKER](iii) the plaintiffs would be required to pay their attorneys' fees and expenses; and (iv) the court would grant the defendants an injunction.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion for summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought by female employees of Citigroup Global Markets against Citigroup Global Markets and its subsidiary, Smith Barney, seeking injunctive and declaratory relief and damages for the company's discriminatory practices against female employees.[SENTMARKER]This case was solved by a class-action settlement on August 13, 2008, resulting in relief granted.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2005, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Citigroup Global Markets, Inc., d/b/a Smith Barney, alleging that Smith Barney discriminated against female employees on the basis of gender with respect to business opportunities, compensation, professional support and other terms and conditions of employment in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the California Fair Employment and Housing Act, Cal. Gov't Code  12940 et seq.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to gender discrimination when they complained about unfair, discriminatory treatment to the highest levels of 8 the company, including to the Director of Human Resources of Smith Barney.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which Smith Barney agreed to implement various revisions to its policies and practices, to provide its Human Resources staff with appropriate training regarding compliance with state, federal, and local EEO laws, to maintain its commitment to its female broker networking meetings, to pay the cost of such binding mediation, and to post on its intranet site a statement in support of its anti-discrimination and harassment policies.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required Smith Barney to establish a Settlement Fund and to implement changes to its policy and practices.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 25, 2006, the Denver Field Office and the Phoenix District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sued Moreland Auto Group, LLP under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Two former female employees sought injunctive relief to enjoin the defendant from discriminating against employees based on gender or from retaliating against employees who complain about discrimination.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2008 Judge Edward J. Nottingham approved a settlement agreement that included a $70,000 fund to be dispersed amongst the claimants, and an injunction enjoining the defendants from gender-based discrimination.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2008, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against Moreland Auto Group, LLP d/b/a Kids Automotive, Inc., Kids Financial, Inc, and Brandon Financial Inc. alleging that the defendants discriminated against female employees by subjecting them to sexual harassment and a hostile work environment in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that more than 30 days prior to the institution of this lawsuit, two female employees of the defendants filed charges of discrimination with the EEOC alleging that they were discriminated against because of their gender, because of sexual harassment, and by retaliating against them for complaining about the harassment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the EEOC a total of $70,000 and to provide annual training to its officers, managers and employees regarding discriminatory harassment and retaliation in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Edward W. Nottingham on August 22, 2008 and is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: This case was brought by ten black current and former special agents of the United States Secret Service against the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Treasury and the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief including back pay, front pay, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and an injunction, alleging that the Secret Service discriminated against them on the basis of race in promotions as well as in transfers, assignments, testing, hiring, and disciplinary practices.[SENTMARKER]The court approved a settlement agreement that awarded $24 million in damages, $8 million in attorney's fees, and $860,000 in costs.[SENTMARKER]The agreement will remain in place until 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2000, ten African-American Special Agents of the United States Secret Service filed this employment discrimination action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, alleging that the Secret Service engaged in a pattern and practice of racial discrimination against black agents.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the agency's hiring practices, promotions, transfers and assignments, performance, bonuses and awards, discipline, retaliation, and the creation of a hostile work environment were disparately affected based on race.[SENTMARKER]The parties ultimately settled the case in 1996 and the parties are now before the Court disputing the implementation of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit denied review of the district court's certification order, in In re Johnson, 760 F.3d 66 (D.C  1981), on August 1, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to continue to maintain a competency-based scoring system that is validated by an outside expert, and to continue publishing competency reports.

gold_sents: This case was brought by eight Hispanic Special Agents against the U.S. Department of Treasury's United States Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and injunctive relief, alleging there was a pattern and practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin by the U.S. Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted Defendant's Motion for Summary Judgment on March 20, 2007, thereby terminating the case.

Yellow Transportation, Inc. , linked below (Clearinghouse code: EE-IL-0329).[SENTMARKER]The decree awarded a total of $11 million ($1.1 million in attorney's fees) and no significant injunctive relief because of a consent decree in other litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case is technically open but effectively closed.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and Central 4 American Resource Center (the "Plaintiffs") filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Justice ("DOJ"), Department of Customs and Border Protection ("CBP"), and the Executive Office for Immigration Review ("EOIR"), alleging that the government's policy of denying asylum to persons who entered the United States through the southern border was unlawful under the Administrative Procedures Act ("APA"),  15(a)(1) of the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA"), or  10(b)(2) of the Refugee Act of 1924 ("RANA").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction, a temporary restraining order, and a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on June 30, 2020, finding that the Rule was unlawful on the ground that it was not in accordance with law and was in excess of statutory limitations because it did not adhere to notice and comment procedures.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2019, the organizations filed a motion for temporary restraining orders to prevent the Rule from taking effect.[SENTMARKER]On September 9, 2019, the parties filed a petition for a writ of certiorari, which was granted by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit granted the parties's motion for a stay pending the outcome of the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would not settle the case in Mexico, and the parties did not intend to settle in Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On August 16, 2019, several health care providers and nonprofit organizations serving immigrant communities filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Department of Homeland Security's Final Public Charge Rule (the Rule), which added non-cash benefits to the factors considered in determining whether a person applying for legal permanent residence is likely to become a public charge.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Government violated the Administrative Procedure Act by exceeding its statutory authority, claimed that the Rule was "arbitrary and capricious," and asserted that the Rule violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, a district court judge denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction enjoining the government from implementing the Rule, but issued an order for preliminary injunction in a related case that would enjoin the implementation of the rule in California, Oregon, the District of Columbia, Maine, and Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]This preliminary injunction was stayed by the Ninth Circuit in December 2019.[SENTMARKER]It was affirmed a year later in December 2020, but the order was stayed pending petitions to the Supreme Court in the Second, Seventh, and Ninth Circuits.[SENTMARKER]The Rule was abandoned by DHS on March 9, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of April 15, 2021, the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 14, 2019, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) published a final rule entitled 22 "Inadmissibility on Public Charge Grounds" in the Federal Register.[SENTMARKER]The final rule is intended to prevent the disenrolling of eligible U.S. citizen children from Medicaid due to fears that their children's health care coverage will affect their ability to seek immigration relief.[SENTMARKER][ENTITYCHAIN] The plaintiffs filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of various organizations, including Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County, Central American Legal Center of Los Angeles, and the Children's Hospital Association of California.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief, enjoining DHS from using the revised Manual to process immigrant visas applications, and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss.

gold_sents: On 2014, Joe Arpaio, Sheriff of Maricopa County in Arizona, filed this lawsuit in the D.C. District Court under the Declaratory Judgment Act and the Administrative Procedures Act (APA) against President Obama, the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the Director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, and the U.S. Attorney General, claiming that the federal programs deferring immigration action for various categories of out-of-status aliens were unconstitutional abuses of the President's power, or should have been done via formal rulemaking.[SENTMARKER]In December 2014, the D.C. District (Judge Beryl A. Howell) dismissed the case, holding that Sheriff Arpaio lacked standing.[SENTMARKER]The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed in August 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 20, 2014, the Maricopa County Sheriff's Office, Arizona, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Attorney General, and the Director of the Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) alleging that the President's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program and Executive Order Amnesty (EOA) programs were unconstitutional abuses of the president's role in our nation's constitutional architecture and exceeded the powers of the President.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, ECF No. 7, and dismissed the complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The court affirmed the district court's dismissal of the case for lack a cognizable injury in fact for purposes of Article III standing.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In May of 2019, asylum seekers detained under the jurisdiction of the New Orleans ICE Field Office filed a class action lawsuit against DHS, ICE, and the New Orleans ICE Field Office, alleging that they were giving blanket parole denials without individualized reviews.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, the court granted preliminary injunction, enjoining defendants from continuing to detain asylum seekers without individualized consideration.[SENTMARKER]In March 30, 2020, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for preliminary injunction, seeking immediate reviews of class members still detained.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then filed a motion for order to show cause why the defendants should not be held in contempt for violating the 2019 preliminary injunction order, expedited discovery, and the appointment of a special master.[SENTMARKER]The court granted limited discovery.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 30, 2019, a group of asylum seekers detained at the New Orleans Field Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (NOLA ICE) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against ICE and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking injunctive and declaratory relief setting aside NOLA ICE's blanket parole denial policy.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' failure to follow the Parole Directive of 2009, as well as their unlawful failure to provide individualized determinations of flight risk and danger, violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (APA) and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC), which is a project within the SPLC.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 2019, the parties filed a Joint Status Report (Dkt.[SENTMARKER]Report) in the D.C. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a preliminary injunction requiring the defendants to comply with the conditions of the consent decree and consent order.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion to dismiss on October 10, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied on October 17, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A group of public interest law firms filed this class action lawsuit in June, 2005 on behalf of migrant workers against their former employer, alleging gross underpayment in violation of the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act (AWPA) and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).[SENTMARKER]The Court granted, and the Eleventh Circuit affirmed, class certification for the plaintiffs in September, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs won partial summary judgments in 2008 and 2009, resulting in an eventual award of $11 million in a final judgment in October, 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: The Southern Poverty Law Center's Immigrant Justice Project brought this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia on behalf of migrant agricultural workers who were admitted to the United States to work under the H-2B temporary foreign worker visa program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of their rights under the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act (AWPA) and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) during their employment at Eller Sons Trees, Inc. (Eller Sons) from June 1999 through June 2005.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory relief and damages for violations of the minimum wage and overtime provisions of the AWPA and FLSA.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment on various issues, many of which the Court decided in its October 8, 2008 Order.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2007, the parties filed a motion for partial summary judgment, which was granted by the Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In May 2018, the Council on American-Islamic Relations - Chicago (CAIR-Chicago) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Citizenship & Immigration Services for failing to process its FOIA request for immigration records since the 2008 institution of the Controlled Application Review & Resolution Program, alleging that this conduct was a wrongful delay of release of records in violation of FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs dismissed their claims without explanation on June 28, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2018, the Council on American-Islamic Relations-Chicago (CAIR-Chicago) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the United States Citizenship Immigration Services (USCIS) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking the release of records concerning a policy called the Controlled Application Review Resolution Program (CARRP), which imposes extra-statutory rules and criteria to delay and deny immigration benefits to which applicants are entitled.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, on August 1, 2017, CAIR-Chicago submitted an electronic FOIA request to the USCIS National Records Center FOIA/PA Office seeking information on all individuals who have applied for naturalization, change of status, and asylum through forms N-400, I-589, and I-485 since April 11, 2008 and the processing time for each application, the number of times each applicant was interviewed by USCIS agents, and the number, if any, of subsidiary applicants and the status of their citizenship applications.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA request was denied by USCIS and the defendants failed to produce in a timely manner records that respond to the request.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleged that the defendants violated FOIA by failing to provide a date by which processing of the request could be expected to be completed.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for injunctive and declaratory relief with respect to the release and disclosure of the requested records and ordered the defendants to provide expedited processing and a waiver of fees.

gold_sents: On March 2, 2007, a resident alien and two non-profits filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, challenging the mandatory detention provision of Section 236(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2241, requesting his immediate release from detention.[SENTMARKER]On July 12, 2007 district court held a hearing on the writ of habeas corpus, however, before ruling on the issue the plaintiff was released from custody.[SENTMARKER]The court then dismissed the remainder of the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 2, 2007, the Political Asylum/Immigration Representation Project (PAIR) and the Catholic Legal Immigration Network, Inc. ( CLINIC) filed this action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and Section 303(b) of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 (IIRIRA) for violations of the mandatory detention provision of section 1226(c) of INA.[SENTMARKER]On June 14, 2007, the parties filed a joint motion for summary judgment, which was denied by the Judge.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2007, the Judge entered a final judgment in favor of the DHS and dismissed the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, lack of standing, and for failure to state a claim.

gold_sents: In September 2019, the Irish International Immigrant Center sued U.S. Citizenship & Immigration Services and President Trump.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged defendants illegally terminated an immigration relief program that granted "deferred action" to seriously ill individuals and their families.[SENTMARKER]Represented by the ACLU, the plaintiff sought injunctive and declaratory relief for violations of Equal Protection and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a joint motion to stay the case on October 31, 2019, so parties could seek a nonjudicial resolution.[SENTMARKER]This followed a USCUS announcement that the deferred action program would return but requests would only be granted “based on compelling facts and circumstances.”[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case without prejudice on June 15, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2019, the Irish International Immigrant Center (IIIC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) and its acting director, alleging that the defendants' termination of deferred action in non-military cases was impermissibly motivated by racial animus and animus based on national origin, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The IIIC represented individuals and families applying for deferred action from USCIS as a result of a serious medical need.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' decision to terminate the deferred action program was based on impermissible animus, which is contrary to law.[SENTMARKER]On June 22, 2020, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case for mootness.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint status report on or before February 16, 2021.[SENTMARKER]On July 16, 2021, the court granted the defendants’ motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on June 22, 2020.

gold_sents: In 2018, the City of Baltimore filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that certain changes to the Public Charge rule by the U.S. President, Secretary of State, and Department of State were made without following proper administrative procedure and in violation of equal protection.[SENTMARKER]The rule increased the number of immigrants barred from applying for visas for having previously received public assistance.[SENTMARKER]The rule was preliminarily enjoined in a different lawsuit on July 29, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit is ongoing, but proceedings are stayed until May 24, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: In January 2018, the City of Baltimore filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against President Donald J. Trump, the United States Department of State, and the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA) alleging violations of the Administrative Procedure Act and the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' January 2018 revisions to the provision of the Foreign Affairs Manual governing the application of the public charge ground of inadmissibility (the "FAM change") would deter immigrants from accepting Baltimore's public benefits.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, and for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that Baltimore had sufficiently alleged multiple plausible legal challenges to the FAM change as well as its standing to bring those challenges.[SENTMARKER]The district court also granted a temporary restraining order against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 4, 2020, two individuals in ICE (US Immigration and Customs Enforcement) custody sued ICE and the Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that restrictions to telephone access by impsing costs and denying access to incoming calls during the COVID-19 pandemic when in-person visitations have been rendered impossible is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, they alleged that their Fifth and First Amendment rights had been violated by preventing communication with counsel, denying their right to legal representation, and other resources critical to support their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 3, 2020, the ACLU of Northern California filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) on behalf of individuals detained in the custody of ICE at the El Paso Service Processing Center and the Otero County Processing Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ICE and DHS violated their constitutional, statutory, and regulatory rights under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA),  16a, and  17 Administrative Procedures Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, class certification, appointment of counsel, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The district court certified the class and held a bench trial, finding shortcomings with the prison system, including the training of staff, the updating of legal materials, and the availability of photocopying services.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit, which remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.

gold_sents: A group of immigration legal service providers filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon on December 18, 2019, alleging the federal government had manipulated the immigration adjudication system in a way making it virtually impossible for asylum seekers to succeed.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Take Care Clause of the U.S. Constitution, as well as provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act and the Administrative Procedure Act. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]After the defendants filed a motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs moved for a Temporary Restraining Order due to the COVID-19 pandemic, alleging that the immigration courts had failed to take adequate public health measures to protect judges, respondents, attorneys, and staff.[SENTMARKER]On April 1, 2020, the District Court denied the plaintiffs' motion.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, the court granted in part and denied in part the defendant's motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought reconsideration, which was denied on September 10.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2020, a group of legal advocacy organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against the Department of Justice (DOJ) alleging that the DOJ's use of video teleconferencing (VTC) in removal proceedings violated the Take Care Clause of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights of noncitizens seeking legal assistance in the immigration court system.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought an emergency order with respect to the national COVID-19 emergency or the next 28 days, whichever is shorter.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, ECF 28, and denied the government's motion to dismiss the case for lack of jurisdiction.

gold_sents: On April 15, 2009, two longtime permanent residents of the United States who had been detained in Pennsylvania prisons for periods exceeding six months while they pursued challenges to decisions to deport them filed a class action lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Justice, and the prisons that held them, claiming that their prolonged detention without a hearing to determine whether such detention was justified violated the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On August 10, 2009, the Court (Judge John E. Jones III) declined to certify a class action or grant habeas class relief but granted the plaintiffs' individual habeas petitions.[SENTMARKER]Alli v. Decker, 644 F. Supp.[SENTMARKER]2d 535 (M.D. Pa.[SENTMARKER]Rather than present evidence on the reasonableness of the plaintiffs' detention at a bail hearing, the parties came to an agreement whereby defendants would release the plaintiffs without requiring that they post bail.[SENTMARKER]One plaintiff was released in late January of 2010 under minimal reporting requirements, and the other was released in late March of the same year, subject to electronic monitoring.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 27, 2008, two lawful permanent residents of the United States, Alexander Alli and Elliot Grenade, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of themselves and a class of similarly-situated persons.[SENTMARKER]The petitioners alleged that the DHS violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedures Act (APA), and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment by failing to provide them with a constitutionally adequate hearing to determine whether their continued detention is justified.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the petitioners' motion for a preliminary injunction, but denied their motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is a class action lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a South Carolina immigration law which requires state and local law enforcement officers to investigate the immigration status of any individual they stop, detain, or arrest whenever they have a "reasonable suspicion" that the individual lacks immigration status, allows law enforcement officers to arrest individuals solely for failing to carry registration documents, makes it a crime to harbor or transport an undocumented immigrant or to be harbored or transported by others if one is an undocumented immigrant, and imposes civil liability on the police for failing to enforce its provisions to the maximum extent possible.[SENTMARKER]The law was patterned after Arizona's SB 1070.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the law, and this injunction has been appealed to the Fourth Circuit; in the meantime, the case, along with several others like it from different states, are stayed at the District Court or U.S.[SENTMARKER]Appellate level pending the decision of the Supreme Court in United States v. Arizona.[SENTMARKER]After Arizona v. United States was decided the issue was remanded to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court left in place most of its original preliminary injunction, enjoining the state from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6 (B)(2).[SENTMARKER]The 4th Circuit per Judge Davis agreed and affirmed the order on July 13, 2013.[SENTMARKER]In March of 2014 Judge Gergel permanently enjoined South Carolina from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6(B)(2).[SENTMARKER]Furthermore the state agreed to more favorable interpretations of Section 7, and the remainder of Section, encouraging the Plaintiffs to dismiss their claims on those sections without prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2011, a group of individuals and advocacy groups filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina challenging South Carolina's comprehensive immigration law, Senate Bill 20 (Act 69) (S.C. Code  16-9-460,  17-13-170(B)(2), 16-13-480).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief to prevent serious harm that Plaintiffs and putative class members across the state will suffer if the law goes into effect.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction, finding that certain sections of the Act were preempted by federal immigration law and regulations.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Fourth Circuit, which remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On August 16, 2012, the Supreme Court of the United States issued its opinion in Arizona v. United States, 132 S Ct. 2492 (2012), in which it ruled that Arizona's immigration law was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On January 9, 2012, the District Court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened on August 16, 2012 and the parties filed a motion to re-open the case, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed without prejudice.

gold_sents: On December 15, 2006, a group of employees at Swift Beef Company's meat packing plants filed a class action lawsuit against their employer and related companies, alleging that Swift had engaged in a longstanding scheme of hiring undocumented immigrants for the express purpose of depressing employee wages, and that in furtherance of its scheme, Swift had recruited undocumented immigrants to work in its plants and assisted in providing them with fake immigration documents.[SENTMARKER]After the Court dismissed plaintiffs' illegal hiring claims as insufficiently specific and denied their motion for class certification, the parties stipulated for a dismissal with prejudice on June 18, 2009, and the case was terminated.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 17, 2007, a class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas on behalf of all persons legally authorized to be employed in the United States who had been employed as hourly wage earners at one of Swift Beef Company Inc.'s processing plants.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants engaged in a long-term pattern and practice of violating the Immigration Reform and Control Act and the Immigration and Nationality Act by knowingly hiring a workforce substantially com posed of illegal aliens.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they were harmed by Swift's conspiracy to depress the wages paid to its workers by hiring illegal aliens who did not have the legal right to work at the Swift facilities.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction, for failure to join necessary and indispensable parties, for lack standing, and for failing to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in part and denied in part on January 13, 2009, with each of the parties to bear their own costs and attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: This action challenged the Trump Administration's third attempt to suspend the United States Refugee Admissions Program.[SENTMARKER]On Nov. 29, 2017, this case was consolidated with Doe v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]29, 2017, this case was consolidated with Doe v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]Further updates on this case, which settled in 2019, may be found on the Doe page, available here.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 3, 2019, Jewish Family Service of Seattle, Jewish Family Services of Silicon Valley, and Advocates for Youth Mississippi Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the President of the United States, and the Director of National Intelligence (DNI) in connection with the President's Refugee Ban 3.0.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the President violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the First Amendment, and 23 the Fifth Amendment by suspending the USRAP and the follow-to-join process for Syrian refugees, among other things.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to dismiss the case within 60 days of the date of this judgment.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In August 2018, an inmate filed a civil class action lawsuit against the Pulaski County Jail (PCJ) and six PCJ officials in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, on behalf of himself and twenty-two other inmates, asked the court for monetary and injunctive relief, claiming that he and other inmates were being kept locked in their cells because the jail was not properly staffed.[SENTMARKER]On September 12, 2018, U.S. District Judge James Moody Jr. entered an initial order providing guidelines for proceeding pro se and finding that a request for class certification at this stage was premature; accordingly, he severed the case as twenty-three separate lawsuits.[SENTMARKER]Twenty-one of the other cases were eventually all dismissed without prejudice due to lack of prosecution by the other inmates.[SENTMARKER]This instant case and one other case (docket no. 4:18-cv-00552), which was also dismissed without prejudice due to lack of prosecution and reopened, are the only two ongoing cases out of the total twenty-three cases initially filed on this matter.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 20, 2018, a former inmate of the Pulaski County Detention Facility filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas, alleging that the defendants violated his civil rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by denying him access to a telephone during the one hour a day he was not on lockdown.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Defendants' policy and federal law mandate no more than 80 inmates per officer.[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2018, the case was dismissed, without prejudice, for lack of prosecution.[SENTMARKER]On March 7, 2019, the Plaintiff filed an amended complaint, adding President Donald Trump and Arkansas Governor Asa Hutchinson as defendants.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Plaintiff's Motion to Reopen, stating that he wished to pursue his case even though he was no longer incarcerated, and ordered him to file an amended Complaint.[SENTMARKER]The Clerk will be directed to reopen the case.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, 2019, the Court dismissed the case without prejudice.

gold_sents: In 2012, prisoners in the Los Angeles County Jails filed this is a class action in the US District Court for the Central District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged a long-standing and widespread pattern of violence and abuse by deputies against inmates and sought an injunction requiring training, supervision, and disciplinary policies for deputies.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties reached a settlement that required a detailed and far-reaching remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing with monitoring.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2012, two inmates of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the 6 Central District of California alleging that use of force against inmates in the L.A.[SENTMARKER]County Jails was disproportionately directed at inmates with mental illness.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were beaten and threatened with violence by sheriff's deputies and that they live in fear of deputy violence.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was implemented in the rest of the jail facilities effective November 1, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay reasonable attorneys' fees and costs to class counsel for ongoing work to ensure compliance with the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU's National Prison Project and the ACLU of Southern California already serve as class cotinsel for all prisoners in Los Angeles.

gold_sents: On February 29, 2016, two detainees with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit against San Bernardino County under § 1983, the ADA, and the Rehabilitation Act in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county violated the detainees' Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]In March 2018, the parties reached a settlement and proposed a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree on December 14, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case remains ongoing for enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 27, 2017, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against San Bernardino County, alleging that the county's jails violated the rights of inmates with disabilities by failing to accommodate them in its facilities, programs, and services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jails failed to provide them with timely medical treatment for their disabilities, denied or delayed access to psychiatrists, denied them access to dental services, and used excessive force against them.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which was entered on December 14, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the county to implement corrective measures to ensure that the conditions of confinement in the county jails do not violate the ADA, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, or other provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $25,000.[SENTMARKER]The court granted class certification on January 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties' motion for class certification was granted on January 28, 2019, and the consent decree is in effect for four years from the date it was entered.

gold_sents: On April 2, 2002, prisoners at the El Paso County Jail in Colorado Springs filed a class action lawsuit uagainst El Paso County, the Board of County Commissioners, and former and current Sheriffs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU, alleged that the jail failed to protect and adequately provide for prisoners with serious mental health needs, particularly in preventing suicides.[SENTMARKER]On June 28, 2006, Judge Richard P. pegasus_output_sents: On April 25, 2016, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against the Tennessee Department of Children's Services, the Rutherford County Juvenile Detention Center, and Rutherford County, Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by placing a juvenile pretrial detainee in solitary confinement without regard to his age or mental health status.[SENTMARKER]The court certified a class of all juveniles who were or were placed in solitary for disciplinary or punitive reasons, from April 25, 2015 to the present.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on April 25, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: (1) the defendants will not use solitary confinement as a form of punishment for minor rules violations; .[SENTMARKER](2) the parties will not place any juvenile detainees in isolation for more than 12 hours; .[SENTMARKER](3) the court will have final approval of the settlement agreement; and (4) the plaintiffs will be able to file a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
