gold_sents: On January 20, 2010, an employee of the federal judiciary married to her same-sex partner under California law filed a lawsuit against the federal Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, San Francisco Division, alleging that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) violates the Fifth Amendment by refusing to recognize lawful same-sex marriages for purposes of the laws governing spousal health benefits for federal employees, thereby denying her of a benefit that would be available to her if her spouse were of the opposite sex.[SENTMARKER]On February 22, 2012, the District Court granted summary judgment to the plaintiff, holding that the application of DOMA to deny spousal health benefits in this case did not have a rational basis and thus constituted a Fifth Amendment violation.[SENTMARKER]It entered a permanent injunction prohibiting the defendants from interfering with the enrollment of the plaintiff's wife in her family health benefits plan.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2012, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a petition in the Supreme Court for certiorari prior to judgment.[SENTMARKER]That petition was held without decision while the Court considered the California Prop.[SENTMARKER]8 case (PB-CA-0029 in this Clearinghouse) and Windsor, the DOMA case from the Second Circuit (PB-NY-0017 in this Clearinghouse), in which the Court granted review on December 7.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following the decision in Windsor holding § 3 of DOMA unconstitutional.

pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG | LAW ||| DATE | DATE ||| LAW | DATE [CONTRACTED] On August 30, 2019, two inmates of the Baltimore City Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against Wexford Health Sources, Inc., a private company that owns and operates the DPSCS facility in Baltimore City, Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were denied the opportunity to participate in pre-release programming, including home detention, work release, and "outside detail" because of their disabilities.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the defendants failed to engage competent medical service providers to oversee and administer the healthcare needs of prisoners committed to the custody of DPSCS.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment in part and denied the motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay a total of $1 million to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed not to appeal.

pegasus_output_sents: In 2007, two inmates at the Rivers Correctional Institute filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina on behalf of past, present and future prisoners who are dependent on the institution for medical, dental and mental health care.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that defendants GEO Group, Inc. gold_sents: On October 23, 2009, an individual plaintiff filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of New Jersey under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Hackensack Police Department, Hackensack Municipal Court, Bergen County Jail in the City of Hackensack, Bergen County Municipal Court, and Bergen County Prosecutor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, bringing suit pro se, sought compensatory and punitive damages plus special damages for future legal fees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff specifically claimed that the defendants violated his Second and Fourteenth Amendment rights by attempting to break in and enter his home, threatening to imprison him, fabricating stories to have him incarcerated, and asserting false criminal charges, which led to plaintiff spending three months and five days in county jail.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendant’s and plaintiff’s motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In Dec.[SENTMARKER]2014, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court’s decision to deny summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]Settlement discussions have since been unsuccessful and the case is ongoing in the district court, pending trial once public health conditions allow.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 23, 2009, a New Jersey resident filed a civil rights suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the Hackensack Police Department, the Hackensack Municipal Court, the Bergen County Jail, and the Bergen Regional Medical Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his civil rights by false arrest, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, and conspiracy.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the complaint on April 23, 2010, and the parties subsequently filed seven motions to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2010, the District Court granted in part and denied in part the motions.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, which the district court denied.[SENTMARKER]On April 23, 2013, the parties filed this interlocutory appeal, which was denied on April 24, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A deaf prison inmate who primarily communicates in American Sign Language filed a lawsuit under the Americans with Disabilities Act against the Oregon Department of Corrections, claiming they failed to communicate with him for over 14 years.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit claimed that, instead of providing interpreters, the prison made him train other inmates as his interpreters and they were not qualified to help him and were also privy to confidential information.[SENTMARKER]In May 2016, the Court granted partial summary judgment for the defendant.[SENTMARKER]Following a jury trial on the remaining claims, the Court dismissed the plaintiff's ADA claim for failure to exhaust administrative remedies under the PLRA.[SENTMARKER]The jury awarded the plaintiff $400,000 in noneconomic damages.[SENTMARKER]The Court awarded the plaintiff $683,873.13 in attorneys' fees, $18,155.19 in costs, and $3,924.79 in litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]Although both parties appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, they agreed to voluntarily dismiss their appeals in September 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2014, an inmate at Columbia River Correctional Institution (CRCI) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against the Oregon Department of Corrections (ODOC) alleging discrimination under Oregon Revised Statute  659A.142 (First Claim) and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)  12131–12165 (Second Claim).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that ODOC failed to provide him with accommodations for his hearing disability that would allow him to meaningfully participate in prison programs and services provided to inmates.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also alleged religious discrimination, disability discrimination, violations of the Federal Family and Medical Leave Act and Oregon Family Leave Act, workers' compensation discrimination, and common-law tort claims.[SENTMARKER]On June 6, 2014, the court dismissed the plaintiff's claims for injunctive relief, and his alleged emotional distress damages based on his Americans with Disability Act claim.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to settle the case for $450,000.

gold_sents: On November 10, 2011, the plaintiff--an Oregon Department of Corrections inmate-- filed this lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, in U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Oregon Department of Corrections violated his First Amendment free speech rights, his Fourteenth Amendment Due Process rights, and his Eighth Amendment right to be free of cruel and unusual punishment, when they rejected a return a letter written to another ODOC inmate because the envelope had a drawing on it.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2015, the District Court enjoined the challenged prison policy.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 10, 2011, an inmate of the Oregon Department of Corrections filed this civil rights action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon, alleging that the defendants violated his First Amendment free speech rights and his Fourteenth Amendment due process rights by rejecting his mail for containing artwork on the front of the envelope.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that defendants rejected his mail in retaliation for having filed a lawsuit against the New Mexico Corrections Department.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2013, the parties filed a motion for summary judgment and a stay of discovery.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a declaratory judgment that the defendant's policy violated the First Amendment rights of other inmates and their correspondents.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on February 10, 2014 and the parties entered a judgment in favor of the defendant.

gold_sents: The Disability Rights Network (DRN), a Pennsylvania non-profit, filed this Eighth Amendment suit against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) for the PDOC's use of solitary confinement with severely mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement for dismissal of the matter, in which the PDOC agreed to implement certain improvements and to pay $750,000 to DRN.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the PDOC will evaluate all incoming prisoners for serious mental illness, and will place prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement only in "exceptional" circumstances; even then, a prisoner with serious mental illness can be kept in solitary confinement for no longer than 30 days and must be allowed out of their cells for 20 hours per week.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a monitor to report on compliance, and will remain in effect for 3 years (less if the defendant demonstrates substantial compliance for a period of 18 months).[SENTMARKER]There has been no activity on the docket since May 2015 and the case is presumably closed since the three year time period set in the agreement has lapsed.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2013, the Disability Rights Network of Pennsylvania (DRN) filed a federal law suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (DOC) alleging that the DOC's treatment of prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement violates their rights under the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The DRN's complaint alleged that the treatment of these prisoners, who make up about 33% of the total RHU population, exacerbates their mental illness, but does not adequately take their mental health into account before disciplining them by placing them in long-term solitary confinement for extended periods of time.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants' policies and practices, including the practice of segregating them for long periods in RHUs, can cause grave harm to the mental and physical health of the prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a private settlement agreement on January 5, 2015, which required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with constitutionally adequate mental health care, provide them with access to mental health treatment, and protect them against dangerous and unconstitutional conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was signed by Judge Martin C. Carlson on May 24, 2015, and the parties agreed to file a Stipulation of Dismissal within twenty days of the execution of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]The deadline for the parties to file an answer to the settlement was September 19, 2015.[SENTMARKER]On September 19, 2015, Judge Susan E. Schwab entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: Incarcerated prisoners, Prison Radio, Human Rights Coalition, a network of educators, and Prison Legal News, filed these two consolidated lawsuits in the Middle District of Pennsylvania under 42 U.S.C.§ 1983 and Pennsylvania state law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the Penn.[SENTMARKER]Revictimization Relief Act--which banned certain public speeches by those convicted of crimes--violated their free speech rights.[SENTMARKER]The District Court agreed, striking down the law on April 2015.[SENTMARKER]Defendants elected not to appeal the judgment.[SENTMARKER]Since July 2015, there has been no activity on the docket and the case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 21, 2014, the Philadelphia City Paper, Pennsylvania Prison Society, Prison Legal News, and Solitary Watch filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections, the Pennsylvania Attorney General, and the Philadelphia County District Attorney alleging that the Revictimization Relief Act of 2014 violated the First and Fifth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, finding that the defendants had not violated the plaintiffs' due process and First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2013, a prisoner in Pennsylvania state prison filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that his 22 years of solitary confinement violated the Eighth Amendment as well as his Fourteenth Amendment right to due process.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the parties concluded successful mediation as a result of systemic changes to Pennsylvania's policies concerning solitary confinement and the case was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2013, a prisoner with serious mental illness and intellectual disabilities (SMI/ID) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (DOC) alleging that the use of solitary confinement on him violated his constitutional rights under the Eighth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act. According to the complaint, from June 1991 to January 1995, Shoatz was confined to a cell that exposed him to air temperature that is colder than the air temperature in the general prison population.[SENTMARKER]For the past 21 years, Shoatz has been subjected to a mandatory strip search and the possibility of a body-cavity search every time he leaves his cell.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleges that his prolonged years in solitary confinement deprived him of physical health and exercise.[SENTMARKER]In May 2013, the Department of Justice's Office of Special Litigation and the Office of the Attorney General's Special Litigation Section conducted a statewide investigation into the use and placement of solitary in the State Correctional Institution (SCI) in Cresson, Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The investigation found a pattern of constitutional violations and violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), as well as violations of PDOC's solitary confinement policies.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ's investigation was conducted by David J. Hickton and supervised by Cynthia Reed Eddy.[SENTMARKER]The case is being handled by John E. Wetzel.

pegasus_output_sents: This is a suit for declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of a class of inmates in Virginia's prisons whose constitutional rights are being violated by the practices, policies and procedures of the Virginia Parole Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that the parole board's practices and procedures violate their constitutional rights with respect to discretionary parole.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case, but the case was appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court upheld the district court's dismissal of the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2015, the plaintiff filed this in the U.S. District Court of Vermont alleging disability-based discrimination while incarcerated.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory, injunctive, compensatory, and punitive relief and the judge dismissed the matter after the parties reached a full settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 7, 2016, Disability Rights Vermont filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Vermont against the State of Vermont, the Department of Corrections, and the Vermont Department of Aging and Independent Living (DAIL) under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Vermont Fair Housing and Public Accommodations Act (VFHPAA) against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants willfully and knowingly caused Plaintiff to be held in unnecessarily segregated circumstances when he would be eligible for community placement if the appropriate, State-funded available community supports and services were implemented.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff was diagnosed with schizo-affective disorder and depression, among other diagnoses, and was serving a minimum sentence at the Southern State Correctional Facility in Springfield, Vermont.[SENTMARKER]On information and belief, Plaintiff would have been eligible for State and federal funded community supports, such as Choices for Care (CFC) and Community Rehabilitation Treatment (CRT) services, if released from incarceration.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff has been held in prison despite facts and circumstances demonstrating that he is eligible for release into the community but for a lack of community-based supports funded by Defendants.[SENTMARKER]On June 6, 2016, Judge William K. Sessions III entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants, requiring the defendants to implement a system in place to identify and implement appropriate disability-related supports in the community to prevent continued, unnecessary and harmful institutionalization.

gold_sents: In 2016, current and former public housing residents filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged rampant discrimination on the basis of race and family status, rent overcharges, and a failure to maintain rental units.[SENTMARKER]After participating in settlement conferences, the plaintiffs agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice and without costs in July 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 13, 2017, a group of current and former residents of the Alexander County Housing Authority (ACHA) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois against ACHA and its Board and Executive Directors for violating the Fair Housing Act and the Illinois Civil Rights Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ACHA discriminated against residents of its McBride and Elmwood family housing developments based on their race and familial status, in violation of Title VI of the Civil rights Act of 1964, and the fair housing act. ACHA has refused to place families with children in certain public housing developments, such as Connell Smith, in order to prevent African American families from living in majority white public housing.[SENTMARKER]In 1974, the Department of Justice sued ACHA for intentionally segregating its two main public housing complexes by race.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was eventually settled, and ACHA agreed to stop segregation of its housing based on race.[SENTMARKER]However, for at least the past ten years, ACHA, through its Executive Directors, have implemented a rule prohibiting family with children from living on the same floor as other families, and improperly reserved them for seniors and people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The defendants were warned that failure to comply with the court's order could result in dismissal of their claims for want of prosecution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: The NAACP and individual people sued the city of San Jose and political officials for policing tactics that allegedly deprived them of their First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, protesting systemic racism in policing, alleged that the police used excessive force in a racially motivated manner to end the protests.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 29, 2020, the San Jose Peace and Justice Center (SJPJC) filed this civil rights class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the City of San Jose and the San José Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The SJPJC alleged that the defendants violated the plaintiffs' First Amendment rights by imposing an unlawful city-wide curfew on a group of demonstrators protesting the police killing of George Floyd on May 29, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that police officers used racial and religious slurs against one of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, injunctive relief, and monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 7, 2020, and the parties agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: This is a lawsuit brought by several black activist groups, legal organizations, and news media outlets, against the heads of various federal agencies, including the DHS, ICE, Federal Protective Services, and the DOJ.[SENTMARKER]They argued that the deployment to Chicago of these federal agencies by President Trump during the protests that ensued after the police killing of George Floyd were unlawful and unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]They argued that the defendants violated the First, Fourth, and Tenth Amendments by using these agents, and that they were in conspiracy to deprive Chicago residents of their rights.[SENTMARKER]When Joe Biden replaced Donald Trump as President, the change in administration mooted the case.[SENTMARKER]It was voluntarily dismissed by the plaintiffs in January 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: In June, the National Lawyers Guild Chicago, Black America, Washington Baltimore News Guild, CWA Local 32035, and First Defense Legal Aid filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Department of Justice (DOJ), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) alleging that federal law enforcement in Portland violated the First, Fourth, and Tenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the federal agents violated their First Amendment rights by sending infiltrators to surveil protest groups and using technology to spy on the communications of protesters and organizers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were subjected to constitutional violations by the defendants, including but not limited to violations of their First and Fourth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The district court in Portland denied the Oregon Attorney General’s motion for a temporary restraining order on standing grounds, Rosenblum, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: Individuals issued summonses by the NYPD without probable cause brought a class action suit against the City of New York.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the NYPD's 'quota' policy is linked to officer promotion and demotion, and as a result, leads to commanding officers ordering police officers to arrest and issue summonses to individuals without probable cause, in contravention of the federal and state constitutions.[SENTMARKER]Judge Sweet, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, granted the case class action status in April 2012.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2017, Judge Sweet preliminary approved the parties' settlement agreement, in which the parties agreed to settlement benefits of up to seventy-five million dollars.[SENTMARKER]On April 18, 2017, the court granted final approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing for compliance purposes.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 25, 2010, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York City Police Department (NYPD) and Raymond W. Kelly (together with the City) alleging that the NYPD violated the constitutional rights of New Yorkers by issuing criminal summonses returnable to the NYPD without probable cause in response to pressure to meet alleged quotas and by failing to train, discipline, or supervise officers regarding their obligation not to issue summonses without a constitutional basis.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were New York customers of defendant Best Buy who were refused a "price match" at the defendant's store.[SENTMARKER]The class is defined to include individuals who were issued summonses that were later dismissed upon a judicial finding of facial insuff iency and who were ticketed without a probable cause.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 23, 2017, in which the parties agreed to pay $18,500 for attorneys' fees and costs, subject to Court approval.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is non-collusive.

gold_sents: On August 28, 1997, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the City of Steubenville pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §14141 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio to remedy an alleged pattern or practice of unconstitutional misconduct by officers of the Steubenville Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into consent decree contemporaneously with filing the complaint.[SENTMARKER]Monitoring and reporting continued into 2005, when the parties filed and the court granted a joint motion for termination.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 3, 1997, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio entered a Consent Decree in the case of United States v. City of Steubenville, et al., C2-97-966.[SENTMARKER]City of Steubenville, et al., C2-97-966.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the City to develop and implement an extensive training policy for all of its police officers as well as an internal affairs policy for the hiring of a future police chief.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment in part, holding that there were genuine issues of material fact on the warrantless-entry and false-arrest claims.[SENTMARKER]On March 3, 2005, the District Court ordered the termination of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On May 8, 2006, the defendants moved for summary judgement on all of the plaintiffs' claims.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion in part.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to dismiss, claiming that the relief sought by the plaintiffs was in direct contradiction to the terms of the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on May 8, 2006.

gold_sents: In July 2008, the plaintiffs sued the City of Tenaha under the Fourth Amendment (unreasonable search and seizure) and the Fourteenth Amendment (equal protection).[SENTMARKER]They claimed that law enforcement officials in and around the City of Tenaha have developed an illegal practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from people who appeared to be non-white or who were traveling with non-white passengers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that they had been victims of such stops and seizures of amounts up to $50,000, as well as false prosecution or detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]Their proposed consent decree included: video and audio recordings of all stops; written documentation with details of the stop; no more dog searches in routine traffic stops; written and oral consent for a search; all asset forfeiture revenue must be donated to nonprofits or used for audio/video equipment or training; and use of an impartial monitor.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree, which it later extended to early 2021 after the plaintiffs alleged noncompliance by the City.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas on behalf of African-American drivers in Shelby County, Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from individuals who are, or appear to be, members of a racial or ethnic minority and their passengers violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The parties negotiated and agreed to a consent decree in August 2012 to end the alleged racial profiling.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provided remedies for the plaintiffs' complaints and required the defendants to make audio and video recordings of all traffic stops and all searches, seizures, detentions, and arrests that result from traffic stops.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree were preliminarily approved by the court on August 8, 2013 and the parties entered into an interlocal agreement with Shelby County Precinct Constables Zack Warr (Pct.)[SENTMARKER]to implement an impartial policing policy.[SENTMARKER]The court stayed its ruling on the motion for class certification pending the Supreme Court's ruling in Wal-Mart the interdiction program.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2021, the ACLU and private counsel brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California in response to President Trump’s June 11, 2020 Executive Order authorizing economic sanctions against individuals who assist the International Criminal Court in investigating or prosecuting war crimes.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and §706 of the Administrative Procedure Act. They sought declaratory relief and an injunction that would prevent the Trump Administration from implementing or enforcing the Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 15, 2020, the ACLU filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the United States government, the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), President Donald J. Trump, Secretary of State Michael R. Pompeo, and Director of OFAC Andrea M. Gacki, challenging the imposition of sanctions against two senior International Criminal Court (ICC) officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the sanctions violated their First Amendment rights by prohibiting their constitutionally protected speech with the ICC.[SENTMARKER]The case is being handled by the ACLU's San Francisco office.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, and the case was assigned to Judge Charles R. Breyer.[SENTMARKER]Judge Breyer granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that the Executive Order, Designations, and Regulations were not narrowly tailored to achieve a compelling governmental objective.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a declaratory judgment enjoining the defendants from implementing or enforcing the executive order and the regulations, and a permanent injunction enjoining them from imposing civil or criminal penalties against the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the plaintiffs' request for a temporary restraining order.

gold_sents: The Alliance Party and two third-party presidential sued the District of Columbia Board of Elections.[SENTMARKER]The D.C. city government had lowered the signatures required for ballot qualification from 5,007 to 250 on August 6, 2020, the day after petitions to appear on the ballot were due.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs contended that they had ceased collecting signatures because it was "impossible" to collect 5,007 signatures while adhering to social distancing guidelines, but would have continued their efforts if they knew they only had to get 250.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied a motion for temporary restraining order, the 2020 election was held and this case was dismissed soon after.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2020, the Alliance Party of the District of Columbia filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District, alleging that the District violated the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights of third-party presidential candidates by lowering the signature requirement to secure access to the District's 2020 general election presidential ballot.[SENTMARKER]The District reduced the signature requirements for candidates for elective office in the District from the lesser of 3,000 signatures or 1.5% of all registered voters to a flat 250 signature requirement in response to the World Health Organization's global pandemic of COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]The Alliance Party's complaint alleged that the reduced signature requirement violated the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the United States Constitution and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief and an emergency temporary restraining order, but denied the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2015, residents of Jefferson County, Florida filed this action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county's 2013 redistricting plan was guilty of "prison-based gerrymandering," and was thus guilty of violating the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought and received a declaration that the 2013 plan was unconstitutional as well as an injunction requiring the defendants to produce an acceptable redistricting plan.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' plan was approved and parties then settled on the attorneys' fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 22, 1983, a group of residents of Jefferson County, Florida filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida against the Jefferson County Board of Commissioners and Jefferson County School Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county's 2013 redistricting plan violated the Fourteenth Amendment right to equal representation under the "one person, one vote" principle of the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief, an injunction preventing Defendants from conducting elections for the Boards under the current scheme, and an injunction against the use of county-wide atlarge elections in a manner that violates the Voting Rights Act, ECF No. 52-1, at 7; .<n>The parties have not resolved issues to the timetable for implementation of the five single-member district election plan and the parties will attempt to resolve the attorney fees and litigation expense reimbursement issue.[SENTMARKER]On March 19, 2016, the Court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Several citizens and residents of Arizona subject to the death penalty brought suit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 against the Arizona Department of Corrections (ADC) and several associated governmental employees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the ADC's lethal injection procedure violated their First Amendment right to access governmental proceedings, the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Eighth Amendment, and the Federal Supremacy Clause.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a stipulated agreement prohibiting the defendant from using certain chemicals for execution, among other limitation.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing after the Ninth Circuit remanded counts for retrial.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 26, 2014, six death-row inmates filed this 42 U.S.C.  1983 action in the United States District Court for the District of Arizona, seeking equitable, injunctive, and declaratory relief under the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Arizona's lethal injection procedures violated the Constitution's due process rights.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to stay the litigation until the Arizona Department of Corrections published a set of revised execution procedures.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court vacated the district court's denial of the inmates' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2012, plaintiffs filed suit in the Eastern District of Michigan, alleging that the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA), when applied retroactively, violated their rights to due process, was unconstitutionally vague, violated prohibitions on ex post facto laws, and violated their fundamental rights.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, upon remand from the Sixth Circuit, the district court held that SORA violated the Ex Post Facto clause and could not be applied retroactively.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 24, 2015, two deaf inmates of the Kentucky State Penitentiary (KSP) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky against the Kentucky Department of Corrections (KDOC) alleging that the KDOC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide telecommunications services to deaf and hard-of-hearing inmates.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the failure to provide videophone services to the inmates violated their rights under the ADA and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 (RLUIPA).[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on April 27, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would provide deaf inmates with access to telephone communications.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide the inmates with hearing aid earphones.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on April 27.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In January 2015, the plaintiff, a prisoner, filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania, alleging that the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections systematically denied medical care to individuals with severe eye conditions, including severe cataracts, in violation of the ADA, § 504, and his Eighth Amendment right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the Department of Corrections changed their cataract policy, no longer denying surgery to individuals who had "One Good Eye."
pegasus_output_sents: On January 2, 1983, a prisoner in the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (DOC) filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania on behalf of inmates with severe eye conditions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DOC systematically denied necessary medical care for inmates with serious eye conditions including severe cataracts, thereby condemning them to partial or total blindness.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, despite repeated recommendations for cataract surgery by his doctors, the DOC's "One Good Eye" policy, which denies surgical treatment in a diseased eye if an inmate has some vision in the other eye, discriminates against individuals with physical eye impairments on the basis of their disability.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief to eliminate Defendants' actions, policies, and practices which infringe their rights.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the DOC agreed to provide post-operative treatment for each inmate undergoing cataract surgery in accordance with the outside ophthalmologist's recommendation, including follow-up examinations, refraction for new glasses, and laser and surgical procedures to address any postoperative complications.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the DOC to inform its staff, and outside medical providers, of its new cataract surgery policy and to inform potential Affected Inmates of the New Cataract Policy.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2011, eight students in the Mobile County Public School System (MCPS) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Alabama against the Board of School Commissioners of Mobile County (the "Board").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Board violated their Fourteenth Amendment rights to due process by imposing long-term suspensions on students without providing even the reduced due process required by the District's challenged policy.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, attorney's fees, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in June 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the School System would provide reasonable career preparation assistance and assistance with the graduation exam for the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2017, four low-income African American mothers filed suit against the numerous officials of the State of Mississippi claiming the state failed to live up to the educational requirements set by the Mississippi Readmission Act of 1870.[SENTMARKER]They sought declaratory relief that the requirements are still intact.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in 2018 due to the state sovereign immunity under the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit which affirmed in part and reversed in part.[SENTMARKER]The defendants requested rehearing en banc, but the Fifth Circuit denied the request.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a petition for review with the Supreme Court and a request to stay the Fifth Circuit's mandate in January 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi on behalf of low-income African-American women whose children attend public schools in Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state had violated the federal education clause of the Mississippi Constitution by amending the education clause after its ratification following the Civil War.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case on several grounds, including the political question doctrine, the Mississippi Readmission Act, and the lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The Third and Fourth Circuits both held that these claims were barred by the Eleventh Amendment and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the plaintiffs moved for leave to amend their complaint to cure the pleading defects that they believe resulted in the dismissal of this case.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened and the district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for re-opening of the case.[SENTMARKER]On January 10, 2019, the plaintiffs filed a motion to amend the complaint to include a private right of action.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case under 12(b)(1) and (b)(6) of the Federal Rule of Civil Procedure.[SENTMARKER]The court granted defendants’ motion for sovereign immunity, holding that it lacked jurisdiction based on Eleventh Amendment sovereign immunity for all further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed an amended motion to dismiss, which was granted by the court on January 11, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee on June 6, 2006 against Whirlpool Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that an African-American female employee was subjected to racial and sexual harassment by a co-worker because of her sex and race, Black, and that her complaints to her supervisors were ignored by the employer.[SENTMARKER]The court awarded total damages in the amount of $1,073,261.00 in front pay and back pay and $300,000.00 in compensatory damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a Motion to Alter or Amend the Judgment, which was denied on March 31, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently filed a motion to dismiss the case on June 12, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on July 27, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a final judgment in favor of the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2018 two US Airmen under pseudonym and OutServe-SLDN, a network of LGBTQ military service-people, filed suit against the U.S. Department of Defense, James Mattis, and Heather Wilson in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs argued that the U.S had violated equal protection under the fifth amendment and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented by Winston and Strawn LLP, LAMBDA Legal Defense and Education Fund, and Outserve-SLDN (now known as the Modern Military Association of America) sought declaratory and injunctive relief allowing HIV positive service members to continue to serve and damages.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that they were discharged from their duties in the Air Force due to their HIV status.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Leonie M. Brinkema.[SENTMARKER]On January 11, 2019, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction to  prevent the defendants from restricting Roe and Voe and others similarly situated from being promoted, changing duty station, or re-training on the same terms as other service members living with HIV who are not being separated.[SENTMARKER]A hearing was held before Judge Brinkema on February 15, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The same day, Judge Brinkema issued an opinion granting in part and denying in part the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendants from separating or dicharging from military service Richard Roe, Victor Voe, and any other similarly situated active-duty member of the Air Force because they are classified as ineligible for worldwide deployment or deployment to the United States Central Command area due to their HIV-positive status.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the decision on the preliminary injunction to the Fourth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]Oral argument was held on September 18, 2019 before a panel of Fourth Circuit Judges comprised of Judges James A. Wynn Jr, Albert Diaz, and Henry F. Floyd.[SENTMARKER]In January 2020, the Fourth Circuit issued an opinion affirming the district court's decision.[SENTMARKER]In the district court, both parties have filed motions for summary judgment, and oral argument is set for August 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 27, 2020, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia granted a preliminary injunction against the Department of Defense (DoD) and the Secretary of the Air Force (Air Force) in a case brought by a non-profit organization representing the interests of veterans, active-duty servicemembers, and civilian employees of the DoD who are LGBTQ+ or HIV positive.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case for lack of standing, arguing that OutServe lacked standing to sue.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss in part and denied the government's motion for preliminary injunction in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties then appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court upheld the district court's decision to grant the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission brought an anti-discrimination lawsuit against United Airlines.[SENTMARKER]The claim was that United Airlines discriminated against its employees when it denied employees with disabilities a reduced hours schedule as an accommodation.[SENTMARKER]On December 17, 2010, the court approved a consent decree which required United Airlines to consider a reduced-hours schedule as a reasonable accommodation for employees with disabilities and awarded the plaintiff $600,000 in damages.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was set to terminate three years from date of entry unless the EEOC asked for a continuation.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed, as there are no further activity on this case's docket as of March 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: The EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against United Air Lines, Inc. (UAL) on behalf of four reservation sales and service representatives (' Charging Parties') who were employed by UAL as Reservations Sales and Service Representatives (' RSSRs') in the District of Hawaii.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that UAL's policy and practice of requiring charging parties to work a minimum of 30 hours per week and to work at least five days per week violated the Americans with Disabilities Act ('ADA').[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree ('Conviction Decree') on June 10, 2008 to resolve the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The Decree required UAL to provide reasonable accommodation to the charging parties and similarly situated individuals in the form of reduced work schedules of less than thirty (30) hours and five (5) days per weeks.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the parties a total of $600,000 in damages and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is final and binding upon the parties to it, their successors 27 and assigns.[SENTMARKER]In light of the Ninth Circuit's mandate issued on October 6, 2009, the parties are directed to file a Joint Status Report by November 20, 2010.[SENTMARKER]In all such cases, United will engage in the interactive.[SENTMARKER]United will pennit reduced-hours schedules as accommodations for 16 qualified individuals with disabilities when and to the extent they constitute reasonable 17 accommodations and do not impose any undue hardship on the Company.

gold_sents: Private citizens sought an exception to the Affordable Care Act mandate requiring employers to provide contraception coverage on that basis that paying for this insurance plan violated their Catholic religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On October 16, 2013, the Eastern District of Missouri (Judge Jean C. Hamilton) dismissed the claim for want of standing, but on July 20, 2015, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed and remanded for merits decision.[SENTMARKER]Judge Hamilton dismissed all but one of the plaintiff's claims but granted summary judgment in favor of the plaintiff on that claim, enjoining the defendants from requiring the plaintiffs to pay for contraception through their insurance.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed this determination, but following President Trump's May 4, 2017 executive order directing a change in regulations to allow for conscience-based exceptions to the contraceptive-care mandate, the parties agreed to have the case dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 20, 2013, a Missouri couple filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 (ACA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HHS's enforcement or threatened enforcement of the mandate violated their religious rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 (RFRA), the First and Fifth Amendments to the United States Constitution, and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the complaint with prejudice, concluding that the plaintiffs had not met their burden to establish standing.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

gold_sents: On May 17, 2018, the plaintiff, a catholic foster care and social services agency, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the City of Philadelphia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City's decision to stop referring foster care discriminated against them for their religious beliefs and violated their contract, constitutional rights, and state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 13, 2018, Judge Petrese B. Tucker denied the plaintiffs motion for a preliminary injunction holding that the City of Philadelphia was entitled to suspend the contract for violations of the City Fair Ordinance which prohibited discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed on the same day, and the Third Circuit affirmed the lower court's decision on April 22, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing, and the Supreme Court granted the plaintiff's petition for writ of certiorari on February 24, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 22, 2019, Catholic Social Services (CSS) filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the City of Philadelphia, alleging that the city's Fair Practices Ordinance (FPO) violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The FPO prohibits discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion for preliminary injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, and the Third Circuit affirmed the district court's denial of the defendants’ motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs challenged a city ordinance prohibiting residents from living in trailers or homes worth less than $7500.[SENTMARKER]Less than a week after plaintiffs filed their complaint suit, the City changed the ordinance and eliminated the provision at issue.[SENTMARKER]Ultimately the parties settled outside of court for roughly $20,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2016, the City Council of the City of McCrory passed an ordinance prohibiting the placement of mobile homes within the City unless the owners show at their own cost that the trailers have a value of at least $7,500.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas, alleging that the City's wealth-based banishment scheme violated the Fourteenth Amendment and the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for a declaratory and injunctive injunction, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In August 2017, the Department of Housing and Urban Development (“HUD”) abruptly announced it would delay, by two years, a rule designed to allow low-income families greater choice in their housing options.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs argued that HUD’s failure to implement the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act, and they sought a preliminary injunction, which was granted.[SENTMARKER]HUD then agreed to implement the rule and paid the Plaintiffs' attorney's fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 15, 2018, a group of low-income housing voucher holders and a nonprofit organization filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and HUD Secretary Ben Carson, alleging that HUD's decision to suspend implementation of its own promulgated rule, the Small Area Fair Market Rent Rule (Small Area FMR Rule), violated the Fair Housing Act of 1968 and the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 (HCD).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction requiring HUD to implement the Rule on its effective date of January 1, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, finding that the two-year delay of the Rule's implementation was arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought in Indiana federal court and in Michigan federal court by the United States against the developers, builders, and operators of rental apartment complexes in Indiana, Michigan, Illinois, Ohio, Wisconsin, and Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The plantiff claimed the defendants had designed and built apartments that are not accessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree that resulted calls for millions of dollars in retrofits to apartments in six different states, and compensatory damages in the amount of $1,060,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 18, 2001, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a civil action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Indiana against Edward Rose Development Co. and its affiliates alleging that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by failing to include accessible features required by the Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act in a number of apartment complexes it developed in Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, Wisconsin, Illinois, Virginia, and Nebraska.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Eastern District of Michigan and the parties entered a consent order on September 30, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Under the consent order, the defendants will retrofit 49 apartment complexes to enhance their accessibility to individuals with physical disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The consent order will remain in effect for five years.[SENTMARKER]In the event the parties cannot resolve their differences, any party may move the Court for an order compelling compliance with the Consent Order or for attorney's fees and costs.

gold_sents: On September 28, 2020, the Massachusetts Fair Housing Center and Housing Works, Inc. filed a complaint against the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Secretary of HUD in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the defendants under the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 702-703, alleging that a new HUD rule (“the 2020 Rule”) limiting disparate impact claims under the Fair Housing Act was contrary to law and arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought to enjoin the defendants from implementing the 2020 Rule until after this case was resolved and filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on October 6, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs’ motion on October 25, 2020, finding that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claim that the 2020 Rule was arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 28, 2020, the Massachusetts Fair Housing Center and Housing Works, Inc. filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) alleging that HUD's implementation of the Fair Housing Act's Disparate Treatment Standard (disparate impact standard) violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Equal Access to Justice Act (E.A.J.).[SENTMARKER]The parties sought a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief, seeking to vacate a new rule promulgated by HUD on September 24, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties alleged that the new rule violated the APA's notice and comment requirements.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for preliminary and stay of the effective date of the 2020 Rule on October 6, 2020, and issued a preliminary injunction on September 29, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2020, the parties filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied by the First Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The parties are appealing the decision, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 31, 2006, in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky, DOJ simultaneously filed a CRIPA complaint against the state and a settlement agreement between the parties, the latter referencing and attaching the strategic action plan obligating the state to implement remedial measures at the Oakwood Developmental Center.[SENTMARKER]The court monitored implementation of the agreement until 2011, when the case was closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2001, the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky against the Commonwealth of Kentucky and Oakwood Developmental Center, a facility for persons with developmental disabilities located in Somerset, Kentucky.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to protect their residents from harm due to abuse and mistreatment and failed to maintain a safe environment at the facility.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants did not provide sufficient physical therapy services to residents in need of such services.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also failed to provide adequate preventative medical care designed to keep serious medical problems and disease from developing.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 29, 2011 by Judge Karen K. Caldwell.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement and maintain a Strategic Action Plan ("SAP"), which details methods by which the Commonwealth will operate Oakwood and provide services to its residents.[SENTMARKER]The SAP is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On June 7, 2007, attorneys with the Southern Poverty Law Center filed a class action lawsuit in the U. S.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Western District of Arkansas on behalf of about 2,700 Mexican migrant workers who entered the United States with H-2A visas and harvested and packed tomatoes and performed other agricultural work in Bradley County, Ark., from 2002 to 2007.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the employers violated the Fair Labor Standards Act ("FLSA"), 29 U.S.C. § 201 et seq. by failing to pay the prevailing wage and overtime wages, and not reimbursing workers for travel, visa and hiring fees.[SENTMARKER]On May 20, 2011, the Court (Judge Harry F. Barnes) granted summary judgment for the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]Later, the parties reached a settlement agreement, and a final version of the agreement was approved by the Court on April 9, 2012, requiring the defendants to pay $1,212,500 in damages and attorney fees to plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]Defendants breached this agreement and the Court entered judgment against them on September 4, 2013.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 31, 2008, a group of Mexican workers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Arkansas against Arkansas Tomato Shippers, LLC (Candy Brand) alleging violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and the federal common law of contracts.[SENTMARKER]The workers alleged that Candy Brand violated the FLSA by failing to pay them minimum and overtime wages when they worked more than 40 hours in a work week in Defendants' packing shed operations.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the workers claimed that the defendants failed to pay the workers properly for their return travel at the end of the season, and did not pay them "subsistence pay" for the days they spent traveling.[SENTMARKER]On December 29, 2011, the court granted preliminary approval to a settlement agreement between the workers and Candy Brand.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay $1,215,500 to the workers as part of the settlement, which was subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The class action was certified as a FLSA collective action with respect to the minimum wage and overtime claims, and a Rule 23 class action with regard to the breach of contract claims.[SENTMARKER]The court conditionally certified the case as a collective action on October 31, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment in August 2010, and the parties filed another motion for class action certification in August 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a final settlement agreement in August 2011, which was approved by the court on December 29, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The final settlement is subject to the court's approval.

gold_sents: On August 31, 2010, hourly employees sued their employer under federal and state employment and non-discrimination statutes for requiring plaintiffs to work as many as fourteen hours a day without compensating them with mandatory overtime pay.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs dismissed their federal claims in order to participate in a civil action filed by the U.S. Department of Labor against defendants and the court declined to exercise supplemental jurisdiction over plaintiffs' state law claims.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 21, 2010, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against Terra Universal, Inc. and George Sadaghiani for violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and the California Business and Professions Code (B&P).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were required to work as many as 14 hours a day without overtime pay and, in some cases, without any payment of wages.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the defendants deprived them and other class members of overtime pay on account of their immigration status.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a stipulation to dismiss the case on April 14, 2011 and the case was transferred to the Southern Division of the Court on April 18, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to court approval.

gold_sents: A class-action lawsuit on behalf of people facing deportation proceedings, who are detainees at facilities contracted by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, resulted in a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff-detainees alleged that ICE restricted their telephone access, violating their rights under the First, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments and the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement included provisions for longer access to free and private phone calls in a timely manner, as well as attorneys’ fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2014, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and its parent agency, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) alleging that ICE did not provide adequate telephone access for immigration detainees housed in Contra Costa West County Detention Facility, Yuba County Jail, Rio Cosumnes Correctional Center, and Mesa Verde Detention Facility.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the cost of phone calls was unreasonably expensive, particularly as many detainees were indigent.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in which the parties agreed to pay $405,000 to class counsel to settle claims for attorneys' fees and costs incurred in this litigation.[SENTMARKER]The settlement will be in effect for four years after that.

gold_sents: On June 4, 2013, plaintiffs, natives of Mexico who had agreed to voluntary departure from the United States, filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Central District of California under the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA"), 8 U.S.C. §1101, and state law against the acting director of Homeland Security, U.S. Customs and Border Protection ("CBP") and Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement ("ICE").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant's agencies in southern California violated INA by coercing plaintiffs into accepting voluntary departure through misstatements, omissions, threats, and/or pressure in violation of defendants' own regulations.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on March 11, 2015, where defendants agreed to allow applications from the class members that would enable their return to the United States and their legal position prior to acceptance of voluntary departure.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 4, 2013, a group of individuals and three non-profit organizations filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Bureau of Immigration and Custome Enforcement (ICE) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Administrative Procedure Act and the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHS and ICE's voluntary departure program for foreign nationals who were present in the United States without permission deprived the deportees of their rights under federal statutes and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed that the parties would not enforce any of the terms of the agreement until the case was settled.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 11, 2013, before the parties could file a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]On November 5, 2013, the parties filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, which was denied by Judge Abrams.[SENTMARKER]On April 25, 2014, the parties held a settlement conference and the parties reached an agreement.[SENTMARKER]On May 23, 2014, Judge Abrams entered a final judgment in favor of the class.

gold_sents: On July 10, 2018, the ACLU of Northern California filed this FOIA suit against U.S. Immigrations and Customs Enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought records pursuant to a FOIA request about the defendant's use of a contractor to process and transport immigration detainees, some of whom had allegedly suffered injury and death due to the contractor's malfeasance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought an order from the court that the defendant provide the records.[SENTMARKER]This case was combined with a suit from a private plaintiff alleging mistreatment in ICE and G4S custody in July 2019.[SENTMARKER]Document production appears to be continuing smoothly at a rate of 750 pages per month, but shifting production online due to COVID-19 has yielded some issues in getting documents over to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]Document production is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2017, the ACLU of Northern California filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking information about the treatment of immigration detainees in ICE's San Francisco Area of Responsibility (ACLU-NC).[SENTMARKER]The ACLU-NC and a local newspaper filed a FOIA request to ICE seeking records about the use of private contractors to transport detainees in the San Francisco area.[SENTMARKER]ICE has not complied with the FOIA requests, and has not produced a single document in response to either the First FOIA 15 Request or the Second FOIA Request.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the ACLU's motion for partial summary judgment and ordered ICE to produce the requested records.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU is seeking injunctive and declaratory relief against ICE for its unlawful withholding of government documents pertaining to the subject of 13 FOIA requests.

gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 13, 2020, the State of California filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for rescinding the in-person learning exemption for F-1 and M-1 nonimmigrant students.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the rescission of the exemption violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) because it was arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the State's motion for declaratory, injunctive, and other relief, and granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint motion for summary judgment on July 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed on the same or similar grounds.[SENTMARKER]On August 4, 2020, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the State, and the parties agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: On July 20, 2010, the American Immigration Lawyers Association (AILA) filed suit against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for failing to adequately respond to FOIA requests regarding USCIS procedures for inspecting potential H-1B visa fraud.[SENTMARKER]On March 30, 2012, the District Court ordered DHS to provide adequate description of the exempted information in response to the FOIA request so that AILA could make a proper segregability determination.[SENTMARKER]This was the last action in this case.
pegasus_output_sents: The American Immigration Lawyers Association filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its component, the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) seeking the release of records concerning agency policies and procedures relating to nonimmigrant temporary workers and the adjudication of petitions for their lawful employment in the US.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to comply with the FOIA by failing to disclose the responsive records, failing to segregate non-exempt information from allegedly exempt information, and failing to release the records in their entirety pursuant to FOIA exemptions.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory, injunctive, and other appropriate relief with respect to the unlawful withholding of these records by the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, seeking summary judgment as to the entirety of their searches and subsequent responses to plaintiff’s FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment and denied the defendants’ request for expedited processing.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Central American mothers and children detainees brought suit against the Department of Homeland Security and its various agencies for the government's unlawful expedited removal policies at the Artesia Family Residential Center.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case in January 2015 after DHS remedied the violations of Plaintiffs' rights in their immigration proceedings and closed the Artesia facility.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2014, a mother and her two daughters from El Salvador and Honduras filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking relief under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Equal Access to Justice Act (E.A.J.).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government's new expedited removal policies and procedures make it much more difficult for detained women and children to present and substantiate their claims to asylum or other forms of immigration relief, and to seek the assistance of counsel in doing so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that they were denied access to legal materials in Spanish in the Artesia Family Residential Center in New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on January 30, 2015 without prejudice.

gold_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents separated from their children filed a civil action against various federal agencies and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for immediate reunification with their children.The plaintiffs were detained after crossing the United States-Mexico border without inspection with young accompanying children, seeking asylum.[SENTMARKER]After plaintiffs were apprehended at the border, the children were separated under the “zero-tolerance” immigration policy announced April 6, 2018, which criminally prosecuted adult entrants crossing the border illegally and placed accompanying minors in custody of the government.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs crossed the border prior to the Executive Order issued on June 20, 2018, which allowed immigrant parents and children apprehended at the border to remain together during the pendency of their proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged interference of family integrity in violation of Due Process, and sought preliminary and permanent injunctions to immediately reunite plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs obtained preliminary relief and were (along with another parent who joined the case later to prevent separation from her daughter) ultimately re-united with their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents who were separated from their young children filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and certain federal agencies and officials responsible for enforcing immigration laws and regulations.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction requiring the government to immediately reunify children under the age of five with their parents by July 10, 2018, and those age five and over by July 26, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a TRO in abeyance on July 5, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On July 16, 2018, the court granted plaintiffs' TRO with respect to certain outstanding requests.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2018, the parties filed a joint status report in which the parties agreed that they had resolved several issues pertaining to the TRO application, but that some matters were still outstanding.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to meet and confer and provide a joint report to the Court.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on July 12, 2019.
