same day, the plaintiff also filed a motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Elaine Bucklo.[SENTMARKER]At a status hearing on February 1, the parties told the judge they had reached a "settlement in principle."[SENTMARKER]On February 2, the plaintiff successfully entered the United States at Chicago O'Hare International Airport.[SENTMARKER]On February 8, the plaintiff filed a motion for voluntary dismissal and leave to reinstate on or before August 1, 2017.[SENTMARKER]Judge Bucklo granted this motion and terminated the case.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 30, 2017, a Syrian national, who was in possession of a valid J-1 visa issued to complete his residency at the University of Illinois College of Medicine/Christ Advocate Hospital, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the President of the United States (President Donald Trump) alleging that his treatment and treatment under the President's January 27, 2017 Executive Order was arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff was detained at Abu Dhabi International Airport on January 29, 2017, and subsequently refused entry onto an Etihad Airways flight bound for Chicago, O'Hare International Airport.[SENTMARKER]According to the terms of the Executive Order, the entry into the US of non-citizens from Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen is "suspended" from 90 days from the date of the EO.[SENTMARKER]In addition to burdening First Amendment rights to religion, the EO also burdens First Amendment right to speech, as well as First amendment rights to political, cultural, and familial associations.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, granted his motion to intervene, and issued an injunction enjoining the enforcement of the executive order, with leave to reinstate on or before 8/1/17.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on February 10, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff is seeking injunctive relief, with costs and attorney's fees.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]14, 2013, 13 Indian guestworkers filed suit in S.D.[SENTMARKER]Miss.[SENTMARKER]for harm suffered as a result of an allegedly fraudulent and coercive employment recruitment scheme.[SENTMARKER]In Oct. 2013, the court transferred this case to E.D.La where it was consolidated with the Achari lead case.[SENTMARKER]The Achari case was dismissed due to settlement agreement but the court retained jurisdiction.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2006, a group of Indian workers brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against Signal International, Inc. (Signal), a private limited liability company organized under the laws of India.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were forced to work in unsafe and unsanitary conditions in a labor camp in Pascagoula, Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged discrimination on the basis of their race, ethnicity, religion, and alienage.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated with a separate suit against Global Resources Inc., also known as Medtech Consultants, in October 2013 and the parties agreed that the case should be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of their employment contract.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed not to retaliate against the plaintiffs in the future.

gold_sents: In 2015, six refugees living in Utica, NY filed this class action in the Northern District of New York against the Utica School District Board of Education and the Utica City School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that that the defendants consistently denied Utica residents between the ages of 17 and 20 who were limited English proficient (LEP) and immigrants access to educational opportunity.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the parties reached a settlement requiring the defendants to end their discriminatory practices and enact a detailed remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]Enforcement of the consent decree is ongoing as of November 2018.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2016, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York against the Utica City School District Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants have a policy and practice of excluding limited English proficient (LEP) immigrant students aged 17-20 from Proctor High School, the only high school in Utica, and diverting them to alternative education programs.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants did not test LEP immigrant students to determine their level of English proficiency before placing them in the Newcomer Program.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also excluded LEP students from the District’s GED program and have no regular contact with English-speaking students.[SENTMARKER]As required by the Equal Educational Opportunities Act (EEOA), the parties entered into a consent decree, which was effective immediately upon the signature of the court on June 6, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the defendants to: (i) provide the plaintiffs with the opportunity to earn a high school diploma; .[SENTMARKER](ii) ensure that the district does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, or national origin; .[SENTMARKER](iii) allow the plaintiffs to participate in the GED program; .[SENTMARKER](iv) provide them with the option to transfer to Proctor High; and (v) allow them to use their native language and English language skills to complete high school.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed that the consent decree will expire four years following the effective date of the decree.

gold_sents: In 2020, two immigration detainees in the Batavia Federal Detention Facility in Batavia, NY, filed this class action in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they and others similarly situated had been improperly denied bond, that non-bond alternatives to detention had not been properly considered by their immigration judges, that such considerations were required by the Immigration and Nationality Act, and that the policy of placing the burden of proof on the Plaintiffs to show they posed no flight risk violated their Fifth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted relief for pre-hearing detainees, agreeing that they pled sufficient facts to state a Due Process Claim that the government is required to bear the burden of proof at bond hearings for individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. §1226(a).[SENTMARKER]It denied Plaintiffs' request to certify the putative post-hearing class.[SENTMARKER]Both parties appealed; the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2020, a group of immigration detainees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York against the Executive Office for Immigration Review (EOIR), the Department of Justice (DOJ), and the Buffalo Federal Detention Facility (BFDC) seeking class certification, a declaratory judgment, and a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The petitioners alleged that the defendants violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Fifth Amendment, and the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the class certification motion in part and denied the motion for a preliminary injunction in part.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the court on July 22, 2020, and the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss on April 27, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed as to the class members detained at the BFDC, and that each class member must be released unless provided with a custody hearing before the Buffalo and Batavia immigration courts.[SENTMARKER]The D&O also agreed to pay the Petitioners' attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: In May 2015, parents of children born in Texas sued the Texas Department of State Health Services.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs, all Mexican or Central American citizens, asked for the release of their U.S.-citizen children's birth certificates, which defendant would not issue after refusing to accept the parents' consular identity documents.[SENTMARKER]The parties privately settled in July 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas by the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF) against the Texas Department of State Health Services (DHSS) and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHSS).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DHSS and HHSS denied access to birth certificates for children born in Texas, who are thus citizens of the United States, on the basis of their immigration status.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a Declaratory Judgment, a .<n>declaratory judgment, and a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction, and denied the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This suit seeks to support Texas's law Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the suits that seek to challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order, this suit aims to support the work of federal immigration officials.[SENTMARKER]There are, so far, four cases addressing SB4.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2017, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed this suit seeking a declaratory judgment approving SB4.[SENTMARKER]Defendants are Travis County, City of Austin, and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF).[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction on May 24, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice to refiling on August 9, 2017, finding that Texas lacked actual or imminent injury, which was required for Article III standing to seek declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Texas appealed to the Fifth Circuit, who affirmed the district court's dismissal of the claim on December 12, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 7, 2017, the State of Texas filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against local governments, elected officials, and a non-profit advocacy group.[SENTMARKER]The State alleged that the local governments had violated the Constitution by refusing to cooperate with federal immigration authorities.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the suit for lack of jurisdiction, ruling that the City of El Paso engaged in a pattern and practice of violating federal immigration law and that the State had not alleged an injury sufficient to warrant a declaratory injunction.[SENTMARKER]On May 18, 2017, the District Court granted the State's motion for a preliminary injunction in the San Antonio Division of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 3, 1993, the U.S. Department of Justice investigated the Harrison County, MI jail.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ found violations of inadequate staffing and medical care.[SENTMARKER]Apparently after negotiation, the Attorney General filed an action under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. 1997 et seq., against the jail in 1995.[SENTMARKER]Six days later, Judge Walter J. Gex III approved a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree mandated doubling the number of officers, increased training, and hiring of medical professionals for the physical and mental health of the patients.[SENTMARKER]The decree was enforced sporadically throughout the next ten years.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2015, the parties filed a joint motion for dismissal, with the county agreeing to continue to use its best efforts to improve its mental health and medical care.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on August 12, 1995.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 1993, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi against Harrison County, Mississippi, alleging violations of the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA) by the Harrison County Adult Detention Center (HCDC).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the HCDC violated the rights of inmates by failing to provide them with adequate access to the courts, inadequate access to law books and legal research materials, inadequate mental health care, and inadequate medical staffing.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to implement a number of reforms to improve conditions of confinement and treatment of inmates.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered on August 12, 2003, and the parties entered a final judgment on December 12, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered by Chief District Judge Louis Guirola, Jr. on 8/12/15, pursuant to the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice, each party to bear its own attorney fees and costs.

gold_sents: In 2003, prisoners filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Erie County Sheriff's Department had an unconstitutional policy and practice of strip-searching prisoners when they entered the county facilities.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the Supreme Court ruled that a similar strip search policy was constitutional in Florence v. Board of Chosen Freeholders.[SENTMARKER]Board of Chosen Freeholders.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case argued that their case was distinguishable from Florence.[SENTMARKER]However, no further action occurred in the case after 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: In the course of a lawsuit by a class of arrested persons against Erie County (and certain of its officials) alleging that they were subjected to unconstitutional strip searches of non-felony detainees, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York granted the plaintiffs' motion for a writ of mandamus.[SENTMARKER]The district court's April 17, 2006 order was vacated; the district court is instructed to determine whether the attorney-client privilege was waived.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to appeal, which was denied by the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit granted the defendants' motion to stay the case pending an appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Two detainees in Shelby County Jail in Tennessee filed this petition for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that failure to take sufficient COVID-19 precautions violated the Fourteenth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and they sought release.[SENTMARKER]The court appointed an "Independent Inspector" to assess conditions at the jail and, based on his report, denied preliminary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied defendants' motion to dismiss, and a trial is scheduled for May 2021.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Inspector was tasked with inspecting the jail to evaluate the conditions.[SENTMARKER]While praising defendants' professionalism, he wrote that several adjustments needed to be made in order for the jail to be a safe place for detainees.[SENTMARKER]After attending mediation and filing a joint motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement, the court preliminarily granted the consent decree requiring monthly reports on the status of COVID-19 in the Jail and unannounced, periodic inspections by the Inspector.[SENTMARKER]A final approval hearing is scheduled for March 5, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2020, the ACLU of Tennessee filed a class-action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against the Shelby County Sheriff's Office on behalf of a class of medically vulnerable and disabled individuals detained at Shelby County Jail due to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief to protect medically vulnerable people and people with disabilities detained at the jail, including the jail's Quarantine / Isolation procedures, the Jail's policies concerning medically screening staff and/or visitors to the Jail, and the Jail’s efforts to limit movement in the Jail.[SENTMARKER]On June 10, 2020, the Court denied the defendants' motion and certified a class and subclass.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a proposed consent decree in which the jail agreed to follow certain procedures to protect people from COVID.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the jail to provide at least one mask to all detainees, provide free soap and that soap is not to be confiscated if the inmates have more than one bar.[SENTMARKER]The jail also agreed to provide the plaintiffs with access to the Skype for Business webpage for instructions on downloading the proper extensions for their computer.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree on June 11, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to work out the details of the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In August 2014, detainees at the Franklin County Jail filed a lawsuit alleging that jail officials used excessive force against them and that the jail provided inhumane living conditions, in violation of the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In March 28, 2016, the parties settled.[SENTMARKER]The defendant paid $400,557.66 in attorneys’ fees and was required to hire additional staff, renovate the prison, and adopt new mental health services policies.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2014, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington on behalf of inmates at the Franklin County Corrections Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail's widespread unconstitutional 13 practices, including the use of four point restraints against inmates, violated their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on February 5, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion for referral to a magistrate for 5 settlement conference on December 8, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a 17 settlement, which was approved by the Court on July 31, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties have also agreed to end or end certain practices at the Jail.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed and the parties have entered into a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2011, a private company filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the National Security Letters (NSLs) issued by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to telecommunications and Internet service providers violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The NSLs allowed the FBI to demand non-content information from telecommunications providers in counterintelligence investigations.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the NSL law violated their First Amendment rights by prohibiting them from disclosing information about their customers to the press, members of the public, and members of Congress.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the government's cross-petition to set aside the nondisclosure provision in each of these cases.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the Second Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit agreed with the district court's decision in part, but remanded the case to the lower court to address the first amendment issues presented in the 2006 Reauthorization Act of 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending before the Ninth Circuit.

gold_sents: In 2014, an investigative reporter filed suit under the Freedom of Information Act against the National Security Agency and U.S. Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants were improperly withholding records concerning the NSA's surveillance of federal and state judges.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the defendant conduct an email search for draft memoranda or opinions concerning such surveillance program.[SENTMARKER]The search wielded no results.[SENTMARKER]A settlement agreement was reached paying plaintiff's attorney's fees on February 27, 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2014, Plaintiff Jason Leopold filed this Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the National Security Agency (NSA), the Department of Justice (DOJ), and the Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) seeking records related to the NSA's bulk collection and storage of telephone metadata.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated FOIA by failing to conduct an adequate search of the requested records.[SENTMARKER]In July 2015, the district court granted the defendants' first motion for summary judgment, finding that they had no records responsive to Plaintiff's FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a second motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion, and the parties agreed to reprocess the FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2016, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants, granting the defendants summary judgment and ordering the defendants to search their records for responsive documents.

gold_sents: On September 16, 2016, The Associated Press, Gannett Satellite Information Network LLC, and Vice Media, LLC, filed a lawsuit seeking information about the recently purchased tool allowing government access to the phone of one of the perpetrators of the mass killings in San Bernardino, California on December 2, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendant's summary judgment motion on September 30, 2017, finding information at issue was protected under FOIA exemptions 1, 3, and 7.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2016, two news organizations, USA TODAY and The Washington Post, filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request with the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia seeking documents related to the use of a third-party vendor to circumvent the need for a court order to access the locked iPhone of Syed Rizwan Farook, one of the perpetrators of the mass killings in San Bernardino, California.[SENTMARKER]The FBI initially denied each request on the basis of FOIA Exemption 7(A), which permits agencies to withhold records for law enforcement purposes to the extent that the production of such records could reasonably be expected to interfere with law enforcement proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On June 20, 2016, USA TODAY timely appealed the denial, arguing that the FBI had applied exemption in violation of the law.[SENTMARKER]On April 21, 2016, AP reporter Eric Tucker filed a FOIA request (the "AP Request") with the FBI for records of the publicly-acknowledged business transaction that resulted in the purchase this March of the so-called iPhone access tool.[SENTMARKER]The VICE Request 28 was filed on April 21, 2016.[SENTMARKER]On June 6, 2016, the FBI denied the VICE Request.[SENTMARKER]On September 30, 2017, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment in favor of the News Organizations.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the FBI to produce the records sought by the VICE requester, as well as the documents identified in connection with those requests.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay the plaintiffs' costs of this proceeding, including reasonable attorney's fees, as authorized by FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On January 17, 2006, plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the National Security Agency alleging that the Terrorist Surveillance Program was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On August 17, 2006, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan (Judge Taylor) agreed and enjoined the program.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2007, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit vacated the order and instructed to dismiss the case based on lack of standing.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan on January 17, 2006 by the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers and the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the National Security Agency (NSA) violated the separation of powers doctrine and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) by accessing the communications of innocent Americans without court approval.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the basis of the state secrets evidentiary privilege and their lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court and it dismissed the plaintiffs’ claims against the NSA and the individuals connected with the NSA’s alleged monitoring.[SENTMARKER]On August 17, 2006, the plaintiffs filed a notice of appeal to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]On September 4, 2007, the case was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction and the plaintiffs appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States denied the appeal and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: The plaintiff, an individual citizen and lawful resident of the United States that was denied boarding a flight from the United Arab Emirates to the United States because of his alleged inclusion on the No Fly List of the federal government, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff specifically alleged that his inclusion on the No Fly List was to coerce him to be an FBI informant.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief for the federal government's various alleged constitutional violations and torture.[SENTMARKER]To date, the case remains pending.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 30, 2013, a man filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the National Security Agency (NSA) alleging that the defendants violated his Fourth Amendment rights by subjecting him to torture in violation of the Torture Victim Protection Act (TPA) and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act ( FISA).[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a declaratory and injunctive relief order in November 2013 and the court dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On November 4, 2015, the court granted Defendants' Motion in part and denied it in part.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's dismissal of Plaintiff's Fourth Amendment claim with prejudice in light of the defendants' violations of the TPA and FISA.[SENTMARKER]In a separate opinion, the Ninth Circuit upheld the dismissal of the plaintiff's procedural and substantive due-process claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On May 8, 2009, the American Civil Liberties Union ("ACLU") of Washington filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU sued the United States Department of Justice ("DOJ") under the Freedom of Information Act ("FOIA").[SENTMARKER]The ACLU asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief to compel the DOJ to disclose and release records it was improperly withholding from the ACLU regarding the National Crime Information Center Violent Gang and Terrorist Organization File ("CVGTOF"), which contains entries on suspected terrorist organizations and individuals.[SENTMARKER]Though the DOJ moved to dismiss the case, on March 10, 2011, U.S. District Court Judge Robert S. Lasnik only granted the motion to dismiss in part, and ordered the DOJ to edit any inappropriate redactions and provide the Court with more facts that would justify a claimed exemption.[SENTMARKER]After some back and forth regarding the confidentiality of the requested documents, the DOJ was required to release certain documents and on March 7, 2013 the parties came to an agreement whereby the United States was to pay the ACLU $50,000 within 60 days via wire transfer, as full settlement for attorneys' fees and costs incurred by the ACLU in this lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2008, the American Civil Liberties Union of Washington (ACLU) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request under 5 U.S.C.  552 for records describing the operation and maintenance of the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) Violent Gang and Terrorist Organization File (VGTOF) maintained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (DOJ) in Seattle, Washington.[SENTMARKER]In May 2009, the ACLU filed this action to compel the release of the requested records.[SENTMARKER]On November 17, 2009, the DOJ denied the ACLU's request for a fee waiver and 12 renewed its processing of the plaintiff's FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On May 19, 2011, the Court granted the DOJ's motion for summary judgment regarding the adequacy of its search and the production of reasonably segregable portions of the record.[SENTMARKER]On March 10, 2011, the court ordered the DOJ to produce specific categories of documents under the FOIA, including the Transportation Security Administration's (TSA) Integrated Automated Fingerprint Identification System (IAFIS) and the Department of Justice's Counterintelligence Sharing Procedures for Foreign Intelligence and Foreign Intelligence.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the FBI to produce documents that would disclose travel patterns and regional data.[SENTMARKER]The case has been ongoing for over two years.

gold_sents: In 2017, the NAACP filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Commerce for failure to provide it with records under the FOIA concerning its preparations for the 2020 census.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged the Census Bureau was failing to adhere to deadlines, failing to confirm certain requests, and refusing to disclose documents in a timely manner in violation of 5 U.S.C. § 552 and 15 C.F.R § 4.6.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the parties reached a settlement that required disclosure of the documents within several weeks and awarded attorneys' fees to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case likely closed in September 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 5, 2017, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), NAACP Connecticut State Conference, and NAACP Boston Branch filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut (New Haven) against the Department of Commerce (DOC), of which the Census Bureau is a component, seeking the release of certain records relating to the 2020 census.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOC failed to respond to Plaintiffs' FOIA request within the statutory deadline, in violation of 15 C.F.R.  4.6(f)(4), and erroneously denied Plaintiffs' public interest fee waiver or fee reduction request.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement in which the DOC agreed to release all responsive, non-exempt records responsive to the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On March 7, 2018, the parties filed a joint motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to make reasonable efforts to resolve any disputes before making an application to the Court.[SENTMARKER]On February 4, 2019, the parties entered into a settlement agreement, which required the DOC to release certain records to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment and ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' legal fees and costs.

gold_sents: Jacqueline Jones filed this lawsuit challenging Florida's failure to provide her with sufficient home care services via the Traumatic Brain Injury/Spinal Cord Injury Medicaid waiver.[SENTMARKER]Although she sought to expand her case to represent a class of plaintiffs, the state began providing her with appropriate services after her lawsuit was filed and she agreed to a voluntary dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 2, 2009, a Florida resident with a severe disability who had been paralyzed in a car accident filed a private lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the State of Florida, alleging that the state was using Medicaid's home and community based waiver services to provide essential long term care to some residents with disabilities, but not to others.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were violating Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehab Act) by failing to provide in-home personal care services for adults who require them, both disabled and nondisabled, within nursing facilities.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice pursuant to the settlement terms of January 4, 2007 and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On November 28, 2005, the Florida Pediatric Society, the Florida Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics, the Florida Academy of Pediatric Dentistry, Inc., and certain named individual children who are eligible to receive medical and dental care through Medicaid filed this class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued several state defendants in their official capacities, claiming that these defendants violated Title XIX of the Social Security Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1396 et seq. (also known as the Medicaid Act), by failing to provide essential medical and dental services to eligible children in Florida.[SENTMARKER]After extensive discovery and a lengthy trial, the District Court (Judge Adalberto Jordan) held that the defendants were liable in several respects.[SENTMARKER]After several months of settlement discussions, the court approved a final settlement agreement on June 28, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The Court has jurisdiction over the litigation until September 30, 2022.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs $12,000,000 to cover attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: The Florida Pediatric Society/The Florida Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics (FPS), the Florida Academy of Pediatric Dentistry, Inc. (FAPD), and the named plaintiffs and their families filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the Florida Agency for Health Care Administration (AHCA) and the Florida Department of Children and Family Services (DCF) on behalf of more than 1.6 million children who are enrolled in the Florida Title XIX and EPSDT services program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that more than 500,000 Medicaid-enrolled children were not furnished with preventative healthcare in violation of federal law.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the plaintiffs sought an injunction to force the defendants to comply with Florida laws regulating the sale of insurance.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for partial summary judgment, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a confidential settlement agreement in September 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: (i) the defendants would pay the plaintiffs a total of $1 million, (ii) the parties would evaluate their current internet-based information for customers on the use of the self-service portal, and (iii) they would make improvements to the web based information about the payment of dental services.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into on May 19, 2009 and is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: On December 28, 2011, two Hawaii-based religious organizations filed a lawsuit in United States District Court against the State of Hawaii.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit alleged that a California law set to take effect in 2012 was chilling plaintiffs' religious freedom and unconstitutional under the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The case was stayed, and the law changed in July of 2012.[SENTMARKER]On October 3, 2012, the case was dismissed for lack of standing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 28, 2011, a group of same-sex couples filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Hawaii against the State of Hawaii, the Governor, and the Director of the State Department of Health, seeking declaratory and prospective injunctive relief, in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the plaintiffs' First Amendment rights by refusing to rent their church grounds for same sex ceremonies and receptions.[SENTMARKER]On December 30, 2011, the court denied the parties' motion for a preliminary injunction, and on October 2, 2012, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the action without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On January 1, 2012, the Hawaii legislature passed a law prohibiting same sex couples from renting the premises of religious institutions, churches, and houses of worship in the state of Hawaii.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the decision to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court reversed the lower court's decision, and remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 28, 1991, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DCFS violated the federal statutes and the federal Constitution by failing to provide adequate food and shelter to homeless children and their families.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, including the appointment of a monitor to monitor DCFS's compliance with the terms of a consent order.[SENTMARKER]The consent order was approved by the court on March 28, 1991 and the parties settled the case on March 29, 1991.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction in part and denied the motion for an injunctive order in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the monitor would report to the court and make recommendations concerning the implementation of the consent order for a period of four years from July 1, 1991.[SENTMARKER]In part, the court granted preliminary injunction relief to two of the named plaintiffs in May 1990, and the case was resolvind on its merits or the Seventh Circuit resolved the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On Sept.[SENTMARKER]8, 2014, a same-sex couple filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Indiana under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against a county clerk and the Indiana Department of Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the state's ban on same-sex marriages violated the their 14th Amendment rights to due process and equal protection.[SENTMARKER]After the 7th Circuit struck down Indiana's marriage ban, the state agreed to recognize the plaintiffs' out-of-state marriage pending a final resolution to the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 11, 2014, two same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Indiana against the State of Indiana, the Lake County Clerk's Office, and the Indiana State Department of Health.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and permanent injunctive relief for their violation of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, and for the harm caused by the State's refusal to recognize their out-of-state marriage.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a temporary restraining order and/or a preliminary injunction, but the parties agreed that the case should be stayed until the Supreme Court issues its decision regarding the appeal in an adversarial legal system.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2014, the court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed not to enforce Indiana Code  31-11-1-1(a) against any other source of Indiana law that discriminates against same sex couples.

gold_sents: In 2013, three same-sex couples married under the laws of other states filed a lawsuit, individually and on behalf of their children, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky against the Commonwealth of Kentucky, challenging the constitutionality of Kentucky's laws prohibiting same-sex couples from marrying and voiding within Kentucky marriages of same-sex couples validly entered into under the laws of other states and countries.[SENTMARKER]Judge John Heyburn found for the plaintiffs on July 1st, 2014, and issued the final order declaring Kentucky laws banning same-sex marriages to be unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]This order was stayed and then reversed by the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is pending before the U.S. Supreme Court.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 27, 2014, a group of same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky against the State of Kentucky.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged Kentucky's ban on recognizing out-of-state marriages and the state's refusal to issue marriage licenses to those couples.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs relief in two of the cases.[SENTMARKER]The case was restyled on February 27, 2014 and the Supreme Court of Massachusetts ruled in favor of the plaintiffs in the other two cases.[SENTMARKER]In the second case, the plaintiffs challenged Ohio's denial of recognition of out- of-state marriage.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the Ohio law violated the due process and equal protection guarantees of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court held that there was no basis for the state to appeal the district court's decision.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought by Disability Advocates, Inc. against the Governor of the State of New York seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to compel Defendant to provide services in the most integrated setting appropriate.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued judgment in favor of Plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]After the Defendants appealed, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit vacated the judgment of the District Court and dismissed the action due to lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ continued to pursue a settlement.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2013, the State and the DOJ filed a settlement to provide approximately 4000 qualifying adult home residents the option of living in community-supported private homes scattered throughout New York City.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved in March 2014.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was amended and changed several times from 2014 to 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing and the court maintains jurisdiction.

(DAAS) brought this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York on behalf of individuals with mental illness residing in New York City adult homes.[SENTMARKER]DAAS alleged that the adult homes violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by not ensuring that adulthome residents were receiving services in the most integrated setting appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted partial summary judgment to the plaintiffs, holding that the State's failure to place L.C.[SENTMARKER]residents in the community violated the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the district court's holding but remanded for a reassessment of the state's costbased defense.[SENTMARKER]The parties negotiated a settlement in the aftermath of the Second Circuit's ruling in which the parties agreed to pay up to $75,000 annually to DAAS.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2012, the parties filed a motion to intervene in the case and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the court on July 23, 2013 and is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs are lesbian couples who filed suit on November 3, 2004 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma, against the United States and the State of Oklahoma, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and Article 2 § 35 of the Oklahoma Constitution (the "Oklahoma Amendment") violate the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that DOMA and the Oklahoma Amendment violates the Due Process, Equal Protection, Full Faith and Credit, and Privileges and Immunities Clauses of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court found for the plaintiffs, holding on Jan.[SENTMARKER]14, 2014 that the ban on same-sex marriage violated the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit found for the plaintiffs on July 18, 2014, and after the Supreme Court denied a petition for a writ of certiorari (on October 6, 2014), the Court lifted the stay on its original mandate and enjoined the Defendant from enforcing the Oklahoma Amendment and denying same-sex couples marriage licenses.[SENTMARKER]The Court awarded $309,485.27 in attorney's fees to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 3, 2004, three same-sex couples filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma challenging the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and Oklahoma's amendment to its Constitution (Oklahoma Amendment) prohibiting same sex couples from being married in Oklahoma and the recognition of out-of-state same sex marriages.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the venue of the case was improper and that the Oklahoma Amendment violated the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]In response to the plaintiffs' complaint, the Oklahoma officials moved to dismiss, claiming venue was improper, the plaintiffs lacked standing, and the suit was barred by the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment, but the district court allowed the plaintiffs to file an amended complaint naming the State of Oklahoma as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Tenth Circuit and the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the defendants in a similar case in 2007 and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought by workers with limited English proficiency, whose jobs were lost or threatened by foreign competition against the U.S. Department of Labor, seeking injunctive relief, a declaratory judgment and costs for the DOL's failure to provide adequate training under the Trade Act of 1974.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on December 30, 2005 and resulted in the establishment of a program for Limited English-Proficient workers in the El Paso area by the DOL as well as widespread policy changes as to the administration of the job training benefits.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2002, the Association of Border Workers (ATF) and several of its members filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the Department of Labor (DOL) alleging that the Department violated the Trade Act of 1974 (Trade Act) by failing to provide training benefits to limited English proficient (LEP) workers in the El Paso, Texas area.[SENTMARKER]The Trade Act prohibits approval of incomplete training.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on December 17, 2003 and the parties entered a settlement agreement on November 5, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to fund and administer a project for LEP workers who lose their jobs to foreign competition.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay each party's attorney fees and costs associated with the project.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On September 13, 2013, an African American inmate in the Arizona State Prison Complex in Tucson filed this lawsuit against the State of Arizona and the Arizona Department of Correction in the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]He sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the prison segregated him by race, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on December 22, 2015, under which the defendants would narrowly limit racial consideration in prison housing and employment opportunities, and pay $5,000 in monetary damages to plaintiff as well as $195,000 to plaintiff’s counsel in attorneys’ fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 20, 2013, a prisoner at the Arizona State Prison Complex-Tucson filed a pro se civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the Arizona Department of Corrections, alleging that the prison's policy of racial segregation violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The prisoner alleged that he was assigned to and retained in segregation on the basis of his race, in violation of the Constitution's equal protection clause.[SENTMARKER]On June 9, 2014, the defendant filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement on December 22, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendant to develop and institute policies, procedures, and practices necessary to implement an integrated housing program.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to pay the prisoner a total of $2,100.[SENTMARKER]The settlement amount was determined by multiplying the amount of the settlement by the number of inmates housed at the prison complex.

pegasus_output_sents: This is an action for relief from Defendants’ violation of the rights of persons with psychiatric disabilities under the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, and California Government Code section 11135.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff seeks declaratory and injunctive relief, and reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs, for defendants’ violations of his rights.[SENTMARKER]On November 17, 2006, defendants California Department of Corrections and 24 Rehabilitation (CDCR), Schwarzenegger, Tilton, Woodford, Poulos and Dovey filed a Rule 12(b) and (f) motion to dismiss the case in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California.[SENTMARKER]On December 1, 2005, the parties filed amended complaints, alleging violations of the 18 ADA and Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties did not reach a settlement, and the case was stayed on March 15, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the United States Supreme Court and the Supreme Court affirmed the decision on May 3, 2011.

gold_sents: In 2016, two Missouri Medicaid recipients filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri after being denied medication to treat their Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Missouri Department of Social Services and MO HealthNet denied medically necessary treatment to Medicaid beneficiaries with Hepatitis C, discriminated against similarly situated Medicaid beneficiaries, failed to provide "reasonably prompt" treatment, violated due process, and violated the American with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In November 2017, MO HealthNet modified its policies and the case was dismissed as moot without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in November 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 22, 2013, the U.S.[SENTMARKER]Food and Drug Administration approved a new direct acting antiviral (DAA) treatment for Hepatitis C virus (HCV), a serious and communicable disease that can cause severe liver scarring, liver damage, cancer, and death.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, the Missouri Department of Social Services (DSS) and the Missouri HealthNet program, denied coverage for medically necessary treatment for some Medicaid enrollees with Hepatitis C because of the defendants' arbitrary and improper policies that restrict treatment only to the sickest beneficiaries.[SENTMARKER]The DSS and MO HealthNet denied the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction prohibiting the defendants from requiring three months of negative drug and alcohol screens prior to submitting requests for DAA approval.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs’ request for an injunction, requiring the defendants to provide coverage for all Medicaid beneficiaries with HCV.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri.

pegasus_output_sents: On December 15, 2010, the ACLU of Washington filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the City of Mount Vernon, Washington and the city of Burlington, Washington, alleging that the defendants violated the constitutional rights of indigent persons charged with crimes in the municipal courts of the two cities by systematically failing to provide assistance of counsel to the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that defendants had jointly maintained a contract system of 12 providing for the defense of the defendants in the courts of 13 Mount Vernon and Burlington.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to extend the duration of the contract by two years to 2 December 31, 2012.[SENTMARKER]In the event of any litigation arising out of this agreement, the prevailing party will be reimbursed for reasonable attorneys' fees from the other party.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the United States entered a Memorandum of Agreement with King County, Washington in order to reform the King County Correctional Facility.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed this suit to challenge the constitutional adequacy of the public defense system provided by King County and the cities.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 5, 2011.

gold_sents: On November 13, 2018, CNN and CNN’s chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta sued President Trump and several senior members of his administration for violating his First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking his White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]under The plaintiffs sued under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgments Act, arguing that defendants violated the Constitution and APA when they revoked Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting that the court require the defendants to restore Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on November 19, 2018 after the Trump administration returned Acosta's White House press credentials to him.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 15, 2018, CNN and its chief White House correspondent, Jim Acosta, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald J. Trump, the White House, and the United States Secret Service.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleges that the defendants violated Acosta's First Amendment rights when they revoked his White House press credentials and barred him from covering the President's press conference and the midterm elections.[SENTMARKER]The White House had not told CNN and Acosta that his credentials were revoked in advance of the revocation.[SENTMARKER]On November 9, 2018, President Trump held a press conference to mark the centennial of the end of the First World War, and Acosta asked the President questions about the war.[SENTMARKER]The President accused Acosta of "placing his hands" on a White House staffer who attempted to take the microphone from him during the press conference.[SENTMARKER]The Secret Service denied Acosta access to President Trump during that press conference, and on November 10, 2018, the Secret Service revoked his press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On December 5, 2018, CNN filed an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order and permanent injunction against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on November 15, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2019, the District Court issued a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, concluding that the revocation of their press credentials violated the First Amendment and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to further litigation.

gold_sents: When mass protests against police violence were exempted from New York’s COVID-19 gathering restrictions, but congregational worship continued to be prohibited, two Catholic priests and three Orthodox Jews brought this lawsuit, alleging that New York officials were discriminating against people of faith.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 26, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 10, 2020, a group of New York Catholics filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of the New York against New York Governor Andrew M. Cuomo, Attorney General Letitia James, and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First Amendment rights to freedom of exercise, speech, assembly, and expressive association, and their Fourteenth Amendment right to equal protection.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that New York’s 10-person outdoor gathering limit and the Phase 2 limitation on indoor religious services at 25 percent capacity violate their constitutional rights to participate in congregate religious activities.[SENTMARKER]On June 11, 2020, the plaintiffs filed an application for a temporary restraining order (TRO) Dkt No. 7 against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The TRO was granted on June 26, 2020, and the parties agreed to a final injunctive order on October 9, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On October 9, 2020, the defendants filed an appeal, which was denied by the Second Circuit on October 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: DATE | ORG ||| DATE ||| LAW ||| ORG [CONTRACTED] In August 1970, the Detroit Federation of Teachers (DFT) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the Detroit Board of Education, the Detroit Superintendent of Public Instruction, and various local and state officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had engaged in intentional racial segregation of the Detroit public schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the district was segregated on the basis of race and ordered the parties to submit plans to desegregate the Detroit Public Schools.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for an expedited trial on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed the District Court's denial of the motion to intervene on May 2, 1986.
